questions.text: During routine dissection classes, you and your friend are discussing and revising the circulation of cerebrospinal fluid. Your friend forgets the name of the space marked X in the image. You would remind him that space marked 'X' is ______________
questions.solution:
The marked structure located just inferior to the nodule of the cerebellum is the Foramen of Magendie. It is the median aperture present in the roof of the fourth ventricle. The fourth ventricle communicates with the subarachnoid space of the cisterna magna through this foramen.

The 4th ventricle is a tent-shaped ventricle lying between the brainstem and the cerebellum. It is widest at the level of the pontomedullary junction.

The roof of the 4th ventricle is formed by the superior medullary velum and inferior medullary velum. The superior medullary velum is made of white matter and stretches between the superior cerebellar peduncles. The inferior medullary velum is devoid of any nervous tissue. It is made of ventricular ependyma and pia mater of tela choroidea. It is pierced by the foramen of Magendie in the midline opening into the cisterna magna. The lateral openings of the ventricle are foramina of Luschka. These openings allow the flow of CSF from the ventricle into the subarachnoid space.

The T-shaped choroid plexus of the 4th ventricle is formed from the tela choroidea and is supplied by the posterior inferior cerebellar arteries. 

 Communications of the ventricular system:

  • Lateral ventricle to the third ventricle: Foramen of Monro
  • III ventricle to IV ventricle: Cerebral aqueduct of Sylvius
  • IV ventricle to subarachnoid space
    • Cisterna magna: Foramen of Magendie (midline)
    • Subarachnoid space: Foramina of Luschka (laterally)

Clinical note:

  • The outflow of CSF from the IV ventricle is via the medial outlet. This is covered by a membrane in the fetus which perforates later. The persistence of this membrane causes cystic obstruction. 
  • In Dandy-Walker malformation, there is the presence of many posterior fossa anomalies such as cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle,  hydrocephalus, hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis, and an enlarged posterior fossa.

questions.text: Identify the virus in the transmission cycle shown in the given image:
questions.solution:
The transmission cycle of the Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus is shown in the image. 

Japanese encephalitis follows bird-arthropod-human transmission. Humans are the dead-end hosts, pigs are the amplifier hosts, and herons act as reservoir hosts. The disease is transmitted by the bite of Culex mosquitoes, specifically Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui (common in India)

Clinical features include high fever, headache, and vomiting. Signs of encephalitis such as convulsions, neck rigidity, and altered sensorium appear after 1-6 days. Measures like mosquito control, and locating piggeries away from houses can be done.

Inactivated vero cell culture-derived SA-14-14-2 vaccine is approved for use in India. JE vaccine is given in two doses- at 9-12 months of age and at 16-24 months of age in areas that are endemic to the disease, according to the National Immunization Schedule. 

Other options:

Option-A: Nipah virus is a zoonotic virus, which is transmitted from pigs to humans. Fruit bats are the natural hosts. It causes severe encephalitis with high mortality. 

The image given below depicts the life cycle of the Nipah virus:

 

Option B: Ebola virus belongs to the family Filoviridae and is transmitted by bats. Human-to-human transmission through blood or body fluids can occur. It causes fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and hemorrhage. 

The image below shows the lifecycle of the ebola virus:

 

Option D: Zika virus is transmitted to human beings by the bite of an infected Aedes mosquito. It can also be transmitted trans-placentally, causing microcephaly and other severe fetal brain defects.

questions.solution:
The correct match is as follows:

Part of Urethra  Lining epithelium
A. Prostatic 2. Urothelium
B. Membranous 3. Stratified columnar
C. Distal penile 1. Stratified squamous
D. External meatus 4. Keratinized squamous

Transitional epithelium/Urothelium is found in the renal pelvis and calyces, the ureter, the urinary bladder, and the pre-prostatic and prostatic part of the urethra. 

In the urinary bladder, it is usually observed that transitional epithelium can be stretched considerably without being damaged. When stretched it appears to be thinner and the cells become flattened or rounded.  

The following are various parts of the urethra in males and their lining epithelium:

  • Pre-prostatic & Prostatic urethra: Transitional epithelium
  • Membranous urethra: Pseudostratified columnar or Stratified columnar
  • Penile/Spongy urethra: Proximally: Pseudostratified columnar or Stratified columnar, Distally: Stratified squamous
  • External urethral meatus: Keratinised stratified squamous epithelium.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old lady presented with pain and swelling in her left arm. Her X-Ray is shown in the image below. Which among the following are primary conditions with which it is can be associated?
  1. Paget's disease
  2. Previous radiation therapy with 1500 cGy
  3. Osteoporosis
  4. Fibrous dysplasia
  5. Chondrosarcoma
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis, in this case, is osteosarcoma which can be secondary to Paget's disease, Chondrosarcoma, and Fibrous dysplasia. Osteosarcoma secondary to radiation therapy occurs with doses >2500 cGy.

The above x-ray shows irregular destruction in the metaphysis overshadowed by the formation of new bone, lifting of the periosteum inciting a periosteal reaction and new bone formation along the blood vessels within the tumour centrifugally - sunburst (sunray) appearance. 

Secondary osteosarcomas occur at the site of another disease process and constitute almost half of the osteosarcomas in patients >50 years of age. They have a less favourable prognosis. The most common factors associated with secondary osteosarcomas include Paget disease and previous radiation therapy.

Osteosarcoma secondary to Paget disease usually occurs in the sixth to eighth decades of life. The pelvis is the most common site, but the femur, humerus and skull can also be involved. It presents with the appearance of pain or swelling in a patient with long-standing Paget’s disease. Pathological femoral fractures may occur. The mean age at presentation is 71 years. X-rays show a typical pagetic bone with a lytic destructive mass extending into the soft tissues.

Radiation doses greater than 2500 cGy lead to osteosarcoma and occurs in sites such as the pelvis, scapula, skull, spine, clavicle, and ribs The onset of secondary osteosarcoma averages 10 to 15 years after radiation exposure but can occur as early as after 3 years.

Other conditions that can lead to secondary osteosarcoma are:

  • Fibrous dysplasia
  • Bone infarcts
  • Chondrosarcoma
  • Chronic osteomyelitis
  • Melorheostosis, and
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta

Treatment: Chemotherapy with doxorubicin, cisplatin, ifosfamide and methotrexate for 8–12 weeks. Tumour is then restaged and resected with limb reconstruction if the tumour is resectable with no skip lesions.

questions.text: An elderly woman is undergoing following therapy for her chronic knee pain. Which of the following statements is true regarding the procedure done below?

choices.text: There is inhibition at the presynaptic level in the dorsal horn
The unmyelinated C fibres block the propagation in the myelinated fibers
Pacemaker is not a contraindication for this procedure
Decreases the levels of endorphins and enkephalins

questions.solution:
The given image shows transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation. It acts by inhibition at the presynaptic level in the dorsal horn.

Rubbing or shaking an injured area can decrease the pain due to injury. This is called gate-control mechanism of pain modulation and has been used transcutaneous electrical stimulation (TENS). It is based on the mechanism that the myelinated Aα and Aβ fibres block the propagation in the unmyelinated C fibers.

Rubbing, shaking over the skin causes activation of the Aα and Aβ myelinated fibres. Impulses from these fibres presynaptically inhibit the nociceptive impulses from the small, unmyelinated C fibres in the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn. It also increases the levels of endorphins and enkephalins.

Indication of TENS

  • Neurogenic pain
  • Musculoskeletal pain
  • Visceral pain and dysmenorrhea
  • Diabetic neuropathy
  • Urge incontinence

 Contraindication of TENS

  • TENS should not be used in patients having pacemakers
  • Pregnancy- Should be avoided in pregnancy with complications, prior abortions, as it can cause premature abortion
  • It should not be placed over the anterior neck or over the carotid sinus as it can cause laryngospasm or hypotension
  • It should not be placed over burn skin

questions.text:
A truck driver presents to the dermatology clinic with painful lesions on his genitals. On examination, there were clusters of vesicles with an erythematous base. A smear is prepared from the lesion and stained accordingly, shown in the image below. Which of the following is true about the causative organism?
  1. Type 2 is most commonly responsible for the given condition
  2. Type 1 remains latent primarily in the sacral ganglia
  3. Type 1 infection confers protection against type 2
  4. Postnatal infection is more commonly due to type 1
  5. Infectivity of type 2 is more temperature-sensitive than that of type 1
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing clusters of vesicles with an erythematous base and smear shows Tzanck cells or multinucleated giant cells is seen in genital herpes caused by the Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) which can be Type 1 (HHV 1) or type 2 (HHV 2). Statements 1, 4, and 5 are true about the two types of HSV.

The Tzanck smear is a rapid, sensitive and inexpensive diagnostic method.  Smears are prepared from the lesions, from the base of vesicles and stained with 1 % aqueous solution of toluidine blue 'O ' for 15 seconds. Multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained 'ground glass' chromatin known as Tzanck cells are seen.

The given condition is genital herpes which may be caused by both types of HSV but is more commonly caused by Type 2.

HSV 1 is usually isolated from lesions in and around the mouth and is transmitted by direct contact or droplet spread from cases or carriers. HSV 2 is responsible for majority of genital herpes infections and is commonly transmitted venereally.

Differentiating features between the two types is mostly demonstrated in a laboratory set-up where the infectivity of type 2 is more temperature sensitive than that of type 1. 

Transmission :

The virus enters through defects in the skin or mucous membranes and enters cutaneous nerve fibres and is transported intra-axonally to the ganglia where it replicates. The virus remains latent in the ganglia, particularly the trigeminal (type 1) and the sacral (type 2) nerves to be reactivated periodically causing recurrent oral and genital lesions.

The typical herpes lesions are thin-walled, umbilicated vesicles, the roof of which breaks down, leaving tiny superficial ulcers . They heal without scarring. The most common site of cutaneous lesions is the face - on the cheeks, chin, around the mouth or on the forehead.

HSV 2 infection confers some protection against HSV 1, but not vice versa.

The clinical course depends on the site of the infection, age and immune status of the host and the type of virus. It can either be cutaneous, mucosal, ophthalmic, neuologic, visceral, genetic or congenital.

Transplacental infection can occur with both types but is quite rare. Infection can occur during birth if the mother has genital lesions due to HSV 2. Cesarean section is done to prevent infection. Postnatal infection is more commonly due to type 1. The mortality rate of neonatal herpes is quite high and may leave neurological impairments.

questions.solution:

Third step – Proceed if the patient is unresponsive. Shout for help.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male patient is being evaluated for infertility. His semen analysis shows a sperm concentration of 10 million/ml, pH of 7.5, and volume of 2 mL. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The semen analysis showing a sperm concentration of 10 million/mL (<15 million/mL), and normal pH and volume are suggestive of oligozoospermia. 

According to the WHO 2010 criteria for semen analysis, the lower reference limit for normal sperm concentration is 15 million/mL. Oligozoospermia is defined as a sperm concentration <15 million/mL, and counts <5 million/mL are considered severe.

Other options: 

Option A: Normozoospermia refers to normal values of all ejaculate parameters. 

Option C: Azoospermia refers to no spermatozoa in the ejaculate. 

Option D: Aspermia refers to no semen.

questions.text:
A teenager developed swelling of the face, lips, and tongue and also found it difficult to breathe within a few minutes of consumption of prawns. What are the major cytokines produced in this condition? (IL- Interleukin, IFN-γ -Interferon gamma)
  1. IL-4
  2. IL-5
  3. IL-6
  4. IL-13
  5. IL-17
  6. IFN-γ
questions.solution:
Anaphylaxis following consumption of prawns is an example of IgE-mediated reaction or Type 1 hypersensitivity where the major cytokines involved are IL-4, IL-5 and IL-13.

Immediate (Type I) hypersensitivity reactions refer to allergic reactions or allergies. It is a rapid immunologic reaction that is triggered by the binding of an antigen to IgE antibody on the surface of mast cells. It occurs in a previously sensitized individual. These reactions are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals. 

Activation of TH2 cells is mediated by IL-4 and in turn, TH2 cells produce IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13. These cytokines act on B cells to stimulate IgE and activation of eosinophils. IgE coats mast cells by binding to the FcεRI receptor. Re-exposure to the allergen leads to cross-linking of the IgE and FcεRI which in turn causes activation of mast cells releasing powerful mediators. The principal mediators are:

  • Histamine
  • Proteases
  • Prostaglandins
  • Leukotrienes
  • Cytokines like TNF, IL-1, and chemokines. 

The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mildly annoying rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis. It occurs in two phases: 

  • The immediate phase is characterized by vasodilation, vascular leakage, smooth muscle spasm (in asthma), or glandular secretions. These changes occur within minutes after exposure to an allergen and subside in a few hours.
  • Late-phase reaction is characterized by infiltration of tissues with eosinophils, neutrophils, basophils, monocytes, and CD4+ T cells. Late-phase reaction sets in 2 to 24 hours later and may last for several days.

Image: Sequence of events in immediate (type 1) hypersensitivity.

Other options:

  • IL-6 is a principal mediator of inflammation.
  • IL-17 secreted by T lymphocytes is plays a role in acute and chronic inflammation by recruiting of neutrophils and monocytes.
  • IFN-γ activates macrophages and is a mediator of chronic inflammation.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man with a Cluster A personality disorder is described by his family members as odd, aloof, and isolated. He lives alone and prefers to work in isolation. Identify the features congruent with the diagnosis.
  1. A history of aggressive verbal behavior 
  2. Isolation is due to fear of criticism or rejection
  3. Appears to be indifferent to the praise or criticism of others
  4. Under stress, there is development of psychotic symptoms
  5. Their capacity to recognize reality is normal
questions.solution:
The diagnosis, in this case, is a schizoid personality disorder, and statements 3 and 5 are congruent with the diagnosis. Cluster A includes Schizoid, Schizotypal, and Paranoid personality disorders.

A persons with schizoid personality dis­order are described by others as eccentric, isolated, or lonely. They exhibit lifelong pat­tern of social withdrawal. The onset of this disorder is in childhood or adolescence.

Persons with the disorder prefer solitary jobs so that there is little or no involvement with other people. They are cold, aloof, and show no involvement with everyday events and concerns. They appear to be indifferent to the praise or criticism of others. They pursue their own lives with little or no need for emotional connections and are often unable to directly express anger. Although they appear self-absorbed and lost in daydreams, their capac­ity to recognize reality is normal. 

Men with the disorder may not marry because of the inability to achieve intimacy, while women may passively agree to marry an aggressive man who wants the marriage. 

Differential diagnosis:

  • Schizophrenia, delusional disorder, and affective disorder are characterized by the presence of positive psychotic symptoms
  • Schizotypal personality disorder- Due to poor interpersonal relationships and inappropriate behavior, they are isolated and have very few friends. Under stress, they may decompensate and have brief psychotic symptoms. 
  • Paranoid personality disorder - More social engagement compared with a schizoid personality disorder. They also often have a history of violent verbal behavior and tend to project their feelings on to others
  • Avoidant personality disorders - They are isolated but strongly wish to participate in social activities, which is not seen schizoid personality disor­der. These people isolate themselves and avoid companionship due to their fear of rejection and criticism.

Treatment is with psychotherapy and pharmacotherapy. Small dos­es of antipsychotics, antidepressants, and psychostimulants are effective.

questions.text: You are a researcher working on developing a new mode of treatment for Covid 19. This requires culturing the SARS-CoV-2 virus. What is the minimum biosafety level (BSL) to be followed?
questions.solution:
Attempts to culture the SARS CoV 2 virus requires minimum BSL-3 facilities.

SARS CoV 2 virus is grown in cell cultures. Nasopharyngeal (NP) and oropharyngeal (OP) swab specimens are collected on day 3 post symptom onset, placed in 2–3 mL of viral transport medium, used for molecular diagnosis, and frozen. Vero CCL-81 cells are used in Dulbecco minimal essential medium (DMEM) supplemented with heat-inactivated fetal bovine serum for isolation of virus. The virus is then grown in the inoculated cultures in a humidified 37°C incubator in an atmosphere of 5% CO2 and observed for cytopathic effects (CPEs) daily.

SARS CoV 2 virus can cause coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). Microbiology and pathology laboratories performing diagnostic tests on a stool or respiratory specimen should handle potential SARS-CoV specimens using standard biosafety level (BSL) -2.

Biosafety levels include a specific combination of work practices, safety equipment, and facilities that are designed to minimize the exposure of workers and the environment to infectious agents. There are four biosafety levels

Related Pearl: Laboratory Biosafety Levels (BSL)

questions.text:
A young female patient with SLE visits the doctor for a follow-up. Her urine analysis shows the presence of proteinuria and microscopic hematuria. The patient undergoes renal biopsy, and it shows focal glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli. What is the class of lupus nephritis?

SLE - systemic lupus erythematosus
questions.solution:
Focal glomerulonephritis involving less than 50% of all glomeruli belongs to class III lupus nephritis (focal lupus nephritis).

Nephritis is a serious and life-threatening manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). In the initial stages, the patients are usually asymptomatic. Therefore, evaluating patients for renal function is important to prevent the progression of the disease. 

Symptoms of nephritis are proteinuria, hematuria, nephrotic syndrome, and hypertension. If the patient has clinical or laboratory evidence of nephritis, they have to undergo renal biopsy. Depending on the histopathological features, lupus nephritis is divided into six classes.

Class III or focal lupus nephritis shows focal, segmental, or global glomerulonephritis involving ≤ 50% of all glomeruli. Focal subendothelial deposits might also be present.

Immunofluorescence of the renal biopsy in lupus nephritis will show positive staining for all immune reactants (IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, kappa and lambda light chain). This is called a full house pattern.

Below image shows the deposition of all the immune reactants in the glomeruli:

questions.text:
A 14-year-old boy is brought to the department of paediatrics with complaints of sudden jerks in the morning causing him to drop objects. An EEG revealed a generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike and slow-wave discharges. Identify the correct statements regarding this condition.

1. It is the most common generalized epilepsy in young adults
2. CACNB4, CLNC2 and EJM2 genes are mutated
3. Onset is classically during early infancy
4. KCNQ2 and SLC2A1 genes are mutated
5. Precipitated by sleep deprivation
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy or Janz syndrome, and options 1, 2, and 5 are correct.

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy is the most common generalized epilepsy in young adults. It has been linked to mutations in the genes:

  • CACNB4
  • CLNC2
  • EJM2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9
  • GABRA1
  • GABRD
  • Myoclonin1/ EFHC1

It typically starts in early adolescence with myoclonic jerks in the morning causing the patient to drop things, generalized tonic-clonic seizures while sleeping, or on waking up, and juvenile absence seizures. Precipitating factors include sleep deprivation, photic stimulation, alcohol (in older patients), and certain cognitive activities.

The EEG in shows generalized 4-5 Hz polyspike–and–slow-wave discharges in juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.

Disease Typical EEG feature
Lennox-Gastaut syndrome 1-2 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep
Absence seizures 3 Hz spike and slow-wave (spike and dome pattern)
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy 4-5 Hz spike
West syndrome  Hypsarrhythmia (high-voltage waves with chaotic background)

Treatment of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy: The FDA-approved drugs for the treatment of Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy are lamotrigine, levetiracetam, and topiramate, while NICE guidelines recommend valproate in addition to these. 

Other options:

Option 4: Mutations in KCNQ2 are associated with benign familial neonatal seizures while mutations in SLC2A1 are linked with epileptic encephalopathies and early-onset absence seizures.

questions.text:
Which cyclin-CDK (cyclin-dependent kinase) combination is essential for the G2 to M phase transition of cell cycle?

G2 - Gap 2
M - Mitotic
questions.solution:
Cyclin B-CDK1 combination is essential for the G2 to M phase transition.

Cell cycle progression is driven by the formation of complexes of proteins called cyclins and associated enzymes known as cyclin-dependent kinases. Cyclins are synthesized only during the cell cycle to regulate the progression of the cell across the phases of the cell cycle, while cyclin-dependent kinases are constitutively present irrespective of the cell cycle.

Cyclins D, E, A, and B appear sequentially during the cell cycle and bind to one or more CDKs.

  1. G1-S transition: Cyclin D-CDK4, cyclin D-CDK6, and cyclin E-CDK2
  2. S-phase: Cyclin A-CDK1 and cyclin A-CDK2
  3. G2-M transition: Cyclin B-CDK1

CDK inhibitors (CDKIs) enforce the cell cycle checkpoints. There are several families of CDKIs:

  • CDKIs that broadly inhibit multiple CDKs: p21, p27, p57
  • CDKIs that inhibit CDK4 and CDK6: p15, p16, p18, and p19

questions.text: 35-year-old patient presented with a history of cold sores 2 days ago, now came with non-pruritic lesions on his elbow, as seen below. What type of hypersensitivity is seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing target lesion is suggestive of Erythema Multiforme, which is due to Type 4 hypersensitivity.

Erythema Multiforme is best regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from type IV hypersensitivity reaction associated with certain infections, medications, and other triggers.

Precipitating factors include HSV 1& 2 (commonly), EBV, and drugs like sulfa drugs (commonly).  This is consistent with the patient having history of cold sores.

The papules evolve into pathognomonic target or iris lesions that appear within a 72-hour period and begin on the extremities. Lesions remain in a fixed location for at least 7 days and then begin to heal.

questions.text: An AIDS patient presented with neurological symptoms like seizures, focal neurological deficits, and diplopia. There is history of headache, nausea, dizziness, irritability, and a low-grade fever for the past 3 months. Brain biopsy showed granulomatous inflammation, trophozoites, and cysts. The trophozoites were large, 20-50 μm in size, and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia. Which of the following organisms is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of granulomatous amebic encephalitis. It is caused by acanthamoeba.

Granulomatous amebic encephalitis: It is a granulomatous infection of the brain and spinal cord that typically occurs in persons with a compromised immune system. 

  • Granulomatous amebic encephalitis is believed to follow the inhalation of the dried cysts. The incubation period is long and the evolution of the illness is slow. 
  • The clinical picture is that of intracranial space-occupying lesions with seizures, pareses and mental deterioration.
  • Diagnosis of GAE is made by demonstration of trophozoites (The trophozoites are large, 20-50 μm in size, and characterized
    by spine-like pseudopodia)     and cysts in brain biopsy, culture and immunofluorescence microscopy using monoclonal antibodies.

Other options:

Naegleria fowleri a pathogenic free-living amoeba which causes the disease primary amoebic meningoencephalitis(PAM)

Naegleria fowleri:

  • Patients are mostly previously healthy young adults or children, the infection comes from water containing free-living amoeba and usually follows swimming or diving in ponds.
  • The amoeba invades the nasal mucosa and passes through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges and brain to initiate acute purulent meningitis and encephalitis (PAM).
  • The incubation period varies from 2 days to 2 weeks.
  • In the incubation period, the patient experiences anosmia, the disease advances rapidly, causing fever, headache, vomiting, stiff neck, ataxia, seizure and coma and ends fatally within a Week. (average 5 days). 

Toxoplasma: Trophozoites are crescent-shaped and are 3-7 μm in size.

Plasmodium falciparum: Runs more acute course. In peripheral blood smear, ring forms and gametocytes are seen.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the hospital after he collapsed on the dance floor. The findings of a 12-lead ECG taken at the emergency room are shown in the image below. Which of the following drugs could have precipitated the associated condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the ECG findings are suggestive of torsades de pointes. Among the given options, cisapride is most likely to have precipitated this condition.

Cisapride is a prokinetic agent. Its prokinetic action is exerted mainly through 5-HT4 agonism aided by weak 5-HT3 antagonism.

At high concentrations, cisapride blocks delayed rectifying K+ channels in the heart which prolongs Q-Tc interval and predisposes to torsades de pointes/ ventricular fibrillation.

The illustration given below shows the ECG findings of torsades de pointes.

Other options:

Option A: Domperidone can cause galactorrhea, gynecomastia, amenorrhea, or impotence.

Option B: Metoclopramide can cause dystonias, parkinsonian-like symptoms, and tardive dyskinesia. Extrapyramidal effects occur more commonly in children.

Option D: Adverse effects of omeprazole include headache, nausea, diarrhea, and accelerated osteoporosis in the elderly.

questions.text: A term newborn does not cry at birth, despite stimulation. The heart rate doesn't improve even after 30 seconds of the bag and mask ventilation. Ventilation is continued and chest compressions are initiated at the lower third of the sternum. The compressions should be at the rate of
questions.solution:
The chest compressions should be at the rate of 90 compressions/min during neonatal resuscitation.
 
The response to neonatal resuscitation at various steps is assessed based on the heart rate.
  • If the heart rate is less than 100, PPV (positive pressure ventilation) is provided with bag and mask and SPO2 monitoring is done and adequate ventilation is ensured.
  • If the heart rate is below 60, then chest compressions are initiated over the lower third of the sternum at a rate of 90 compressions/min.
  • Recommended rate of ventilation is 30 inflations/min. (90 compressions + 30 inflation = 120 events/ min). The ratio of compressions to ventilation is 3: 1.
  • If the heart rate still remains <60, despite effective compressions and ventilation, then IV epinephrine is given.

 

Kindly note: Neonatal resuscitation is primarily to support a newborn during the transition from intrauterine to extrauterine life. AHA guidelines recommend 90 compressions/ min for neonatal resuscitation. Whereas, pediatric CPR is for cardiac arrest in infants and children. AHA guidelines recommend 100-120 compressions/ min for pediatric CPR.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given dose-response curve:

choices.text: Drug B is the most potent
Drug B is the most efficacious
Drug C is more efficacious than drug D
Drug B is more efficacious than drug A

questions.solution:
The more the curve is to the left, the more its potency. Hence drug B is the most potent on the given dose-response curve (DRC).

Potency

  • It is defined as the amount of drug needed to produce a given response. 
  • A highly potent drug evokes a given response at low concentrations and vice-versa.
  • The more the curve is on the left in a log dose-response curve (DRC), the greater its potency.

Hence in the given DRC drug B is the most potent and drug D is the least potent.

Efficacy

  • It is defined as the maximum effect produced by the drug.
  • It reflects the capacity of the drug to activate a receptor and produce the response.
  • In the log dose-response curve, the perpendicular height represents the drug efficacy.

Hence in the given DRC, drug B has the least efficacy (Option B and D), and drugs A, C & D are equally efficacious. (Option C)

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a road traffic accident. Evaluation reveals hypotension, tachycardia and decreased pulse pressure. The FAST scan reveals massive intraabdominal bleeding. He receives 5 units of packed red blood cell transfusion in the next hour. Which of the following complications is least expected to be seen in this patient?
  1. Hypokalemia
  2. Hyperkalemia
  3. Hypocalcemia
  4. Hypercalcemia
  5. Hyperthermia
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describing a patient of RTA with hypotension and decreased pulse pressure is suggestive of haemorrhagic shock. The patient is probably seeping into hypovolemic shock. The patient who received 5 units of packed red blood cell transfusion(pRBCs) in 1-hour also indicates massive blood transfusion. Hyperthermia and Hypercalcemia are least likely seen after massive blood transfusion. 

Hypocalcemia is a known complication of massive blood transfusion and not hypercalcemia. This is due to the citrate toxicity of transfusing stored blood. Hypothermia is due to the opening up of coelomic cavities and infusion of cold blood (refrigerated). 

The classification of haemorrhagic shock, the compensatory mechanisms seen in shock and the expected electrolyte abnormalities in a massive blood transfusion are all enlisted in the pearls attached below. 

Related Pearl: Complications of a Massive Transfusion

Massive transfusion (MT) is defined as the replacement by transfusion of 10 units of pRBCs in 24 hours or more than 4 units of pRBCs in one hour.

Complications from massive transfusion include:

Coagulopathy

MT with PRBCs alone causes a dilutional coagulopathy (vs consumptive coagulopathy caused by massive hemorrhage)

Initially - Hyperkalemia, as stored blood has high K+ levels due to inactivated Na/K/ATPase pump

Later - Hypokalemia, due to intracellular potassium uptake and metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: An hour after the blood transfusion, the patient develops a fever with chills and flank pain. Tachycardia and hypotension are noted on examination. The direct Coombs test is positive. Which of the following mediates this reaction?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) following blood transfusion. It occurs most often due to ABO incompatibility and is mediated by IgM antibodies.
 
Acute hemolytic transfusion reaction (AHTR) occurs within 24 hours of transfusion and is usually caused by preformed IgM antibodies against donor red cells that fix complement. The patient presents with tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, fever, flank pain, and in severe cases, hemoglobinuria, renal failure, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC).
 
It is caused by ABO incompatibility which is a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction. They test positive for the direct Coomb's test. In light of acute hemolytic transfusion reaction, the transfusion is to be stopped immediately.

Allergic or urticarial reactions during transfusions are mediated by IgE antibodies.

A delayed hemolytic transfusion reaction which occurs after 24 hours (within 2 weeks) of transfusion is a reaction mediated by IgG antibodies.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method of direct transmission of communicable diseases?
questions.solution:
Airborne transmission by droplet nuclei is not a method of direct transmission of diseases.

It is a method of indirect transmission of diseases.

Droplet nuclei are tiny particles of size 1-5 microns range that may be formed by either due to evaporation of droplets coughed or sneezed into the air or are formed from aerosols.

These droplet nuclei remain airborne for long periods of time and can transmit diseases like tuberculosis, influenza, chickenpox, measles, Q fever and other respiratory infections.

Droplet transmission, vertical transmission, and contact with soil are methods of direct transmission of diseases.

Differences between droplet and droplet nuclei are summarised below:

DROPLET NUCLEI  DROPLET 
Indirect transmission Direct transmission
It is the residue from evaporated droplets It is produced while coughing, sneezing, talking
<5microns in diameter ≥5 microns in diameter
No need for close contact for transmission Requires closeness and direct contact for transmission
Diseases transmitted: chickenpox, measles etc. Diseases transmitted: diphtheria, meningococcal meningitis etc.

questions.text: A 23-year-old student attempted suicide by hanging. He was taken to the hospital but declared as brought dead. His non-circulating heart was planned for transplant to a recipient. Which category of non-beating heart donors would this patient fall into as per the modified Maastricht classification?
questions.solution:
The patient would fall under category-I as per the modified Maastricht classification.

Modified Maastricht classification includes 5 categories of non-heart-beating donors in which categories I, II and V are uncontrolled while III, IV are controlled.  A non-heart-beating organ donation is when the organs are taken from a donor who was declared dead because of cessation of cardiac activity.

The categories of non-heart-beating donors are:

Uncontrolled- transplant team not present or prepared 

  • Category I- includes victims found dead at the scene of accidents and suicide. It includes the scenario where resuscitation when done is pointless (e.g. fatal cervical spine fracture).
  • Category II- donors are mostly victims of sudden cardiac or cerebral catastrophe. They are resuscitated in the ambulance and brought to emergency departments or they might have died in the department. Isolated brain injury, anoxia,  stroke, and victims of major trauma who died soon after hospital admission also fall under this category. 
  • Category V- Unexpected cardiac arrest during intensive care - Uncontrolled

Controlled- transplant team present and prepared 

  • Category III- encompasses dying patients in an intensive care unit. These are the patients prone to cardiac arrest and the treatment has been decided to stop by the clinicians and not commence resuscitation for various reasons.
  • Category IV- includes patients who suffer unexpected cardiac arrest during or after the estimation of brain death.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a hard and irregular lump in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. Histopathological appearance of the specimen is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows discohesive infiltrating tumor cells, signet-ring cells containing intracytoplasmic mucin droplets, and the Indian file appearance which is suggestive of lobular carcinoma of the breast.

Lobular Carcinoma is usually bilateral, multicentric, and presents as hard irregular masses. It can have a diffuse infiltrative pattern with minimal desmoplasia. It is the most common type of breast carcinoma to present as an occult primary.

It is associated with a mutation in the CDH-1 gene which encodes for cadherin. Loss of E-cadherin leads to small, monomorphic discohesive cells arranged one after another. This arrangement is called an Indian file/ Single file appearance. Desmoplasia is minimal or absent in this type.

They are Luminal-A type and have an excellent prognosis.


Note: Mutation in CDH-1 also poses a high risk for gastric signet ring cell carcinoma.

Other options:

Option B: Papillary carcinoma consists of true papillae with a leaf-like arrangement of fibrovascular tissue, lined by the tumor cells.

The image below shows histopathology findings of papillary carcinoma of the breast:


Option C: Medullary carcinoma of the breast shows sheets of highly pleomorphic cells with mitotic figures, lymphoplasmacytic infiltrates, and pushing border.

The image below shows histopathology findings of medullary carcinoma of the breast:


Option D: Colloidal carcinoma is an invasive breast carcinoma, which shows intra and extracellular mucin deposition. Extracellular type shows tumor cells with faint nuclei arranged in clusters floating in pools/lakes of mucin on histopathological examination. In the intracellular type, nuclei are pushed to the peripherally to form a signet ring appearance.

The image below shows histopathology findings of colloidal carcinoma of the breast:

questions.text: A 2-year-old baby weighing 15 kg was brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. He is afebrile, and there is no blood in his stools. The baby is lethargic. On examination, the eyes are sunken and during the skin pinch test, the skin retraction took more than two seconds. On offering water the child does not show eagerness to drink and responds poorly. Which of the following is correct concerning the treatment of dehydration in this child?

choices.text: 600 ml to be given as IV in the first 1 hour
600 ml to be given as IV in the first  half hour
450 ml to be given as IV in the first half hour
450 ml to be given as IV in the first 1 hour

questions.solution:
The child in this scenario has severe dehydration, as indicated by lethargy, and sunken eyes, and the skin goes back slowly on the skin pinch test (>2 seconds). 450 ml to be given as IV in the first half hour is correct for the treatment of dehydration in this child.

Severe dehydration requires treatment plan C. This involves using intravenous fluids (ringer lactate with 5% dextrose).

100ml/kg of fluid should be given over 3 hours in children aged more than 12 months. For those who are less than 12 months old, the fluid should be given over 6 hours.

The fluid requirement for severe dehydration is as follows:

Age 30 mL/kg 70 mL/kg
<12 months 1 hr 5 hr
>12 months 30 min 2.5 hr

Calculation of fluid required: The baby requires 30 mL/kg fluid and the weight of the baby is 15 kg. 

Therefore, the total fluid requirement is: 

15 kg x 30 mL/kg = 450 ml fluids in the first half-hour, and

15 kg x 70 mL/kg = 1050 ml over the next 2.5 hours.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 18 weeks of gestation with bleeding per vagina had a miscarriage. The products of conception are sent for appropriate tests. Which of the following is not a disposal option for the same?
questions.solution:
Encapsulation is not a disposal option for human anatomical waste. It is a disposal technique used for expired and discarded medicines along with chemical wastes. 

Human anatomical waste such as an aborted fetus is put in a yellow bag and is disposed of by either incineration, plasma pyrolysis, or deep burial. 

The biomedical waste management rule is applicable to all those who collect, receive, store, dispose and treat biomedical waste. The wastes are categorised and segregated at the point of generation of waste. A color coding system with 4 colors namely yellow, red, white, and blue is used for waste segregation. 

The segregated waste is then disposed of by various methods. They are:

  • Incineration - this is a dry oxidation process done using high temperatures. The types are rotary kiln, pyrolytic incinerator, and single chamber incinerator.  
  • Chemical disinfection - chemicals are added to waste to kill or inactivate the microorganisms. Mostly used for treating liquid wastes. 
  • Wet and dry thermal treatment - shredded infectious waste is exposed to high temperature, high-pressure steam and it resembles an autoclave sterilization process. 
  • Microwave irradiation - microorganisms are killed using high-frequency microwaves. Its efficiency should be checked routinely. 
  • Land disposal - either municipal disposal sites or sanitary landfills are used. 
  • Inertization - waste is mixed with cement and other substances before disposal to reduce toxicity. 

Disposal by deep burial is permitted only in rural areas which lack common bio-medical treatment facilities. Permission from the concerned authority is needed and guidelines issued by the central pollution control board should be followed.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male sustained a knee injury while playing football. On examination, the test shown below was positive, and the affected knee is found to be locked in partial flexion. MRI revealed that the tear is in the red zone. How should this case be managed?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem with a positive Thessaly test (shown in image) and locking is suggestive of a tear in the red zone of the medial meniscus, which should be treated with arthroscopic suture repair. In the Thessaly test, the affected knee is flexed to 20 degrees with the foot placed flat on the ground, while being supported by the examiner. The patient is asked to twist their body from one side to the other three times, exerting a rotational force in the knee. In a positive test, there is joint line pain and locking.

Meniscal injuries are usually caused by a rotational and shearing force, occurring when the knee is flexed and twisted while taking weight. The medial meniscus is more commonly affected than the lateral meniscus because it is attached more firmly to the capsule and is less mobile.

Young patients present with severe pain, swelling, and locking of the knee(inability to fully extend the knee). Older patients may be asymptomatic during the injury but later complain of the knee giving way. 

On examination, the joint may be held in slight flexion. Tenderness is most commonly present along the medial side of the joint line. Passive flexion is possible fully, but extension is often limited. Tests for meniscal injuries include:

  • McMurray’s test
  • Apley’s grinding test
  • Thessaly test 

MRI is diagnostic. Plain radiographs may appear normal.

Treatment:

  • Conservative treatment: Arthroscopic suturing and repair are indicated in a young patient with a peripheral tear in the red zone (vascularised zone)
  • Operative treatment: Tears other than those in the peripheral third are dealt with by excising the torn portion (partial meniscectomy)
    Indications:
    • If the joint cannot be unlocked
    • If mechanical symptoms like locking or catching are recurrent
    • Failure of non-operative treatment 

Total meniscectomy causes more instability, may lead to secondary osteoarthritis, and has no obvious advantage over partial.

questions.text: A 55-year-old post-menopausal woman with a family history of breast cancer presents with persistent lower backache. Her bone mineral density is measured, and the T-score is -2.6. She is prescribed raloxifene. Which of the following effects of this drug should the patient be informed about?
questions.solution:
This post-menopausal patient with a family history of breast cancer, with osteoporosis (low back pain, a T-score of -2.6), has been recommended to take raloxifene. Raloxifene causes a 3-fold increase in deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

It is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) with the following actions-

Agonist actions:

  • Bone: Increases bone mineral density and reduces the risk of vertebral fractures
  • Lipids: Reduces total cholesterol and low-density lipoprotein. However, it does not increase HDL cholesterol.
  • Increases the risk of deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism. 

Antagonist action:

  • Breast: Incidence of breast carcinoma is reduced (option D). Raloxifene has an antiproliferative effect on ER-positive breast tumors and significantly reduces the risk of ER-positive but not ER-negative breast cancer.
  • Uterus: does not stimulate endometrial proliferation (option B)

Note: Raloxifene does not help with vasomotor symptoms, and some people might experience hot flashes (option A).

SERM Effect on breast  Effect on endometrium Effect on bone
Tamoxifen Inhibits proliferation Stimulates proliferation Antiresorptive
Raloxifene Inhibits proliferation Inhibits proliferation Antiresorptive

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: A 40-year-old obese female presents to the ER with a history of RTA. On examination, GCS is 15/15, Heart rate = 110/min, BP = 90/60 mmHg, respiratory rate of 44, and there is elevated JVP. The patient winces on chest examination. The right chest is tympanic on percussion with decreased breath sounds. The left chest appears normal. But the patient is dyspneic and ecchymosis is noted over the chest wall. The abdomen was soft. The surgeon performed immediate needle thoracotomy and subjected the patient to a CT scan whose results are attached below. Despite the needle thoracostomy, the vitals did not improve. What should be the surgeon's next best step?

choices.text: Post the patient for video-assisted thoracoscopy surgery
Perform a finger thoracostomy followed by tube thoracostomy
Tracheostomy to secure airway followed by thoracostomy
Perform an eFAST to confirm the diagnosis

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The next best step after a failed needle thoracostomy in this patient would be to perform a finger thoracostomy followed by tube thoracostomy.

The CT scan shows right pneumothorax and collapsed lung. Lung anatomy is not clearly seen and is masked by dark zones.

According to ATLS, due to the variable thickness of the chest wall (here the patient is obese), kinking of the catheter, and other technical or anatomic complications, needle decompression may not be successful always. In this case, finger thoracostomy is an alternative approach and recommended as the next best step. Tube thoracostomy is mandatory after needle or finger decompression of the chest. 

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation.

Advantages over needle thoracostomy:

- Unlimited by needle length

- Observable signs confirming pleural access

  • Puncture sensation of parietal pleura with Kelly/finger
  • Palpation of parietal pleura with finger
  • Palpation of lung parenchyma with finger

- If no pneumothorax, will not puncture lung parenchyma to create a new pneumothorax

- Theoretically does not require placement of chest tube if no initial pneumothorax

- No chance of catheter "kinking"

Advantages over tube thoracostomy:

- Simpler: quicker, easier, less equipment

- no foreign body, decreased infection

 

Tension pneumothorax is characterized by chest pain, tachypnoea, tachycardia, hypotension, tracheal deviation away from the side of injury, unilateral absence of breath sound, cyanosis, and neck vein distention.

Tension pneumothorax and simple pneumothorax have similar signs, symptoms, and examination findings, but hypotension qualifies pneumothorax as a tension pneumothorax.

A tension pneumothorax develops when a "one-way valve" air leak occurs either from the lung or through the chest wall. Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any means of escape, completely collapsing then compressing the affected lung.

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation.

Treatment consists of immediate decompression, initially by rapid insertion of a large-bore cannula on the affected side for rapid decompression, followed by insertion of a chest tube for definitive management.

The RECENT UPDATE (Acc. to ATLS 10th edition):

  • In Adults, needle thoracotomy location changed to 5th ICS mid axillary line from 2nd ICS midclavicular line.
  • In the Paediatric age group, thoracotomy location remains at 2nd ICS midclavicular line

Note: Numerous studies suggest that needle thoracostomy inconsistently accesses the pleural space. This procedure is an alternative that provides feedback that the pleural space has been accessed.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old male patient presents to the hospital with a history of epigastric pain, weight loss, diarrhoea, and edema of feet. Diarrhoea is present for the past 5 months. On examination, he was found to have hypoproteinemia. The surgeon performed an endoscopy, and it showed the following finding. There was no presence of ulcers. A small piece of tissue was taken and was sent for histopathology. It showed the presence of foveolar hyperplasia and a marked reduction in oxyntic glands and parietal cells and chief cells. Which among the following statements is/are incorrect regarding this condition?
  1. Occurs due to over-expression of transforming growth factor α
  2. It is associated with cytomegalovirus infection in children
  3. The antrum is the most common site of involvement
  4. Cetuximab is used in the treatment
  5. Massive upper gastrointestinal bleed is very common
questions.solution:
The image shows the presence of hypertrophied gastric mucosal folds which are characteristic of Menetrier’s disease. Statements 3 and 5 are incorrect regarding this condition.

It is a gastropathy characterized by large tortuous mucosal folds. It is common in men and the age of onset is usually between 40-60 years. In children, it is usually associated with cytomegalovirus infection and in adults the aetiology is unknown.

This disease is caused due to the overexpression of TGF- alpha, which in turn stimulates epidermal growth factor receptor. This increases the growth of mucous cells. The increased number of mucous cells leads to giant rugal folds. There is excessive production of mucous in the stomach which results in increased loss of proteins, and decreased number of oxyntic glands leads to hypochlorhydria. The folds are prominent in the body and fundus and usually spares the antrum.

These patients usually present with epigastric pain, nausea, diarrhoea, vomiting, anorexia, peripheral edema, and weight loss. Occult gastrointestinal bleeding may occur, but overt bleeding is unusual and is usually due to superficial mucosal erosions.

Histologically, massive foveolar hyperplasia (hyperplasia of surface and glandular mucous cells) and a marked reduction in oxyntic glands and parietal cells and chief cells are seen.

Some patients may respond to cetuximab (a monoclonal antibody against EGFR). Severe cases require a gastrectomy.

Below image shows slide of Menetrier's disease with hyperplasia of the mucous cells.

questions.text: You are performing a cardiotocograph on a woman in labor, and your findings are shown below. What could be the possible cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
The given cardiotocograph shows decelerations that are variable with respect to the size, shape, depth, duration, and timing of uterine contractions. This is indicative of variable decelerations, and the likely cause among the given options is umbilical cord compression.

Baseline variability is observed in many conditions such as:

1. Acceleration: Transient increase in fetal heart rate (FHR) by 15 bpm or more, lasting for at least 15 seconds. It denotes intact neurohormonal and cardiovascular activity and, therefore, a healthy fetus.

2. Deceleration: Transient decrease in FHR below the baseline by 15 bpm or more and lasting ≥15 seconds. Three basic types of deceleration are early, late, and variable:

  • Early deceleration/ Type I Dips: Slowing of FHR and in most cases, the phases of the deceleration (onset, nadir, and recovery) coincide with those of the uterine contraction (beginning, peak, and ending). It is due to head compression (vagal nerve activation).

 

  • Late deceleration/ Type II Dips: that begins after the onset of the uterine contraction. Usually, the onset, nadir and recovery of the deceleration occur after the start, peak and end of the uterine contraction respectively. It suggests uteroplacental insufficiency and fetal hypoxia (50%). Causes of late deceleration: (i) Placental pathology (postmaturity, hypertension, diabetes, placental abruption); (ii) Excessive uterine contractions; (iii) Injudicious use of oxytocin; (iv) Regional anaesthesia (spinal or epidural)

 

  • Variable deceleration: The most common type of deceleration. Here the decelerations are variable, with varying parameters of size, shape, depth, duration, and timing with respect to uterine contractions. They indicate cord compression and may disappear when the patient's position is altered. Accelerations often precede and follow this type of deceleration.

 

3. Prolonged deceleration is the abrupt decrease in FHR to levels below the baseline, and it lasts for >3 min but <10 min. If it lasts for >10 min, it is a baseline change.

4. Lag period: It is the time taken for the FHR to reach the nadir (the lowest point of the FHR dip) from the apex of the preceding uterine contraction. In deceleration, the lag period is >30 seconds.

5. Sinusoidal pattern: It resembles a sine wave. It has a stable baseline FHR with fixed or absent baseline variability lasting >20 min. Accelerations are absent. It is often associated with fetal anaemia and fetomaternal haemorrhage. It may occur when narcotics are given to the mother. Such FHR patterns are called pseudo-sinusoidal as the fetus is well-oxygenated.

Related Pearl: Partograph

Partograph types:

WHO Modified Partograph (2000)

  • No latent phase
  • Vaginal examination: This should be done no less than every 4 hours to assess cervical dilatation, descent of the fetal head, and moulding of skull bones. More frequent examination is only undertaken if indicated.
  • Charting starts at 4 cm of cervical dilation.
  • Colour of liquor mentioned as C-clear, B-blood stained, M-meconium stained.
  • Moulding mentioned:
    • bones are separated and sutures can be easily felt - (0)
    • bones touching (1+)
    • bones overlapping but can be reduced(2+)
    • bones severely overlapping and irreducible ( 3+).
  • Alert line reflects the average rate of cervical dilation of the slowest quintile of term primigravidas, if dilation slows or ceases, the partograph plot will cross the alert line.
  • Alert line: at 4 cm dilation and expected dilation of 1 cm/hour.
  • Action line is 2–4 hours after the alert line, which prompts interventions to accelerate labor or perform cesarean delivery.
  • Higher rates of perinatal mortality are associated with delays of 4 hours or more after the alert line.
  • Contractions measured for a span of 10 min (duration noted) and measured every 30 min (1 square = half hour).
  • Pulse: record every 30 minutes and mark with a dot (•).
  • Blood pressure: record every 4 hours and mark with arrows, unless the patient has a hypertensive disorder or pre-eclampsia, in which case record every 30 minutes.
  • Temperature: record every 4 hours.

WHO Composite Partograph: It is same as modified except for it has latent phase and charting done at 3 cm.

WHO Simplified Partograph: WHO further modified the partograph for use by skilled attendants in health centers. This simplified partograph is colour coded.

  • The area to the left of the alert line in the cervicograph is coloured green, representing normal progress.
  • The area to the right of the action line is coloured red, indicating dangerously slow progress in labour.
  • The area in between the alert and action line is coloured amber, indicating the need for greater vigilance.

questions.text: Identify the instrument in the given image that is used in spinal fusion surgery.
questions.solution:
The instrument in the given image, used in spinal fusion surgery is a polyaxial pedicle screw. 

Pedicle screws are used in a spinal fusion to add extra support and strength to the fusion while it heals. They are placed above and below the vertebrae that were fused. Rods are used to connect the screws which prevent the movement and allows the bone to heal. The Xray below shows a pedicle screw 

Other options: 

Option A- Herbert screw is a headless screw often used for the fixation of unstable scaphoid fractures. It is cannulated and threaded at both ends.  The proximal portion has a wider pitch to its thread. This screw is used where a standard screw would impinge on adjacent tissues. It is designed to fix fractures of small articular bones such as the carpals and the scaphoid.

Option B: The Kuntscher's cloverleaf intra-medullary nail (K-nail) is used for internal fixation of femoral fractures. The eye at the end of the nail is useful during its removal and the cloverleaf shape on the cross-section provides good rotational stability.

Option D: Acutrax screw is used for the treatment of most scaphoid fractures.  It is a cannulated, headless, and fully threaded screw.

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with fever, abdominal discomfort, cough, and difficulty in breathing for the past 3 weeks. He has a history of pica and contact with pet dogs. Laboratory investigations show leucocytosis and high eosinophilia. The eggs of the implicated organism are shown in the given image. The most likely causative parasite is______
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and the eggs of Toxocara are suggestive of visceral larva migrans, most commonly caused by Toxocara canis.

Toxocara eggs appear murky as the surface contour is pitted due to the mammilation of the protein layer of the shell.

Larva migrans is generally seen when human infection occurs with nonhuman species of nematodes. It can be classified into cutaneous or visceral types, depending on whether the larval migration takes place in the skin or deeper tissues.

Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of nematode larvae that infect by the oral route whereas cutaneous larva migrans is caused by the migration of larvae that infect by skin penetration. The most common cause is the dog ascarid Toxocara canis and, less often the cat ascarid T.cati.

Children are more likely to swallow dirt (pica) so this condition is more common in them. The infective eggs present in the soil are ingested, and the larvae hatch in the small intestine, penetrate the gut wall and migrate to the liver. From the liver, they may migrate to other organs such as the lungs, brain, or eyes. They do not develop into adults, but induce granulomatous inflammation and cause local damage.

Clinical manifestations like fever, hepatomegaly, pneumonitis, and hyperglobulinaemia are seen. A history of pica can be present. Patients can develop neurological disturbances (Neural larva migrans) or endophthalmitis (Ophthalmic larva migrans). CBC shows leucocytosis and high eosinophilia.

Serological tests like ELISA have been useful in diagnosis. Thiabendazole can be used for treatment. Deworming of household pets also helps in prevention.

questions.text: A family of four from London developed recurrent episodes of watery diarrhea and abdominal pain after their trip to Bali. Stool culture on MacConkey medium is given below. Biochemical tests done show IMViC ++-- and negative Eiken's test. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin secreted by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette along with lactose fermenting MacConkey agar (bright pink), IMViC : ++--, and negative Eiken's test is suggestive of Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)/traveler's diarrhea caused by the E. coli heat-stable enterotoxin which acts by activation of cGMP in the intestine.

Persons from developed countries visiting endemic areas often suffer from ETEC diarrhea, a condition known as Traveler's diarrhea. Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli is the most common cause of Traveler’s Diarrhoea. It can range from mild watery diarrhea to fatal disease, similar to cholera.

The first step in pathogenesis is adherence to the intestinal mucosa by fimbria called colonization factor antigens. ETEC then produces enterotoxins which may be either heat-labile (LT) or heat-stable (ST).

This is distinguished by several tests, one of the serological tests being Precipitin test (Eikien's) which is positive in LT and negative in ST. IMViC test includes indole, methyl red (MR), Voges-Proskauer (VP) and citrate utilisation. E.coli is indole positive and MR positive, and VP negative and citrate negative.

Two types of heat-stable enterotoxins are known :

  1. STa/ST I
  2. STb/ST II

STa acts by activation of the cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) in the intestine. This is rapid and accumulates fluid in the intestine in the infant mice (infant mouse test) which is the standard method for the demonstration of STa.

The mode of action of STb is unknown but it is neither through cAMP or cGMP.

ETEC with heat-labile enterotoxins act by activation of cAMP.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text:
You are a second-year postgraduate in the department of ophthalmology working on various bioengineering approaches on conservative therapies and donor tissue transplantation approaches for corneal regenerative medicine. Which of the following constitute the limbal stem cell markers?
  1. ABCG2 transporter
  2. α enolase
  3. Na+-K+ ATPase
  4. p63
  5. Vimentin
questions.solution:
All of the options mentioned are limbal stem cell markers.

The major markers proposed for epithelial stem cells can be categorized into at least three groups:

  • Nuclear proteins such as transcription factor p63
  • Cell membrane or transmembrane proteins
    • Integrins (integrin ß1, α6, and α9),
    • Receptors (epidermal growth factor [EGF] receptor and transferrin receptor CD71)
    • Na+ K+ ATPase
    • Drug-resistance transporters (ABCG2—a universal stem cell marker)
  • Cytoplasmic proteins such as
    • Cytokeratins (cytokeratin 19)
    • Alpha-enolase
    • Vimentin

Note:

The most important of these include:

ABCG2:

  • ATP binding cassette subfamily G - member 2 also known as BRCP1 - Breast cancer resistance protein 1 is a defined marker for hematopoietic stem cells. It is also used to culture limbal stem cells in-vitro.

p63:

  • Belongs to the p53 tumour suppressor gene family.
  • It functions as a transcription factor between epithelial cells.
  • p63 is accepted as a universal limbal epithelial stem cell (LEKH) marker, especially ΔNp63α isoform.

Corneal preservation – They can be transplanted immediately or preserved in an eye bank by various preservation techniques for varying intervals.

  • Short-term preservation
    • In a moist chamber or McCarey–Kaufman medium (MK medium)
    • Refrigerated at 2-8 °C
    • Cornea to be used within 48 to 72 hours (maximum 96 hours)
  • Intermediate– term preservation
    • In medium containing chondroitin sulfate
    • Refrigerated at 2-8 °C for 7 to 14 days
    • Or maintained at 37°C by organ culture methods
    • Using modified Eagle's medium extends this to 30 days
  • Long-term preservation
    • By cryopreservation in liquid nitrogen or in glycerol
    • Is up to 1 year
    • Loss of transparency of the tissue is a disadvantage.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who worked as a miner for the past 25 years, comes to the OPD with complaints of dyspnoea and cough. Routine blood work-up, pulmonary function tests, and a lung biopsy is taken to confirm the diagnosis. The histopathological examination of the sample is shown below. Which type of emphysema can this condition give rise to?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and microscopic image show abundant black pigment within the macrophages of lung parenchyma, which is characteristic of pulmonary anthracosis/coal worker's pneumoconiosis and may give rise to centrilobular emphysema.

The black color is due to the deposition of carbon particles. The inhaled carbon particles are engulfed by the lung macrophages and then accumulate in the connective tissue along the lymphatics or in lymphoid tissue along the bronchi or the hilum, blackening the tissues. Aggregates of carbon dust present as coal macules or nodules, which consist of carbon-laden macrophages.

It is commonly seen in people who work in environments with high air pollution and carbon particles, such as coal mines. Coal worker's pneumoconiosis is usually benign, and less than 10% of cases develop progressive massive fibrosis, which may lead to pulmonary dysfunction, pulmonary hypertension, and cor pulmonale.

Coal workers may also develop emphysema or chronic bronchitis, independent of smoking. Unlike asbestosis, this condition does not predispose to cancer.

Other options:

Option A: Panacinar emphysema is caused by alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency. It affects the entire acinus and primarily involves the lower lobes. It is not related to occupational exposures like mining but rather a genetic enzyme deficiency that leads to lung damage, making it an unlikely cause in this patient.

Option C: Paraseptal emphysema involves distal acinar destruction, often affecting subpleural areas. It is associated with spontaneous pneumothorax in young adults. Since this condition is not linked to prolonged dust exposure or mining, it is not the correct answer for this case.

Option D: Irregular emphysema occurs secondary to lung scarring, often due to previous infections or fibrosis rather than occupational lung diseases.

questions.text: A construction worker is brought to the casualty following a crush injury to his right lower limb. Which of the following scores can be used to decide between amputation and limb-salvage surgery?
questions.solution:
Mangled Extremity Severity Score (MESS) score can be used to decide between amputation and limb salvage in crushing injuries.

Components of MESS are:

  • Shock
  • Ischemia
  • Velocity
  • Age

Total score is 11. Six or less is consistent with a salvageable limb.

Other scores to assess if the limb is salvageable or not are:

  • Limb salvage index
  • Ganga score

Option A: Gustilo Anderson Classification is used to classify open fractures. 

Option B: Revised Trauma Score (RTS) characterizes the injured patient’s condition by incorporating the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS), systolic blood pressure, and respiratory rate. 

Option D: Trauma Injury Severity Score (TRISS) comprises Injury Severity Score (ISS), Revised Trauma Score (RTS), age of the patient and mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating).

questions.text: The most common renal lesion in hepatitis C infection is
questions.solution:
The most common renal lesion in hepatitis C infection is cryoglobulinemic glomerulonephritis, followed by membranous glomerulonephritis, and type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

Cryoglobulins are the immunoglobulins that precipitate when the temperature is less than 37°C. Cryoglobulinemia means the presence of cryoglobulins in the serum. Deposition of these immune complexes leads to cutaneous vasculitis, arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis. 

Causes of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis:

  • Idiopathic
  • Hepatitis C
  • Multiple myeloma
  • Connective tissue disorders
  • Liver diseases

The presence of cryoprecipitate containing oligoclonal/polyclonal immunoglobulins in the absence of underlying disease was called essential mixed cryoglobulinemia. The majority of these cases have an underlying hepatitis C infection.

Laboratory investigations will show the presence of circulating cryoprecipitates, positive for rheumatoid factor, and hypocomplementemia. They have to be tested for hepatitis C antibodies and hepatitis C RNA.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the medical intensive care unit.  There is a patient admitted there with heart failure. He has low cardiac output with oliguria. Which of the following inotropes would be preferred in the given scenario?
questions.solution:
Dopamine is used in the treatment of severe congestive heart failure, particularly in patients with oliguria as it improves renal function.

It is administered at 2–5 mcg/kg/min intravenously. Stimulation of dopaminergic and β-adrenergic receptors produces increased glomerular filtration, heart rate, and contractility.

Other options:

Option A: Epinephrine (adrenaline) is a potent stimulant of both α- and β-adrenergic receptors. It increases cardiac contractility but decreases renal perfusion. It is mainly used in anaphylactic shock.

Option B: Norepinephrine is a potent α and β1 agonist, with very little effect on the β2 receptor. It can be used to raise blood pressure in intensive care conditions, but since it decreases the renal blood flow, it is not preferred in the above clinical scenario.

Option D: Fenoldopam is an agonist for peripheral D1 receptors and is used to control hypertension.

questions.text: A young man comes to the urology department with a chronic history of deformity of the penis, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection.  On examination, there were palpable penile plaques and penile ultrasound showed a thickened area of tissue around tunica albuginea. He has been using the device shown below but is now seeking a permanent solution. What surgical procedure you would recommend for him?
questions.solution:
In this case, the patient is suffering from Peyronie’s disease. The image shows the traction device/ extender used to treat excessive penile curvature. The most common surgical procedure used in Peyronie’s disease is the Nesbit's procedure.

Peyronie's disease is characterized by penile deformity, palpable penile plaques, erectile dysfunction, and pain on erection. It causes the penis to bend, usually towards the side of the plaque. It can be associated with Dupuytren's contracture as a part of the Galezia triad (Dupuytren's contracture, retroperitoneal fibrosis, peyronie's disease).

Some cases may resolve spontaneously. If not, conservative measures such as oral tamoxifen, vitamin E, terfenadine, intralesional verapamil, etc. can be tried. Intralesional collagenase has also been used. Penile extenders/ traction devices such as that shown in the above image have also been used. However, if none of these methods are effective, surgical management can be tried using Nesbit's procedure.

Nesbit's procedure is indicated when all other interventions have failed and the patient is experiencing difficulty in their sexual and personal life because of it. The procedure is started by creating an artificial erection by injecting normal saline. Following this, an elliptical excision is done on the convex side of the penis (opposite to the thickened plaque). The width of the excised tissue depends on the degree of penile deformity. The side with the plaque is left as it is. 

The images attached below depict the pathology in Peyronie's disease and the ultrasound finding observed in the disease-

Other options-

Options (A) and (B): Lord’s operation and Jaboulay’s procedure are surgery performed for hydrocoele.

Option (D): Anderson-Hynes operation is a pyeloplasty procedure performed for hydronephrosis.

questions.text: While examining a pregnant woman, you measure her fundal height to be 32 cm and the station of the fetal head is at -2. What could be the probable weight of the fetus?
questions.solution:
The fetal weight in the above case is 3.1Kg.

In the above case, fetal weight can be estimated using Johnson's formula. Height of uterus is 32cm, the station is –2 implying the head is above the ischial spines. Therefore, it is calculated as follows: [32-12] x 155 = 3100 grams = 3.1Kg

Estimation of fetal weight:

  • Johnson’s formula: This is only applicable in vertex presentation.
    • If station of head is below the level of the ischial spine: [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-11] x 155 in grams
    • If station of head is above the level of the ischial spine: [Height of uterus above pubic symphysis (in cm)-12] x 155 in grams
  • Sonography: Fetal weight has been estimated by combining a number of biometric data, e.g. biparietal diameter (BPD), head circumference (HC), abdominal circumference (AC) and femur length (FL), using the following formulae:
    • Shepard’s formula
    • Hadlock’s formula.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with diabetes and a BMI of 46 kg/m2 undergoes the following laparoscopic procedure as shown in the image below. On the second postoperative day, she develops a fever and tachycardia, and her CBC report shows leucocytosis. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of fever, tachycardia, and leucocytosis in a postoperative patient of LSG (Laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy) should raise suspicion for leak along the gastric staple line. The next best step in the management of this patient is to perform a contrast-enhanced CT to confirm the diagnosis. 

Leaks following LSG most commonly occur in the proximal third of the stomach, close to the angle of His. Early leaks are due to tissue trauma and staple misfire, and late leaks are usually due to ischemia and high intragastric pressure.

Management of the leak involves providing nutritional support to the patient and adequate drainage. Once the leak is diagnosed, the patient should be kept nil per oral. Total parenteral nutrition and antibiotic therapy should be started in the patient. Drainage can be done either by CT-guided percutaneous catheter placement, endoscopic stenting, or operative procedures.

Note:

Since the leaks following LSG are often difficult to treat, they are called the Achilles heel of the operation.

Sleeve gastrectomy is the most commonly performed bariatric surgery in recent years. It has become the most common primary procedure for bariatric surgery.

A vertical sleeve is created, resecting most of the greater curvature
↓ 
Restriction of stomach capacity
↓ 
Early satiety
↓ 
Reduced consumption of food
↓ 
Weight loss

Advantages of sleeve gastrectomy:

  • Less challenging procedure
  • Preservation of pylorus (avoids gastric dumping)
  • No need for serial adjustments (as seen with gastric banding)
  • Reduction in internal hernias (as seen with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass)  

Complications of sleeve gastrectomy:

  • Bleed from the staple line
  • Leakage from staple line (close to the angle of His)
