questions.text:
Match the following dilution of adrenaline and its use:
A. 1:1000 
B. 1:10000
C. 1:100000
1. Cardiac arrest
2. Anaphylaxis
3. Local anesthesia
questions.solution:
A-2 B-1 C-3

Epinephrine (1:1000 solution) 0.5 ml I.M. is preferred in the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

In cardiac arrest, the 1:1000 adrenaline must be diluted to 1:10,000 for IV use.

Adrenaline in a concentration of 1: 50,000 to 1: 200,000 is added to local anesthetics for:

  • Reducing the systemic absorption
  • Prolonging the duration of action
  • Providing a more bloodless field for surgery

1:1000 dilution can be used for intramuscular, subcutaneous and inhalational (nebulization) route of administration. For intravenous use, 1:1000 adrenaline must be further diluted to 1:10,000 and used cautiously.

IM injection is preferred over intravenous (IV) bolus because it is faster in many situations and safer (ie, lower risk of cardiovascular complications, such as severe hypertension and ventricular arrhythmias). There is a much greater risk of causing harmful side effects by inappropriate dosage or misdiagnosis of anaphylaxis when using IV adrenaline.

Epinephrine is also used in the treatment of hypotension, to induce local vasoconstriction to reduce the diffusion of local anaesthetics, to induce bronchodilation in asthma and COPD.

Note: . The recommended dose of epinephrine is 1mg = 10 mL of a 1:10,000 solution administered IV every 3 to 5 minutes during resuscitation as per the CPR guidelines. For nebulization, 1:1000 adrenaline is commonly used.

questions.text: The incidence of Hodgkin's lymphoma was plotted to measure the age-wise distribution. It was found that there were two peaks, with the initial peak at 25 years and the later peak starting at age of 50. Which of the following is not true regarding such distributions?

choices.text: Such a distribution indicates that the study material is not homogenous
Such a distribution indicates 2 distinct sets of casual factors might be operative
Large numbers of observations are a frequent source of Such a distribution
A similar distribution is also seen in female breast cancer

questions.solution:
The graph shows the bimodal distribution and small numbers of observations are a frequent source of bimodality, which makes their interpretation difficult.

Bimodal distribution refers to the occurrence of two separate peaks. It usually indicates that the study material was not homogenous, and two causative factors might be in effect. Absence of bimodality doesn't indicate that the study is homogenous

Hodgkin's lymphoma, leukaemia and female breast cancer show a bimodal curve with double peaks.

 

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text: Identify the true statement about this procedure.

choices.text: B can be performed without intrathecal contrast, while A cannot
B is invasive, while A is non-invasive
Severe claustrophobia is not a contraindication to B, but it is for A
B can dynamically evaluate active CSF leaks, while A cannot

questions.solution:
The procedures depicted in images A and B represent X-ray myelography and MR myelography, respectively. MR myelography (B) can be performed without intrathecal contrast, while X-ray myelography (A) requires contrast.

X-ray myelography can be used to dynamically evaluate the spinal canal in patients with spondylolisthesis, arachnoiditis, active CSF leaks, and in the assessment of the spine post-operatively. Myelography is also done when there is a contraindication to MR such as a non-compatible pacemaker and severe claustrophobia.

Myelographic MR images are obtained without the injection of intrathecal contrast. It is a non-invasive, painless procedure and precludes exposure to radiation.

MR imaging has almost completely replaced X-ray myelography; however, the advantages of X-ray myelography over MR imaging are as follows:

  • Lower signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of MR myelography (B) compared to X-ray myelography (A) can result in missing small lesions on myelographic MR (B) images.
  • Allows dynamic and functional evaluation of the CSF and helps in the evaluation of active CSF leaks.
  • Myelography is useful in the evaluation of a postoperative spine. Artefacts of surgical material may obscure the spinal canal or nerve roots on MRI.

questions.text: A 30-year old patient comes to the hospital with complaints of blood-tinged nasal discharge. The anterior rhinoscopy shows a pink polypoidal mass in the right nose and the same is biopsied. The image given below is the histological slide of the specimen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the histopathology showing several sporangia is most likely suggestive of the diagnosis of rhinosporidiosis.

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. Patients clinically present with blood-tinged nasal discharge, and pink polypoidal mass in the nose.

Histopathology shows several sporangia, oval, or round in shape and filled with spores which may be seen bursting through its chitinous wall.

It is treated by completely excising the mass with a diathermy knife followed by cauterization of the base.

Other options :

Option A: Rhinophyma is a slow-growing benign tumor due to hypertrophy of the sebaceous glands of the tip of the nose, often seen in cases of long-standing acne rosacea. It is also called a potato tumor.

The image below shows rhinophyma.

Option C: Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus). Histopathology shows large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli, which are Mikulicz cells. There are also homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies consisting of the immunoglobulins in the plasma cells called the Russell bodies.

The image given below shows non-ulcerative granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving the feel of a woody nose in rhinoscleroma. The histology shows large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing the causative bacilli, which are Mikulicz cells.

Option D: Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in patients who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers, iron- and goldsmiths. The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia with atrophy of the seromucous glands.

Related Pearl: Rhinosporidiosis

  • It is a chronic granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi which is recently reclassified as a member of the protistan Mesomycetozoa
  • It is more common in the southern states of India
  • It affects immunocompetent individuals
  • Most commonly a waterborne disease
  • Clinical features: Blood tinged nasal discharge, frank epistaxis, nasal stuffiness
  • Findings: 
    • Leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in color and attached to the nasal septum or lateral wall
    • Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch
    • Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia
  • Diagnosis: Biopsy which shows sporangia

Histologic section showing sporangium (arrow) which is fully packed with immature sporoblasts at the periphery and mature ones at the center

Treatment: Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base. Recurrence may occur after surgical excision. Dapsone is also used.

questions.text:
A patient presents with urethral discharge. The gram stain smear of the discharge sample is shown below. Which of the following is a part of the selective medium used to culture the organism visualised?

questions.solution:
The above image shows gram‐negative intracellular diplococci within phagocytes in a stained smear characteristic of Neisseria gonorrhoeae. The selective medium used to culture N.gonorrhoeae is the modified Thayer-Martin medium which contains vancomycin, colistin, nystatin, and trimethoprim.

questions.text: Minimum number of people required for the following maneuver in a trauma patient according to ATLS is:
questions.solution:
The image shows the log rolling procedure in a trauma patient. At least four people are needed for logrolling a patient to remove a spine board and/or examine the back.

  • One person stands at the patient’s head to control the head and C-Spine and two are along the patient’s sides to control the body and extremities.
  • As the patient is rolled, three people maintain alignment of the spine.
  • Fourth person removes the board and examines the back.
  • Once the board is removed, three people return the patient to the supine position while maintaining alignment of the spine.

Recent update: The 10th edition of ATLS recommends at least 4 people for safe maneuver of log roll in patients suffering from trauma.

  • First person is assigned to restrict motion of the head and neck.
  • Second person positioned on the same side of the patient’s torso manually prevent segmental rotation, flexion, extension, lateral bending, or sagging of the chest or abdomen while transferring the patient.
  • Third person is responsible for moving the patient’s legs
  • Fourth person removes the backboard and examines the back.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presents to you with severe pain abdomen. On examination icterus is present and a small lump is palpable at the right hypochondriac region. The child is subjected to MRCP and the findings are attached below. What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The MRCP findings are suggestive of multiple intrahepatic biliary duct cystic dilations suggestive of Caroli's disease or type V choledochal cyst. The treatment of choice in such patients is Liver transplantation. 

Choledochal cysts:

Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary tree. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain. They are commonly seen in girls. 

Choledochal cyst is classified into five types:

The original classification for choledochal cysts by Alonso–Lej, and colleagues have been modified by Todani and associates to include intrahepatic cystic disease.

  • Type I: is a simple cyst that can involve any portion of the CBD.
  • Type II: It is described as an isolated diverticulum arising from the wall of the CBD
  • Type III: They arise from the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct and are also known as choledochocele.
  • Type IVA: The cysts consist of multiple dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type IVB: These choledochal cysts are multiple dilatations involving only the extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type V (Caroli’s disease): It consists of multiple dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts.

Caroli's disease:

Caroli’s Disease is an autosomal recessive condition multifocal cystic dilatation of segmental intrahepatic bile ducts. According to Todani classification, it is classified as a type V choledochal cyst.  

USG may show dilated intrahepatic bile ducts in these individuals. The beaded appearance of intrahepatic bile ducts on HIDA scan and Central Dot sign on CT are characteristic findings associated with Caroli's disease. MRCP is the investigation of choice.

Treatment options:

  • Type I—excision of the cyst with its mucosa and reconstruction by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy.
  • In type II—excision of the diverticulum and suturing of the CBD wall can be done
  • Type III cysts represent Choledochoceles, consisting of cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum. As type III cysts are associated with the lowest malignancy risk of any choledochal cyst, endoscopic sphincterotomy followed by surveillance is generally recommended over cyst excision with pancreaticoduodenectomy.
  • Type IV, if the cyst is adherent to the portal vein posteriorly, that part of the cyst wall over the portal vein is left behind. But mucosa of the part should be removed. This is named Lily’s operation.
  • Excision of all cystic tissues and reconstruction of the biliary tree is recommended for extrahepatic biliary involvement as in Type 4B and in case of intrahepatic involvement, an additional segmental resection of the liver may be required which can be removed by hepatectomy.
  • Liver transplantation is the preferred treatment of choice in type IV and type V.

The image attached below shows the central dot sign seen in Caroli's disease.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: A woman has a ​blood glucose level of 320 mg/dL and a GFR of 110 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum for glucose is 300mg/min?
questions.solution:
The amount of glucose excreted in the above scenario is 52 mg/min.

Step 1: Calculate total filtered glucose:

In this question,

  • GFR = 110 ml/min
  • Plasma glucose concentration = 320 mg/dL= 3.2mg/ml (1 dL=100 ml).
  • Total filtered glucose = GFR X Plasma glucose concentration.

                               = 110 ml/min x 3.2 mg/ml
                               = 352 mg/min.

Step 2: Check transport maximum:

In the above question, the transport maximum is 300 mg/min.

Step 3: Calculate the excretion:

Excretion = Total filtered glucose – total reabsorbed glucose (transport maximum for glucose)

  = 352 – 300 mg/min
  = 52 mg/min

The renal threshold for glucose is the plasma level at which the glucose first appears in the urine. If all the tubules in the nephron worked at a given time, then the renal threshold would be 300mg/dL, that is, 375 mg/min (TmG) divided by 125 mL/min (GFR). However, the actual renal threshold is 200mg/dL. This is because, at a given time, not all tubules are reabsorbing the glucose. This deviation in the actual renal threshold from the calculated renal threshold is called renal splay.

The normal transport maximum in males is 375mg/min and in females is 300mg/min.

questions.text:
Match the syndromes given in column A with the structures involved given in column B. (CN- cranial nerve, CST- corticospinal tract)
Column A Column B
1. Weber syndrome A. CST, medial lemniscus, hypoglossal nerve
2. Medial medullary syndrome B. CN III, ventral midbrain, CST, red nucleus
3. Millard–Gubler syndrome C. CN VIII, CN IX and CST
4. Benedikt syndrome D. CN III, ventral midbrain, CST
  E. CN VI, CN VII, ventral pons
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-D, 2-A, 3-E, 4-B.

Important syndromes in the brainstem are

Midbrain

  • Weber syndrome- It affects cranial nerve (CN) III, ventral midbrain, and corticospinal tract. Patients will have contralateral hemiplegia and paralysis of the third cranial nerve.
  • Benedikt syndrome- It affects CN III, ventral midbrain, corticospinal tract, and red nucleus. Patients will have contralateral hemiparesis, third nerve palsy, intention tremor, and cerebellar ataxia.
  • Top of basilar syndrome- It affects occipital lobes, midbrain oculomotor nuclei, cerebral peduncle, medial and temporal lobe, and thalamus. Patients will have contralateral hemiparesis, cortical blindness, oculomotor deficits, memory difficulty, and contralateral sensory deficit.

Pons

  • Milard Gubler syndrome- It affects CN VI, CN VII, and ventral pons. Patients will have contralateral hemiparesis, CN VI and CN VII palsies.
  • Clumsy hand syndrome- It affects the corticospinal tract. Patients will have contralateral hemiparesis, dysarthria, and facial weakness.
  • Foville syndrome- It affects CN VII, ventral pons, and paramedian pontine reticular formation. Patients will have ipsilateral CN VII palsy, contralateral hemiparesis, gaze palsy to the side of the lesion.

Medulla

  • Medial medullary syndrome- It affects the corticospinal tract, medial lemniscus, and hypoglossal nerve. Patients will have contralateral hemiparesis, loss of position and vibratory sensation, and ipsilateral tongue paresis. 
  • Lateral medullary syndrome- It affects the spinothalamic tract, trigeminal nucleus, cerebellum and inferior cerebellar peduncle, vestibular nuclei, and nucleus ambiguus. Patients will have ataxia, dysphagia, hemisensory loss, facial weakness, and Horner syndrome.

Brown Sequard syndrome is the hemisection of the spinal cord. Patients present with ipsilateral weakness, ipsilateral loss of position sense, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature.

questions.text: Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017, a patient has the right to choose his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment. What is this provision known as?
questions.solution:
The provision by which a patient has the right to choose his caretaker and future course of action in treatment because of illness or incapacity is known as an advance directive. It is also known as a living will, personal directive, or medical directive.

Related Pearl: The Mental Health Care Act, 2017 and The Mental Health Act, 1987

The Mental Health Care Act, 2017, was passed to provide for health care and services for persons with mental illness and to protect, promote and fulfill their rights during the delivery of mental health care.

Its main provisions are:

  • Patient autonomy: The mentally ill patient has the right to make an advance directive about their treatment and their nominated representative.
  • If the mental health professional/care-giver does not wish to follow the advance directive made by the patient, they can send an application to the Mental Health Board to review/alter/cancel the advance directive.
  • Decriminalization of suicide.
  • Mental Health Review Commission and Mental Health Authority set up.

 

The Mental Health Act, 1987:

The Mental Health Act, 1987 deals with the care of the mentally ill, makes provisions with respect to their property and affairs and states the law for psychiatric hospitals .

Important provisions under it for the diagnosis of mental illness are:

  • For the diagnosis of mental illness, an individual can be kept in a psychiatric hospital for 10 days.
  • If the mental health professional needs further time, the magistrate can permit an extension of 10 more days.
  • This extension can be permitted only twice.
  • Thus, an individual can be detained in a psychiatric hospital for a maximum period of 30 days only.
  • If a mentally ill person is detained against these provisions, the responsible authority can be punished with an imprisonment of upto 2 years.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient presented with right-sided flank pain which radiates to the groin. She also reports nausea and one episode of vomiting. Her X-Ray abdomen is shown below. She has been on regular medication for a seizure disorder. Which of the following drugs can be implicated in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette showing acute symptoms of right flank pain radiating to the groin along with bilateral stones in the abdominal x-ray makes renal calculi a likely diagnosis, which is commonly associated with the antiepileptic drug Topiramate.

Acute renal colic presents with sudden onset of severe pain originating in the flank and radiating inferiorly and anteriorly. At least half the patients will also present with nausea and vomiting. Patients with renal calculi may report infection or hematuria.

Topiramate is an anti-epileptic that can be used as initial mono-drug therapy for 

  • Focal seizures
  • GTCS
  • Lennox-Gastaut syndrome in patients ≥ 2 years 

Mechanism of action: Topiramate acts by

  • Reducing voltage-gated Na+ currents 
  • Activating a hyperpolarizing K+ current
  • Enhancing postsynaptic GABAA receptor currents
  • Limiting the activation of glutamate receptors. 

The drug is also a weak inhibitor of renal carbonic anhydrase and can lead to metabolic acidosis. Metabolic acidosis causes hypocitraturia and hypercalciuria that increase urinary saturation and predispose to the formation of renal calculi.

Other options :

Option A: Ezogabine causes urinary retention and blue pigmentation of the skin.

Option C: Vigabatrin causes bilateral vision loss and a contraction of the visual field.

Option D: Oxcarbazepine causes side effects similar to carbamazepine which include hyponatremia and Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

questions.text:
An elderly woman was brought to the hospital because she has frequent memory problems. Her son says that last week when she had been to the market, she had lost her way home. She was taking care of the expenses of her home, but now she has a problem with calculations and managing household things. She is also unable to recall the names of commonly used items. MRI shows the presence of temporal lobe atrophy. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
  1. Visuospatial deficits occur early followed by memory impairment
  2. Neurofibrillary tangles are composed of hyperphosphorylated tau proteins
  3. Apo E2 allele is a risk factor
  4. NSAIDs are found to be protective
  5. Pyridostigmine is used in the treatment
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario suggests Alzheimer's disease (AD). Statements 2 and 4 are true regarding this condition.

 

1. Visuospatial defects occur in the late or severe stages of the disease. Episodic memory loss is commonly seen in the early stage. 

2. Neurofibrillary tangles are composed of hyperphosphorylated tau proteins 

3. Apo E2 allele is a protective factor whereas the ApoE4 allele is a risk factor 

4. NSAIDs according to the studies, is a protective factor

5. Pyridostigmine is not used in the treatment of Alzheimer's disease. It is used in the management of myasthenia gravis. 

 

AD is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly.

Risk factors

  • Age >70 years
  • Positive family history
  • Female gender
  • Apo ε4 allele
  • Diabetes (increase the risk threefold)
  • Hypertension
  • Elevated homocysteine and cholesterol levels
  • Diminished intake of folic acid, fruits, vegetables, and red wine
  • Low levels of exercise
  • Down syndrome
  • Mutation in presenilin 1 and presenilin 2 genes

Protective factors

  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
  • Apo ε2

The cognitive changes of AD have a characteristic pattern. It begins with memory impairment and progresses to language and visuospatial deficits, followed by executive dysfunction.

The initial memory loss may go unrecognized as the patients might think that it is due to aging. Later, the patient has difficulty in keeping track of finances, following instructions on the job, driving, shopping, and housekeeping. In severe impairment, the patient easily gets lost and confused. Language deficits appear as impairment in naming, comprehension, and finally fluency. Patients have difficulty dressing, eating, copy geometric figures, and reading the clock due to their visuospatial deficits.

In the later stages, the patient becomes rigid, mute, incontinent, and bedridden, and help is needed with eating, dressing, and toileting.

A radiograph may be normal in the initial stages. It is mainly done to exclude other causes of dementia-like neoplasms, infections, vascular dementia, hydrocephalus, etc. In later stages, there may be posterior-predominant cortical atrophy along with atrophy of the medial temporal memory structures.

The earliest and most severe degeneration is usually found in the medial temporal lobe (entorhinal/perirhinal cortex and hippocampus), inferolateral temporal cortex, and nucleus basalis of Meynert. It shows the presence of neuritic plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. Neuritic plaques are formed by a central core of amyloid, proteoglycans, ApoE, α-antichymotrypsin, and other proteins. Neurofibrillary tangles are composed of silver-staining neuronal cytoplasmic fibrils composed of abnormally phosphorylated tau proteins. 

It is treated with cholinesterase inhibitors like donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine, and NMDA receptor antagonist like memantine.

 

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical
    • 2 or more areas of cognitive deficits
    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out 

Risk Factors:

  • Most important risk factor: Old age
  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

CT/MRI:

  • Later stages: Cortical and subcortical atrophy prominent in parietal and temporal lobes, particularly hippocampus. 

Treatment:

  • NMDA antagonist: memantine
  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: A 60-year-old asthmatic lady on inhalational bronchodilators presents with shortness of breath. Incidentally, you also notice the outpatient slip to be bearing the same date with an entry in the ophthalmology glaucoma clinic. Which of the possible drugs would have most likely exacerbated her attack of asthma?
questions.solution:
Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that is used in glaucoma. Non-selective beta-blockers can cause precipitation of bronchial asthma in susceptible individuals due to its antagonist effect on β2 receptor on bronchial smooth muscles. 

Timolol reduce intraocular pressure by decreasing aqueous formation by blockade of β2 receptor which are present on ciliary epithelium.

Timolol is also used for hypertension, congestive heart failure, acute myocardial infarction,and migraine prophylaxis. In ophthalmology, timolol has been used inthe treatment of open-angle glaucoma and intraocular hypertension. 

Timolol is associated with exacerbation of respiratory conditions like asthma & COPD, bradycardia, hypoglycemia, depression, and impotence (Due to non selective β2 receptor blockade).

Other options:

Option B : Betaxolol is a  β1 selective blocker that is used in glaucoma and has a lower propensity to precipitate bronchial asthma.

Options C : Celiprolol is a third-generation selective β1  blocker with weak β2 agnostic action used for hypertension. It is safe in asthmatics. 

Option D : Latanoprost is a prostaglandin (PGF2α) analog and safe in patients with bronchial asthma. 

Related Pearl: Antiglaucoma drugs: Mechanism of lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) at a glance

Drugs that increase trabecular outflow

  • Miotics (e.g., pilocarpine)
  • Epinephrine, dipivefrine

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents to the hospital with complaints of blood-stained sputum. He has smoked around 1.5 packs per day for the last 20 years. Bronchoscopy was suggestive of lung carcinoma. A biopsy was obtained and is shown below. The cells were positive for thyroid transcription factor-1, napsin A and were negative for p63 and p40. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of adenocarcinoma lung. The microscopic image of the tissue shows an increased mucinous type of cells and their characteristics growth along the pre-existing alveolar septa.

Smoking is a major risk factor for developing lung cancer. Other risk factors that can contribute are industrial chemical exposure, air pollution, etc.

They are broadly divided into

  1. Small cell lung cancer
  2. Non-small cell lung cancer
    1. Adenocarcinoma
    2. Squamous cell carcinoma
    3. Large cell carcinoma

Though adenocarcinoma is the most common tumor of the lung in non-smokers, it can be seen in smokers as well. It is also more common in women. Adenocarcinoma of the lung occurs in the periphery of the lung, frequently in areas of chronic scarring caused by chronic inflammatory changes. 

Clinical features include cough, chest pain, hemoptysis, and symptoms due to metastasis. Some lung cancers are responsible for paraneoplastic syndromes.

Lung adenocarcinomas are now classified by their predominant pattern:

  • Lepidic pattern (At the periphery of the tumor, the tumor cells crawl along the surrounding normal alveoli)
  • Acinar pattern
  • Papillary pattern
  • Solid patterns (poor prognosis)

Lung nodules should always be compared with previous films. CT scan is done for further evaluation and biopsy is done to confirm the diagnosis.

In the image below glandular differentiation can be noted which is seen in adenocarcinoma of the lung.

Other options:

Option B: Small cell carcinomas:

They have the strongest association with smoking. They include loss-of-function mutations involving TP53, RB, and chromosome 3p deletions. Small cell carcinomas arise in the bronchi or in the periphery of the lungs. Extensive necrosis leads to the coating of the surrounding walls by DNA. This appears as basophilic staining of the vascular walls and is called the Azzopardi effect. They express chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56.

Below image- Small cell carcinoma:

Option D: Large cell carcinoma 

It is an undifferentiated malignant epithelial tumor that lacks the cytologic features of other forms of lung cancer. They do not express markers of adenocarcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma.

Option A: Squamous cell carcinomas

They are commonly found in men and are strongly associated with smoking. They are located in the central or perihilar region. It can grow as an exophytic mass in the bronchial lumen leading to bronchial obstruction. They are positive for p63 and p40.

Below image- Squamous cell carcinoma:

questions.text:
A child born with a rare genetic disorder presented with failure to thrive and susceptibility to recurrent pyogenic, viral, and fungal infections. His blood reports showed lymphopenia. He was advised to stay in a protective 'bubble' as shown in the image below. The anxious parents of this child want you to try and are ready to experiment with any novel technology or therapeutic interventions available for its treatment. You along with your biochemist and a genetic engineer are planning to work holistically for the treatment of this child. Given below are five different statements on the suspected disease and its therapeutic options. Pick out the incorrect statements.
  1. X-linked inheritance is the most common form of this disease.
  2. It can be associated with a defective non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ).
  3. The X-linked form is due to the deficiency of the adenosine deaminase enzyme.
  4. Both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses are defective.
  5. The novel gene therapy for this condition is safe and associated with minimal complications.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image of a child in a protective bubble (Bubble boy disease) are suggestive of Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). Statements 3 and 5 only are false.

X-linked SCID is the most common form where there is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. Gene therapy for SCID involves the introduction of a new copy of the gene through a retroviral vector. This involves biological vector delivery rather than physical gene delivery vehicles like plasmid-liposomal complex. Currently, Hematopoietic Stem Cell (HSC) transplantation is the mainstay of treatment, but X-linked SCID is the first human disease in which gene therapy has been successful. For gene therapy, a normal γc gene is expressed using a viral vector in HSCs taken from patients, and the cells are then transplanted back into the patients.

Unfortunately, some of these patients with successful gene therapy have developed T-cell lymphoblastic leukaemia, highlighting the dangers of this particular approach to gene therapy. 

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) is characterized by:

  • Defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses.
  • Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, and a host of other bacteria.
  • Genes involved are JAK3, RAG1, and IL-7R.

Types of SCID:

X-linked SCID

  • The most common form, accounting for 50% to 60% of cases, is X-linked, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls.
  • The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors.
  • The thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells resembling fetal thymus.

Autosomal recessive

  • The most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme.
  • In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

Defective non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ).

NHEJ is a predominant pathway for DNA double-stranded break repair. NHEJ deficiency confers (severe) combined immunodeficiency due to a failure to carry out V(D)J recombination efficiently. NHEJ also functions in class switch recombination, another step enhancing T and B cell diversity.

Note:

The deficiency of adenosine deaminase enzyme was the first pathophysiologic condition to be treated by gene therapy. In1990, Dr. William French Anderson introduced a new copy of this gene, which was carried on a retroviral vector, into a 4-year-old girl suffering from severe combined immunodeficiency (bubble boy disease).

Gene therapy involves the introduction of the normal gene in affected individuals using viral or non-viral vectors. Its application is limited to single-gene disorders only. Down syndrome is a chromosomal disorder and transferring a single gene would not cure the disease.  Techniques used in gene therapy are as follows:

  • Delivery of DNA into patient's cells by using recombinant viruses/naked DNA/DNA complexes.
  • Methods used include intranuclear injection, electroporation, gene-gun, sonoporation, and magnetofection.

Note:

FDA-approved gene therapy is used for SCID, Duchenne muscular dystrophy, cystic fibrosis, Leber's congenital amaurosis, familial hypercholesterolemia, multiple myeloma, and adrenoleukodystrophy.

questions.text: A patient who is undergoing treatment for a malignancy, develops generalized edema of the body. Urinary examination reveals grade 3 proteinuria and the presence of hyaline and fatty casts. She has no history of hematuria. The renal biopsy shows no immune deposits. What neoplasm is the patient likely to have?
questions.solution:
The clinical findings, proteinuria, and the absence of immune deposits on biopsy in this patient are strongly suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to minimal change disease (MCD). There is an increased incidence of MCD in patients suffering from Hodgkin lymphoma.

Minimal change disease is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children (peaks between 2–6 years). They account for only 10–15% of nephrotic syndrome in adults.

Minimal change disease in adults is usually associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma and less frequently other lymphomas and leukemias. 

Causes:

  • It is mostly idiopathic.
  • Associated with Hodgkin lymphoma (due to the increased production of cytokines)
  • Associated with atopic disorders such as eczema and rhinitis.
  • It is clinically associated with respiratory infections and prophylactic immunizations

They present mostly with proteinuria. 

Biopsy findings include the following: 

  • Light microscopy: Glomeruli appear normal as shown in the image below (hence called "minimal change")
  • Immunofluorescence studies: No Ig or complement deposits
  • Electron microscopy: Diffuse effacement of foot processes of visceral epithelial cells (podocytopathy)

 

The illustration given below shows the effacement of foot processes of podocytes as seen in MCD.

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient was started on an antipsychotic drug that decreased his hallucinations significantly. 3 days after starting the medication, he developed torticollis and orofaciolingual movements. This effect is due to which of the following actions?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from acute dystonia. Acute dystonia is seen due to the D2 blocking effect of the antipsychotic.

Acute dystonia is an extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotics that occurs within 1-5 days of intake.It is characterized by spasms of the muscles of the tongue, face, neck and back.

Amongst extrapyramidal symptoms of antipsychotics, acute muscular dystonia is the earliest appearing symptom and akathisia is the most common one.

Other options:

Option A: Alpha blockade results in hypotension and sedation.
Option B: H1 blockade results in an antiemetic effect and causes sedation
Option C: Antimuscarinic effect result in dry mouth, dilated pupils, and urinary retention.

questions.text: A patient complained of stiffness and pain in the elbow, which is aggravated when he lifts objects. An arthroscopic release of extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon was done, after failed conservative therapy. Which of the following clinical tests would not have been positive before the surgery?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem with stiffness and pain in the elbow, which is aggravated on lifting objects and treated with arthroscopic release of extensor carpi radialis brevis is suggestive of Lateral epicondylitis or Tennis elbow, in which reverse Cozen's test will not elicit pain.

Reverse Cozen sign is positive in golfer's elbow or medial epicondylitis- Resisted wrist and finger flexion in pronation elicit pain and tenderness over the medial epicondyle.

Tennis elbow (lateral epicondylitis) is tendinopathy characterized by pain arising from the origin of extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) at the lateral epicondyle. It is caused by repetitive contraction of extensor muscles at the origin during activities that involve repeated forceful wrist extension and supination (Eg: backhand in tennis and use of a screwdriver). 

Patients present with outer elbow pain, radiating down the forearm and along with morning stiffness of the elbow. The pain is often aggravated by lifting objects and shaking hands. The elbow may appear normal or have slight swelling, with a full range of movement.

Tenderness is present over the lateral epicondyle. Clinical tests for tennis elbow are:

  • Cozen's test: Resisted extension of the wrist with the elbow in full extension elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.
  • Maudsley’s test: extension of the middle finger against resistance elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.
  • Mill's sign: Extension of the elbow in pronation with a flexed wrist elicits pain at the lateral epicondyle.

Management:

  • Conservative management (consisting of rest, physiotherapy, and exercises)
  • A counterforce brace: releases the forces in the extensor carpi radialis brevis (ECRB) region. The counterforce brace acts by compression of the extensor muscles thereby preventing the tension from transmitting up to the lateral epicondyle. It is shown below.
  • Injection of local anesthetic and steroids
  • Mill’s Maneuver: Forceful extension of a fully flexed and pronated forearm after the injection may be attempted. Rarely performed now.

Surgical methods

  • Arthroscopic or percutaneous release of ERCB and/or epicondylar muscles
  • Bosworth technique: Involves the excision of the proximal portion of the annular ligament, the release of the origin of the extensor muscles, excision of the bursa, and excision of synovial fringes.

Other methods of management: extracorporeal shock wave therapy, autologous blood injections, rehabilitative exercises, and ultrasound-guided percutaneous needle therapy.

Related Pearl: Medial and lateral epicondylitis

Tennis elbow or Lateral epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over or below the lateral epicondyle of the humerus
  • Pain is aggravated by lifting movements
  • It is common among tennis players and in those who perform repetitive wrist extension
  • Extensor carpi radialis brevis tendon is commonly involved

Tests:

  • Cozen's test: The patient is asked to pronate the forearm and make a tight fist.  Wrist extension against resistance causes pain at the lateral epicondyle
  • Mills sign: Pain at the lateral condyle when the elbow is extended in pronation with a flexed wrist
  • Wringing test: The patient is asked to wring a towel. Pain is felt at the lateral epicondyle in the tennis elbow
  • Maudsley's test: Resisted extension of the middle finger produces pain at the lateral epicondyle

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and usage of a tennis elbow clasp are sufficient in most cases. Corticosteroid and local anesthetic injections into the tender area may reduce the pain, but is not curative
  • Operative treatment: Detachment of the common extensor muscle from the lateral epicondyle

 

Golfer's elbow or Medial epicondylitis

  • Pain is felt over the medial epicondyle of the humerus where pronators have their origin
  • Associated with ulnar nerve neuropathy
  • Less common than tennis elbow

Tests:

  • Reverse Cozen: The elbow is kept in slight flexion with the hand and wrist in supination. The examiner attempts to extend the elbow, while the patient is asked to resist this movement with active flexion. If pain is elicited at the medial epicondyle, it suggests golfer’s elbow

Treatment: 

  • Conservative treatment: Activity modification and pain killers is sufficient in most cases
  • Operative treatment:  Excision of the abnormal tendons at the flexor-pronator origin

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with a 2x2 cm mass in her left breast. Mammography showed 4 satellite nodules in the same breast. FNAC of the mass and the nodules turned out to be positive for malignancy. Which of the following is the best treatment modality in her case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of carcinoma of the breast with satellite nodules. This implies that the patient is suffering from T4b disease as per the TNM staging causing stage III B disease. 

The preferred treatment of choice in such patients is modified radical mastectomy combined with neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Pre-operative chemotherapy and postoperative radiotherapy will add to the benefit of the patients.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy is brought to the casualty by his friends after the consumption of the recreational drug- magic mushrooms. On examination, he is delirious and has visual and auditory hallucinations. Blood and urine samples are sent for toxicological analysis which shows the presence of d-lysergic acid. Which among the following did the boy consume?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing hallucinations and the presence of d-lysergic acid is suggestive of the consumption of Psilocybe species of mushrooms/fungi which exhibits mycetism.

Mycotic poisoning is of two types: Mycetism and Mycotoxicosis

Mycetism:

The fungus when eaten, itself causes toxic effects. The hallucinogenic agents (d-lysergic acid and psilocybin) produced by Psilocybe species have attracted attention as recreational drugs in recent years. 

Other fungi which that show mycotic poisoning in the form of mycetism include:

  • Claviceps → Ergot poisoning
  • Coprine → coprine poisoning
  • Inocybe → muscarine poisoning

Mycotoxicosis:

Fungal toxins contaminate food and cause toxic effects.

Examples:

  • Aflatoxins: These are a type of mycotoxins produced by Aspergillus species of fungi, such as A. flavus (secretes B1) and A. parasiticus (secretes B1, B2, G1 and G2)
  • Fusarium toxins

questions.text: A 38-year-old farmer is bitten by an insect whose life cycle is as portrayed below. He develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash 2 weeks later. A positive serological diagnosis for this condition is made using agglutination with antigens from which of the following species?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing characteristic eschar with lymphadenopathy and rash, along with the life cycle of a trombiculid mite (which acts as the vector), is suggestive of scrub typhus. It gives a positive Weil-Felix reaction with OX K agglutinins, which are derived from Proteus mirabilis.

Scrub typhus, also known as chigger-borne typhus, is caused by Rickettsia or Orientia tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. The incubation period is 1–3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash.

questions.text: A deficiency of which factor promotes the formation of thrombus?
questions.solution:
Individuals with the deficiency of Factor XII do not bleed and in fact, maybe susceptible to thrombosis.

Deficiencies of factor V, VII, VIII, IX, and X are associated with moderate to severe bleeding disorders, while factor XI deficiency is only associated with mild bleeding. Individuals with factor XII deficiency do not bleed at all and are susceptible to thrombosis. This paradoxical effect is explained by the involvement of factor XII in the pro-inflammatory bradykinin pathway and the fibrinolytic pathway.

The fibrinolytic pathway is largely accomplished through the activation of plasmin which breaks down fibrin. Plasmin is generated by the catabolism of plasminogen by a sequence involving factor XII. Hence, a deficiency of factor XII may promote thrombosis. This isn't significant in human thrombotic diseases as plasminogen is also activated by t-PA which is produced by the endothelium.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with arachnoiditis, classified as type II on MRI. What is the characteristic finding you are expecting to see?

choices.text: Mass of soft tissue in the spinal canal

questions.solution:
Empty thecal sac sign is seen in type II arachnoiditis.

Arachnoiditis refers to inflammation of the meninges and subarachnoid space. It is characterized by the thickening of the arachnoid membrane and dura mater. The most severe form of arachnoiditis is adhesive arachnoiditis, where scar tissue compresses the nerve roots, disrupting blood supply and flow of cerebrospinal fluid.

Rarely, there may be ossification or dystrophic calcification leading to arachnoiditis ossificans, or ossification of the spinal arachnoid.

The causes of arachnoiditis include:

  • Meningitis
  • Chronic spinal infections like tuberculosis
  • Intrathecal hemorrhage
  • ​Intrathecal drugs - contrast media, anesthetics, steroids 
  • Surgery

MRI is the imaging study of choice for the diagnosis and evaluation of arachnoiditis. Three morphological patterns seen on MRI are:

Type I: nerve roots are clumped together and distorted
Type II: nerve roots are adherent to the theca resulting in an empty thecal sac sign
Type III: nerve roots and theca are clumped or matted together into a single soft tissue mass centrally within the spinal canal

questions.text: A primigravida comes to the primary health center for a routine antenatal visit and enquires about consumption of iron tablets. Which of the following is recommended for pregnant women during the antenatal period based on Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme?

choices.text: 100 mg of elemental iron for 100 days
60 mg of elemental iron for 100 days
60 mg of elemental iron for 180 days
100 mg of elemental iron for 180 days

questions.solution:
According to Anemia Mukt Bharat Scheme, 60 mg of elemental iron and 500 mcg of folic acid are given daily for a minimum of 180 days during pregnancy. It is to be started from the fourth month of pregnancy and to be continued for 180 days, post-partum.

Anemia Mukt Bharat scheme (2018) is an initiative that aims to strengthen the existing mechanisms and foster newer strategies for tackling anemia. It follows a 6x6x6 strategy. Here, 6 groups of beneficiaries are assisted by 6 interventions and 6 institutional mechanisms.

The six distinct groups of beneficiaries are children of 6-59 months of age, children of 5-9 years, adolescents, women in the reproductive age group, pregnant women, and lactating mothers. 

The six interventions are:

  • Iron and folic acid supplementation prophylactically
  • Deworming
  • Behavior change communication campaign
  • Using digital methods and point of care treatment
  • Provision of iron and folic acid fortified foods
  • Addressing non-nutritional causes of anemia

Related Pearl: Prophylactic Iron and Folic Acid (IFA) Supplementation

According to the Anemia Mukt Bharat 2018 scheme, giving IFA to children, adolescents, women of reproductive age, and pregnant women, irrespective of their anemia status, is a key intervention.

questions.text: A 15-month-old baby was brought to the OPD with a history of self-injurious behavior. Past medical history is significant for multiple episodes of seizures. Labs reveal increased plasma tyrosine levels. Urine metabolic screening reveals the presence of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid and its metabolites. Enzyme studies reveal a deficiency of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase. Which of the following inborn errors of metabolism is the child suffering from?
questions.solution:
Primary deficiency of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (4-HPPD) causes hereditary tyrosinemia type 3. The diagnosis is suspected in children with sustained moderate increases in plasma levels of tyrosine (typically 350-700 µmol/L on a normal diet) and the presence of 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid and its metabolites 4-hydroxyphenyllactic and 4-hydroxyphenylacetic acids in urine.

Asymptomatic infants with 4-HPPD deficiency have been identified by neonatal screening for hypertyrosinemia. In symptomatic patients, developmental delay, seizures, intermittent ataxia, and self-injurious behavior have been reported. Liver and renal abnormalities are absent.

Treatment principally includes a low-protein diet and vitamin C.

Other options

Option A: Type 1 tyrosinemia

Type 1 tyrosinemia is the most common form of tyrosinemia caused by defective fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme. They usually present between 2-6 months of age with acute liver failure. They may also present with peripheral neuropathy resembling acute porphyria. Renal involvement is manifested as a Fanconi-like syndrome with hyperphosphaturia, hypophosphatemia, and vitamin-D-resistant rickets.

Boiled cabbage odor may be present in classical type 1 tyrosinemia resulting from increased methionine metabolites (sulfur-containing compounds). Boiled cabbage odor can also be found in cases of Hypermethioninemia.

Elevated levels of succinylacetone in blood or urine is diagnostic of type 1 tyrosinemia. Tyrosinemia type 1 is treated with nitisinone and a diet low in phenylalanine and tyrosine. Rarely, patients treated with nitisinone may develop corneal crystals of tyrosine which can be reduced by strict dietary control.

Option B: Tyrosinemia II tyrosinemia:

Richner-Hanhart syndrome or oculocutaneous tyrosinemia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of tyrosine aminotransferase and presents with ocular manifestations like excessive tearing, redness, pain, photophobia, herpetiform corneal ulcers, intellectual disability and painful, nonpruritic hyperkeratotic plaques on the soles, palms, and fingertips.

Option C: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-linked recessive disorder due to a complete deficiency of the HGPRT enzyme. This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine resulting in increased levels of phospho-ribosyl pyrophosphate (PRPP) and decreased levels of inosine monophosphate (IMP) and guanosine monophosphate (GMP). This causes increased de novo purine synthesis and excessive amounts of uric acid. Patients present with self-mutilating behavior, delayed developmental milestones, positive family history, and hyperuricemia

questions.text: The biopsy of a resected inguinal mass from a patient shows marked fibrotic changes with prominent Leydig cells and hypoplastic Sertoli cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological features are strongly suggestive of cryptorchidism.

Cryptorchidism is histopathologically characterized by the following: 

  1. Testicular atrophy: thickening of the basement membrane, arrested germ cell development, marked hyalinization
  2. Tubules showing Sertoli cells but no spermatogenesis
  3. Increase in the interstitial Leydig cells. 

Cryptorchidism is the failure of the descent of the intra-abdominal testes into the scrotal sac.  It is the most common congenital abnormality of the genitourinary tract. The testes can arrest anywhere during descent, and the most common site is the inguinal region.

Phases of testicular descent:

  • Transabdominal phase: Testes come to lie in the lower abdomen or pelvis. This phase of descent is regulated by Mullerian-inhibiting substances.
  • Inguinoscrotal phase: Testes descend along the inguinal canal and reach the scrotal sac. This phase of the descent is regulated by androgen-induced calcitonin gene-related peptide from the genitofemoral nerve.

The exact pathogenesis remains unknown, however, deficiency in gonadotropins and Mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) and increased expression of estradiol in the placenta are thought to play a role. It is associated with testicular atrophy and dysfunction, which result in sterility. Cryptorchid testes carry a 3–5-fold higher risk for testicular cancer (usually seminoma).

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the OPD following a sting on his toe. On examination, he had tachycardia and hypertension and his pupils were dilated. Local examination of the wound showed mild erythema. The arachnid responsible for the sting is shown below. Which of the following drugs is used to counteract these effects?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem with the image showing a scorpion points to a scorpion bite, for which prazosin acts as a physiological antidote counteracting the symptoms of tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis. 

Most scorpion stings cause pain at the site of the bite. Systemic toxicity occurs in <10% of stings but is more commonly seen in infants and children. The venom is a clear, colorless toxalbumen and is generally classified as either hemolytic or neurotoxic. The venom is a potent autonomic stimulator resulting in the release of massive amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals. It also has a direct effect on the myocardium.

It can present as neurotoxicity with restlessness or seizure-like activity, abnormal oculomotor function, and loss of pharyngeal muscle control leading to respiratory compromise. Tongue fasciculations and hypersalivation are also common. Cardiovascular toxicity from systemic envenomation includes tachycardia, hypertension, pulmonary edema, and cardiogenic shock.

If the scorpion has hemolytic venom, the reaction is mainly local, with edema, pain, and reddening. This usually lasts for one to two hours. 

Treatment:

  • Pain- Paracetamol, NSAIDs, or opioids 
  • Sedation for agitation, oculomotor abnormalities, uncoordinated neuromuscular activity, muscle spasms- Benzodiazepines 
  • Hypertension and pulmonary edema- Prazosin counteracts the adrenergic surge that can lead to these effects
  • Cardiogenic shock- Antivenom, prazosin, nitroglycerin, dobutamine
  • Cholinergic effects- Atropine
  • Supportive care, wound care

questions.text: A male baby born to a non-consanguineous couple was brought to you with the complaints of severe blistering formed after minor mechanical traumas. You suspect epidermolysis bullosa simplex in this child. Which of the following keratin heterodimers will be affected due to mutation in the genes leading to this condition?
questions.solution:
The mutations in the genes for keratin 5 and 14 are associated with epidermolysis bullosa simplex (EBS).

Keratin is a complex protein produced by keratinocytes. It is a major component of our hair and nails, and also the stratum corneum of the skin.

Keratin filaments exist as combinations of one acidic and one basic filament.

Note:

Keratin Heterodimer Site
K5/14 Stratum Basale
K1/10 Stratum Spinosum
K3/K12 Cornea- Eye
K4/K13 Buccal Mucosa
K8/18 Simple Epithelium

 

Note: Epidermolysis bullosa is a disorder in which blisters develop in areas of minor trauma. It results from the congenital absence of proteins that help to maintain the structure of the epidermis and also those that connect the dermis and epidermis. There are three types of epidermolysis bullosa-

  • Epidermolysis bullosa simplex - where the defect is in K5/K14
  • Junctional epidermolysis bullosa - where the defect is in Laminin
  • Dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa - where the defect is in Collagen-7

Related Pearl: Dermoepidermal Junction/Basement Membrane Zone

  • The junction between epidermis and dermis is called the basement membrane zone or dermoepidermal junction and consists of a number of extracellular macromolecules.
  • As many of these components are glycoproteins, the BMZ can be recognized histologically by staining with PAS stain.
  • Ultrastructural examination by electron microscopy shows 2 different layers with different optical densities
    • Lamina Lucida - upper, less electron dense layer
    • Lamina Densa - lower, more electron dense layer
  • This zone is composed of 3 components : 1. Hemidesmosome 2. Anchoring Filaments 3. Anchoring Fibrils.

1.HEMIDESMOSOME

  • Hemidesmosomes are multiprotein complexes that facilitate the stable adhesion of basal epithelial cells to the underlying basement membrane.
  • The intermediate keratin filaments K5/K14 present within the basal keratinocytes attach to the hemidesmosomes at the base of the cell.
  • The major hemidesmosomal Protein is Bullous Pemphigoid Antigen-1 (BPAg1 or BP230) and this attaches to the transmembrane component protein BPAg2 (BP180) below.
  • The other hemidesmosomal protein Plectin is attached to the transmembrane component protein called as α6β4 integrin below.

2.ANCHORING FILAMENTS/Lamina Lucida and Lamina Densa

  • The anchoring filaments form the Lamina Lucida layer.
  • Anchoring filaments consist of Laminin5/332 proteins that connect BPAg2 and α6β4 integrin above to Lamina Densa below.
  • Lamina Densa consists mainly of type IV Collagen and other proteins like Nidogen.  

3.ANCHORING FIBRILS

  • These are ultrastructurally U shaped structures that attach the Lamina Densa above to the underlying connective tissue below in dermis.
  • Type VII Collagen is the major protein in anchoring fibrils.

Blistering disorders in the DEJ/BMZ arise due to defects or antibodies against any of the above mentioned proteins.

Image: Gene/protein systems within the cutaneous basement membrane zone that can harbour mutations and result in blistering of the skin in different forms of epidermolysis bullosa (EB). BP, bullous pemphigoid

questions.text: A middle-aged diabetic farmer presents with decreased vision, redness, blurring of the eye, photophobia and lacrimation in the right eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals the following finding with anterior chamber involvement. The ulcer scraping under microscopy revealed branched septate hyphae. Which of the following agents is preferred in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given scenario with the image depicting a corneal ulcer with feathery margins and thick hypopyon and the microscopic findings of branched, septate hyphae suggest mycotic keratitis caused by Aspergillus or Fusarium. The patient also has an anterior chamber extension. Thus the preferred treatment would be intrastromal voriconazole.

Mycotic or fungal keratitis is seen in tropical countries, rural areas, and immunocompromised individuals. It usually is caused by filamentous septate organisms such as Aspergillus, Fusarium, or yeasts such as Candida albicans.

They are characteristically seen after injury with vegetative matter like thorns or wooden sticks. Patients may present with pain, watering, and photophobia, but these are usually milder in comparison to bacterial ulcers. 

Some salient features that point toward the diagnosis of fungal corneal ulcers are:

  • Dry-looking ulcer with feathery irregular margins
  • Sterile circular corneal infiltrates - Wessely's immune ring due to the deposition of immune complexes. It is a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction
  • Satellite lesions
  • A thick, non-sterile hypopyon

 The image attached below shows the immune ring of Wessley.

The treatment usually consists of non-specific supportive treatment and specific treatment with antifungals. The non-specific treatment includes:

  • Atropine (1%) drops or ointment - it prevents complications like ciliary spasm posterior synechiae formation
  • Local heat

Specific treatment includes:

  • Topical drugs - 
    • Natamycin, voriconazole, and amphotericin B drops are effective against Aspergillus and Fusarium
    • Nystatin is effective against Candida
  • Systemic antifungal agents such as ketoconazole or voriconazole are given orally if the ulcers are severe with hypopyon, perforated or if endophthalmitis is suspected
  • In cases of suspected anterior chamber extensions, intracameral voriconazole can be given
  • Surgical treatment:
    • Removal of necrotic material by scraping with a spatula
    • Cauterization with pure carbolic acid or trichloracetic acid
    • Therapeutic keratoplasty 

Steroids are contraindicated in the treatment of fungal corneal ulcers because fungi which are usually symbiotic saprophytes under normal conditions become facultative pathogens in the presence of steroids and can cause perforation.

questions.text: A 5-month-old baby was brought to the hospital with poor feeding and abnormal twitching of his lower limb. On examination, the child was lethargic with fever and a bulging fontanelle.  CSF analysis revealed gram-stained microorganisms, neutrophilic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and reduced glucose concentrations. Which is the most common neurological sequel of this condition that can develop?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of poor feeding, fever, seizures, bulging fontanelle (due to raised ICP), lethargy with the mentioned CSF findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis, and sensorineural hearing loss is the most common sequelae which can develop in cases of bacterial meningitis. 

Hearing loss is a result of cochlear infection or direct inflammation of the auditory nerve. All patients with bacterial meningitis should undergo an audiological assessment before discharge from the hospital, or immediately after. Neurological sequelae of meningitis include:

  • Hearing loss (most common)
  • Cognitive impairment
  • Recurrent seizures
  • Delay in acquisition of language
  • Visual impairment
  • Behavioral problems

Bacterial meningitis may be caused due to Meningococcus, Streptococcus pneumoniae or Haemophilus influenzae type b. The non-specific symptoms and signs include fever, rash, lethargy, refusal to feed, vomiting, etc. Specific symptoms and signs such as photophobia, nuchal rigidity, bulging of the fontanel, and clinical signs of meningeal irritation (Kernig and Brudzinski signs), but is not usually seen in infants. Seizures and focal neurological signs may be present.

The diagnosis of meningitis is confirmed by CSF analysis which typically shows microorganisms on Gram stain and culture, a neutrophilic pleocytosis, increased protein and decreased glucose concentrations. Blood cultures should be done in all cases of suspected meningitis. 

Acute CNS complications include seizures, increased ICP, cranial nerve palsies, stroke, cerebral or cerebellar herniation, and thrombosis of the dural venous sinuses. Subdural effusions and non-communicating hydrocephalus may develop. Noncommunicating hydrocephalus is a known complication of meningitis.

questions.text: A patient presents with the following oral cavity finding as shown in the image below. He is a smoker. Despite various investigations, the given lesion does not fit under a particular diagnosis. You are planning for a laser-assisted surgical excision of this condition. Which of the following considerations about this procedure is false?

choices.text: You would prefer to use carbon dioxide laser for the given condition
As an operating surgeon you should be wearing amber colored low-power glasses
Oxygen concentration in inhaled gases should be kept low during this procedure
The patient's airway should be secured using a rubber-based cuffed endotracheal tube

questions.solution:
The given image with a white lesion of the tongue in a smoker that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease is suggestive of leukoplakia, a pre-malignant lesion of the oral cavity. The lesion is generally removed by using a carbon dioxide (CO2 laser) for which the surgeon should consider wearing plain protective glasses instead of preferring amber coloured glasses. Amber or yellow coloured glasses are preferred while using Argon or KTP lasers.

CO2 Laser:

  • It is considered as the 'Workhorse Laser' in the field of ENT
  • It cannot pass through flexible optical fibres
  • Ordinary glass or lenses of the microscope can also absorb the rays as well as the glasses worn by the operator.
  • It is absorbed by tissues high in water
  • It can cut precisely, coagulate bleeders and vaporize tissues.
  • Clinically it has been used in laryngeal surgery to excise vocal nodules, polyps, cysts, granulomas or juvenile laryngeal papillomas
  • It is also used for leukoplakia, T1 lesion of the vocal cord or localized lesions of supraepiglottis and infraepiglottis

Concerns while using LASER for surgery:

  • Educate all the staff
  • Protection of eyes of the operator by wearing glasses (Plain for CO2 lasers, amber for Argon or KTP lasers, and blue-green for ND-YAG lasers). The patient’s eye should be protected by a double layer of saline-soaked cotton eye pads
  • The airway should be secured by rubber-based or silicone-based cuffed ET tubes.
  • Choice of anaesthetic gases: Halothane or enflurane are used as they are noninflammable. Nitrous oxide, being oxidizing, is not used. Oxygen concentration in inhaled gases should be kept low (less than 40%) during this procedure
  • Avoid tube fires, be prepared for it and secure ventilation and systems to evacuate smoke.

Leukoplakia:

  • WHO defined leukoplakia as a clinical white patch that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia is caused by the Epstein Barr virus. Oral hairy leukoplakia is due to reactivation of Epstein Barr Virus (EBV) infection and usually occurs in association with immunodeficiency due to HIV infection.
  • Clinical Feature (OHL): HIV-infected patient presenting with white corrugated plaque over the lateral border of the tongue, which cannot be rubbed off. 
  • Leukoplakia is a premalignant condition of the oral cavity. The management includes the elimination of associated aetiological factors and biopsy of the lesion.
  • A photographic record of the lesion is useful for long-term follow-up.
  • Specific management includes surgical excision or ablation with laser or cryotherapy can be done.

Precautions taken before laser airway surgery-

  • Inspired oxygen concentration should be as low as possible

  • Airway checked and burning combustible material (eg, an ETT) should be removed
  • The fire should be extinguished with saline.

questions.text: All of the following are crosslinking fixatives except?
questions.solution:
Methanol is not a crosslinking fixative. It is a dehydrant coagulant fixative.

Fixation of tissues can be done by physical or chemical methods.

Physical methods include heating, microwaving, and freeze-drying.

Chemical methods: These methods are commonly used in the processing of tissue for various histopathological diagnoses. It includes the use of:

  • Cross-linking fixatives: These fixatives add covalent reactive groups which may induce cross-links between proteins, individual protein moieties within nucleic acids, and between nucleic acids and proteins. Eg: Formaldehyde and Glutaraldehyde.
  • Dehydrant coagulant fixatives: These fixatives remove free water from tissues and precipitate or coagulate the proteins. Eg: ethanol, methanol, and acetone.
  • Compound fixatives: Fixatives, which are the mixtures of reagents are referred to as compound fixatives. Eg: alcoholic formalin fixes tissues in two ways i.e firstly, by adding covalent hydroxymethyl groups and crosslinking proteins and secondly, by coagulation and dehydration.

Note: Osmium tetraoxide causes additive cross-links and is used for ultrastructural visualization of membranes as an additive for post-fixation after glutaraldehyde.

questions.text:
An elderly man presents with weakness in his lower limbs. On motor examination, the resident taps on the patellar tendon with a knee hammer and there was a sudden kicking movement of the knee. Which of the following is true about the given reflex?
  1. It is a monosynaptic stretch reflex
  2. Root value of the reflex is L5 - S2
  3. Glycine is the neurotransmitter 
  4. The afferent is carried via group Ia fibres from the muscle spindle
  5. Efferent is acted upon γ-motor neurons of the hamstring muscles
questions.solution:
From the given scenario, the resident is performing a knee jerk reflex (patellar reflex) on this patient. Statements 1 and 4 are correct about this reflex.

Knee jerk or patellar reflex is elicited by tapping the patellar tendon resulting in contraction of the quadriceps muscle. It is an example of a deep tendon reflex or myotatic stretch reflex as stretching the muscle causes reflex contraction. 

The reflex arc in the knee jerk reflex consists of only one synapse between afferents and efferents. Hence, it is also an example of a monosynaptic reflex. 

Reflex arc of knee jerk reflex -  

Tapping the tendon causes a stretch of the muscle spindle which is present within the muscle. The muscle spindle is a sensory proprioceptor responsible for identifying the length of the muscle fibers. The Ia afferent sensory fibers in the muscle spindles are activated in response to the stretch. These Ia afferent fibers go to the spinal cord at the dorsal root ganglia and stimulate the alpha-motor neurons. This results in the contraction of the muscle that was initially stretched. The neurotransmitter at the central synapse is glutamate.

The femoral nerve L2-L4 mediates the patellar reflex.

 

Clinical aspect: 

  • Brisk, hyperactive deep tendon reflexes are seen in upper motor neuron lesions affecting the descending spinal tracts like the corticospinal tract. 
  • Hypoactive or absent reflexes are seen in lower motor neuron lesions or the lesions affecting the components of the reflex arc. Absent reflexes can be seen in diabetes, deep sleep, coma, nerve block, spinal anesthesia etc. 
  • The pendular knee jerk, in which tapping the patellar tendon results in to-and-fro movements of the limb is seen in cerebellar lesions. The increased swinging occurs due to hypotonia of both flexors and extensors leading to a lack of restraint on each other.

questions.text:
Match the different types of chromatography to their respective prototype images.

a. Size-exclusion chromatography

b. Affinity chromatography

c. Paper chromatography

d. Ion-exchange chromatography
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-c, 2-d, 3-b, and 4-a.

Image 1 shows paper chromatography, which works on the principle of polarity. The least polar molecule moves faster.

Image 2 shows ion-exchange chromatography. Here, proteins interact with the stationary phase by charge-charge interactions. Glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) is best measured using ion-exchange chromatography.

Image 3 shows affinity chromatography, which works on the principle of specific ligand-binding behavior of proteins.

Image 4 shows size-exclusion chromatography, also known as gel filtration chromatography, separates the proteins based on their stokes radii. Stokes radius is a measure of the effective volume occupied by a protein as it rapidly tumbles in free solution. Stokes radius is thus a function of both molecular mass and shape.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man was found to have elevated cholesterol levels of 345 mg/dL on a routine checkup. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 42, and also had greatly elevated cholesterol levels throughout his life. The physician put the patient on lovastatin. After 2 weeks his cholesterol levels dropped to 170 mg/dL. The nature of the elevated cholesterol in this patient is most likely due to a mutation in which one of the following proteins?
questions.solution:
The patient most likely has familial hypercholesterolemia due to a mutated LDL receptor. This type of type II hypercholesterolemia is the most common form of familial dyslipidemia. 

Lovastatin is an inhibitor of HMG-CoA reductase. HMG-CoA reductase inhibitors cause cells to decrease the rate of cholesterol synthesis. Lower cellular levels of cholesterol cause a decreased conversion of cholesterol to cholesterol esters (by the ACAT reaction) for storage and increased production of LDL receptors. An increased number of receptors will cause more LDL to be taken up by cells from the circulation and degraded by lysosomes. Thus, blood cholesterol levels will decrease. Blood triacylglycerol levels will also decrease but not to a great extent because LDL contains only small amounts of triacylglycerol. Also, the patient most likely is heterozygous for a mutation in the LDL receptor. If the patient were homozygous for such a mutation, then lovastatin would not reduce circulating cholesterol levels, as there would be no functional LDL receptors to upregulate.

Other options:

  • Option A: The patient does not have a mutation in HMG-CoA reductase, as that is the target of lovastatin, and if an HMG-CoA reductase mutation were to reduce HMG-CoA reductase activity, then lovastatin would have little to no effect.
  • Option B: A mutation in protein kinase A, rendering it inactive, would not affect intracellular cholesterol synthesis (as it is the AMP-activated protein kinase that regulates the HMG-CoA reductase activity).
  • Option C: An inactivating mutation in ACAT (Acetyl-Coenzyme A acetyltransferase) would not lead to a reduction of circulating cholesterol in response to lovastatin as ACAT is important for esterification of the cholesterol to its other utilizable forms.
