questions.text: A 20-year old male patient who is a known case of pulmonary tuberculosis presents with backache. Examination reveals localized tenderness in the T12-L1 vertebral areas, loss of power in both lower limbs, and bladder incontinence. On x-ray, paradiscal destruction of vertebrae is present.  Which of the following is the best management for the above patient?
questions.solution:
This patient who is a known case of pulmonary tuberculosis presents with backache, localized tenderness in the T12-L1 vertebral areas, loss of power in both lower limbs, incontinence of his bladder, and paradiscal destruction of vertebrae seen on X-ray is likely to have Pott's paraplegia. Anterolateral decompression and antitubercular treatment are the best management for the above patient with Pott's paraplegia.

Paradiscal areas are the most common site of vertebral involvement. The other patterns include central, posterior, and non-osseous involvement. 

Management of Pott’s paraplegia includes conservative management or surgery. 

Anti-tubercular chemotherapy forms the mainstay of treatment. The spine is put to absolute rest by a sling traction for the cervical spine, and bed rest for the dorso- lumbar spine. If paraplegia improves, conservative treatment is continued. Bracing is continued for a period of about 6 to 12 months.

Surgery is indicated in the following conditions:

  • Failed conservative management
  • Recurrence of the disease after treatment
  • Rapid onset paraplegia

Surgeries for Pott’s paraplegia include:

  • Antero-lateral decompression- surgery of choice for Pott’s paraplegia as it helps in the removal of both solid and liquid debris
  • Costotransversectomy- surgery indicated for paravertebral abscess
  • Laminectomy- indicated when the posterior parts of vertebrae are involved
  • Radical debridement and arthrodesis (Hongkong operation)

questions.text: A  G2P1L1 woman at her 31st week of gestation comes for an antenatal checkup for the first time. On history, she remembers getting 2 tetanus shots during the antenatal period of the first pregnancy which was 2 years back. What action should be taken with regardsto tetanus immunization for this mother?

choices.text: Give a booster dose of Td
Give the first dose of Td now and the second dose before 36 weeks of gestation
Give tetanus antitoxin just before delivery

questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of a mother who has been immunized in the last pregnancy falling within the past three years, a booster dose of Td is given. 

Unimmunized pregnant women: Two doses of tetanus and adult Diphtheria (Td) should be given, the first as early as possible during pregnancy and the second at least a month later and at least 3 weeks before delivery. These doses may be given between 16-36 weeks of pregnancy.

Previously immunized pregnant women: A booster dose is considered sufficient as long as the patient has been immunized within the past 3 years. If the previous immunization was beyond three years, 2 doses of Td are administered 4 weeks apart. Ideally, Td-2 or booster doses are given before 36 weeks of pregnancy. Td is given to a woman in labor if she has not previously received Td.

The infants born to mothers who have not previously received 2 doses of tetanus toxoid have a high risk of neonatal tetanus. They can be protected by injection of antitoxin (heterologous serum, 750 IU) if it is administered within 6 hours of birth. 

Tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen (d) as recommended for older children and adults. The MoHFW recommends the replacement of TT vaccine with Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5 ml is administered in the intramuscular route in the upper arm.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the emergency room with seizures. On examination, the child is hypotonic and has hepatomegaly. Investigations reveal hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, elevated blood uric acid levels, and marked lactic acidosis. The infant is likely to be deficient in
questions.solution:
The clinical features of hypoglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, hyperuricemia and lactic acidosis are suggestive of von Gierke disease. It is due to the deficiency of glucose 6-phosphatase (type Ia) or glucose 6-phosphate translocase deficiency (type Ib).

Signs and symptoms include

  • Seizures
  • Doll-like facies (fat cheeks and relatively thin extremities)
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Growth retardation
  • Hypoglycemia 
  • Elevated blood uric acid levels 
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Elevated cholesterol and triglycerides
  • Neutropenia (specific to Ib)

Treatment of von Gierke includes

  • Maintenance of glucose levels by infusion of glucose or the use of uncooked cornstarch 
  • Mild to moderate restriction of lactose, fructose, and sucrose.
  • Ensure adequate intake of vitamins and minerals.
  • Allopurinol should be started for hyperuricemia if uncontrolled on dietary therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Liver glycogen phosphorylase deficiency leads to Hers disease (GSD VI). Patients usually present in early childhood with hepatomegaly and growth retardation. Lactic acid and uric acid levels are normal.

Option B: Phosphorylase kinase deficiency leads to Type IX GSD. Phosphorylase kinase is involved in the rate-limiting step of glycogenolysis. It presents in the first 2 years of life with short stature and hepatomegaly. Unlike GSD I, lactic acidosis, bleeding tendency, and loose bowel movements are not characteristic.

Option C: Liver glycogen synthase deficiency leads to Type 0 GSD. It presents in infancy with early-morning drowsiness, pallor, vomiting, fatigue, and sometimes convulsions. Hypoglycemia, hyperketonemia, and low lactate levels are seen. There is no hyperlipidemia or hepatomegaly.

questions.text: A woman delivers a baby at the primary health center. While examining the baby, you notice a foot deformity as shown in the image below. Screening for other defects and early cost-free intervention for this condition is covered under which of the following schemes?
questions.solution:
The condition seen in the given image is clubfoot (congenital talipes equinovarus or CTEV). Screening of this birth defect and early intervention are covered under the Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram scheme.

Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) is an important initiative aiming at early identification and early intervention for children from birth to 18 years to cover 4 ‘D’s which are:

  • Defects at birth
  • Deficiencies
  • Diseases
  • Development delays, including disability.

The first level of screening is done by medical officers, staff nurses, and ANMs, at all the places where deliveries are conducted. After 48 hours, up to 6 weeks, the screening of newborns will be done by ASHA at home as a part of the Home Based New-born Care (HBNC) package.

The target groups are divided into three groups based on age:

  • Newborn to 6 weeks
  • 6 weeks to 6 years
  • 6 years to 18 years.

They screen all the babies born at public health facilities and at home, preschool children in rural areas and urban slums, and children up to 12th grade enrolled in government schools.

Defects screened during birth :

  • Neural tube defect 
  • Down's Syndrome 
  • Cleft Lip & Palate / Cleft palate alone
  • Talipes (club foot)
  • Developmental dysplasia of the hip
  • Congenital cataract
  • Congenital deafness
  • Congenital heart diseases
  • Retinopathy of Prematurity

Other options :

Option B: Navjat Shishu Suraksha Karyakram: NSSK is a program aimed to train health personnel in basic newborn care and resuscitation, has been launched to address care at birth issues i.e. prevention of hypothermia, prevention of infection, early initiation of breastfeeding, and basic newborn resuscitation.

Option C: Janani Sishu Suraksha Karyakaram: It is an initiative to provide completely free and cashless services to pregnant women including normal deliveries and cesarean operations and sick newborns (up to 30 days after birth) in Government health institutions in both rural & urban areas.

Option D: Pradhan Mantri Surakshit Matritva Abhiyan: This program aims to provide assured, comprehensive, and quality antenatal care, free of cost, to all pregnant women on the 9th of every month.

questions.text: An orthopedic surgeon is taking a class on various tendon repair surgeries, by using cadaveric specimens. questions.text: Sophia, a 45-year-old female patient presents to the surgery OPD with a 2-day history of right upper quadrant pain, dyspnea, non-productive cough, fever with chills and rigors. On probing further, she stated that the pain radiates to the right shoulder tip. Her past history is significant for a surgical repair of a perforated duodenal ulcer 3 weeks back. Physical examination reveals a temperature of 40° C and HR of 110/min. Abdominal examination reveals acute tenderness over the right hypochondriac region. A chest X-ray was ordered and the findings are shown below. What is the next best management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with CXR pointing towards right-sided pleural effusion is suggestive of the post-operative right sub-phrenic abscess. The preferred treatment of choice is CT guided percutaneous drainage.

The chest X-ray shows obliteration of right costophrenic angle with a wide pleural based dome-shaped opacity projecting into the lung noted tracking along the CP angle and lateral chest wall. 

Right subphrenic abscess:

  • This space lies between the right lobe of the liver and the diaphragm. It is limited posteriorly by the anterior layer of the coronary and the right triangular ligaments, and to the left by the falciform ligament.
  • Common causes of abscess here are perforating cholecystitis, a perforated duodenal ulcer and a duodenal cap ‘blow-out’ following gastrectomy and appendicitis.

Clinical features:

  • Barnard’s aphorism: “Pus somewhere, pus nowhere else, pus under diaphragm”.
  • Swinging fever with chills and rigors.
  • Pain in right hypochondrium, epigastrium or lower thorax.
  • Tenderness in right hypochondrium.
  • Sympathetic right-sided pleural effusion due to congestion and hyperaemia of the diaphragm.
  • The collapse of the lung/basal atelectasis
  • Tachypnoea and respiratory distress can be observed.
  • Pain in the right shoulder due to irritation of the phrenic nerve manifesting as hiccough, tachycardia.
  • Hoover’s sign: Scoliosis towards the same side in a subphrenic abscess.
  • Occasionally tender mass in the right hypochondrium may be palpable.
  • Tenderness over the 11th intercostal space may be evident in right subhepatic space abscess. 
  • Pfuhl sign: A clinical sign which helps in differentiating between subphrenic abscess and pyopneumothorax. Inspiration increases the force of flow in paracentesis in subphrenic abscess but lessens in the case of pyopneumothorax.

Investigations:

  • Chest X-ray - to appreciate pleural effusion and lung atelectasis
  • Blood panel - elevated leukocytes and CRP
  • USG abdomen - to delineate the infected space
  • CT scan - preferred investigation of choice
  • WBC labelled isotope scans - rarely done

Treatment:

  • Antibiotic coverage
  • Definitive management - Percutaneous CT guided drainage with drain insertion. Preferred catheters - Malecots, Pigtail, 16F trochar catheter and sump catheter.
  • Aspiration alone is never done. 
  • Open dissection and drainage (Option-C) is indicated only when primary treatment fails or there is an associated foreign body or presence of multiple abscesses.
  • Pleurectomy (Option-B) is never indicated for benign pleural effusions.

The image attached below demonstrates various intra-abdominal surgical space infections. 

 

(Option-A) Kehr's T tube is used after the exploration of the common bile duct i.e. horizontal limb is placed in the common bile duct and a vertical limb is brought out like a drain. It allows bile to drain while the sphincter of Oddi is in spasm postoperatively. Once the sphincter relaxes, bile drains normally down the bile duct and into the duodenum.

The images attached below show the tube and the insertion.

Prominent y descent and absent x descent
Accentuated v wave and rapid y descent
Absent v wave with rapid x descent

questions.solution:
The above features are suggestive of cardiac tamponade and the jugular venous pressure (JVP) tracing of the patient will have a prominent x descent but an absent y descent.

Cardiac tamponade is the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space. It will result in the obstruction of the blood flow into the ventricles. Patients present with a triad of hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds and raised JVP (Beck's triad). In JVP, there is a prominent x descent but an absent y descent. 

Another feature found in this is a paradoxical pulse. Normally the blood pressure falls during inspiration. But this fall is not more than 10mm of Hg. However, in the pulses paradoxus, the fall in blood pressure during inspiration is more than 10 mm Hg. This is called a paradoxical pulse. The mechanism for this is as follows: due to cardiac tamponade, the ventricles are now covered in a tight incompressible covering. During inspiration, there is an increase in the volume of the right ventricle. Since this ventricle cannot expand, it pushes the interventricular septum to the left causing decreased volume in the left ventricle. This in turn results in reduced stroke volume and arterial systolic pressure.

It is diagnosed using echocardiography. As soon as the condition is diagnosed, pericardiocentesis should be carried out.

 

Other important conditions and their JVP tracings are

  • Constrictive pericarditis will have prominent y descent, prominent x descent. Kussmal sign is associated with constrictive pericarditis and is characterized by increased fall in JVP during inspiration.

 

  • Atrioventricular dissociation will have cannon a waves

 

  • Atrial fibrillation will have absent a wave

 

  • Tricuspid regurgitation will have accentuated v wave with rapid y descent

 

  • Tricuspid stenosis will have prolonged y wave

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

questions.text: An 82-year-old man presents to the ER with fever and tachycardia since last night. On examination, he is drowsy, his BP is 92/54 mmHg and his temperature is 103 °F. His wife tells you he had been diagnosed with a urinary tract infection 5 days ago for which he had been prescribed antibiotics. He is a known case of colon cancer and also has a history of myocardial infarction 6 months ago. What type of shock is he likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of septic shock as a result of gram-negative sepsis originating from a urinary tract infection.

Gram-negative organisms contain lipopolysaccharide in the outer membrane, which triggers the release of cytokines, such as tumor necrosis factor (TNF). These cytokines cause a cascade of events culminating in increased capillary permeability and redistribution of circulatory volume into the interstitium. It is also known as warm shock, due to fever and increased perfusion.

Other types of shock are:

  • Anaphylactic shock - sudden circulatory collapse due to type I hypersensitivity reaction
  • Cardiogenic shock - ventricular failure, often following myocardial infarction; is a form of cold shock
  • Hypovolemic shock - due to blood or fluid loss

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman was found to have complex endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. How would you consider treating this patient?

choices.text: Progesterone therapy and endometrial biopsy every 6 months
Progesterone therapy only for a duration of  2 years

questions.solution:
Progesterone therapy followed by endometrial biopsy every 3 to 6 months is the best treatment in the above case.

Endometrial hyperplasia is defined as endometrial thickening with the proliferation of irregularly sized and shaped glands and an increased gland-to-stroma ratio. It is a pre-malignant lesion for endometrial carcinoma.

WHO Classification of endometrial hyperplasia based on histology:

  • Simple without atypia: there is an increase in number of glands but the architecture is not compromised. 
  • Simple with atypia: simple hyperplasia with features of nuclear atypia (variation in nuclear shape, size, and prominent nucleoli)
  • Complex without atypia: glands are markedly crowded and irregular
  • Complex with atypia: complex hyperplasia with atypical nuclear features. 

However, there is generally no clear histological distinction between the above mentioned classification, so endometrial hyperplasia is classified into hyperplasia without atypia and atypical hyperplasia/endometrioid intraepithelial neoplasia. 

Type of hyperplasia Risk of progression to cancer
Simple without atypia 1%
Complex without atypia 3%
Simple with atypia 8%
Complex with atypia 29%

Management of Endometrial hyperplasia:

1) Hyperplasia without atypia:

Intrauterine or continuous oral progesterone. Levonorgestrel releasing intrauterine system is preferred due to its lower side effect profile, higher rate of disease resolution. Oral progesterone can be given in the form of medroxyprogesterone acetate 10-20 mg/day. 

Endometrial surveillance in the form of biopsy should be performed at 6-month intervals. At least 2 consecutive negative biopsies should be obtained. Those at high risk (body mass index of more than 35, treated with oral progesterone) should be advised annual follow-up. 

2) Atypical hyperplasia:

Total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is suggested in those with atypical hyperplasia due to the risk of progression to malignancy. 

Premenopausal women who want to preserve their fertility should be counseled regarding the risk of progression to cancer. Once fertility is no longer required, then hysterectomy should be offered. 

Those who refuse hysterectomy should have routine endometrial biopsies every 3 months until 2 consecutive negative biopsies are obtained.

questions.text: A patient presents with ptosis and restricted ocular movements that have gotten progressively worse over a period of time. There is no exacerbation or remission. Initially, the upgaze was involved with subsequent lateral gaze involvement. The patient does not complain of diplopia and the pupils are not involved. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The classical presentation of ptosis with progressively declining ocular movement is characteristic of chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia (CPEO).

CPEO may occur in isolation, in association with Kearns-Sayre syndrome (mitochondrial myopathy associated with mitochondrial DNA deletions), or oculopharyngeal dystrophy.

Isolated CPEO usually presents with bilateral ptosis as the first sign. It may be asymmetrical. It usually begins in young adulthood and is typically characterized by a progressive course without remission or exacerbation. At first, only the upgaze is involved, and later, the lateral gaze is also affected. Since the loss of eye movement is symmetrical, diplopia is rare. Pupils are not involved.

Electromyography shows myotonic and myopathic potentials and serum creatine kinase is elevated.

Treatment involves exercise and the prevention of contractures. A minority of patients with diplopia may benefit from surgery.

Other options:

Options A and D- In cranial nerve palsies, there would be associated diplopia.

Option C- In ocular myasthenia gravis, diplopia is very commonly seen.

questions.text: The parents of 6-year-old Ramya were informed that she does not speak at all in school. Her parents are surprised as she seemed completely normal at home and spoke normally. Which of the following features are not likely to be associated with this case?

choices.text: It is related to social anxiety disorder
No risk of delay in language acquisition
Cognitive behavioral therapy is the first-line treatment

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a lack of speaking in a child in a social situation, like the school setting, while being normal at home, and thus points towards a diagnosis of selective mutism. It is associated with an increased risk for delayed speech and language acquisition.

Selective mutism refers to the persistent lack of speaking (being mute) in one or more specific social situations. The child is able to speak well in other situations, for example at home. It is related to social anxiety disorder.

Younger children are more likely to develop selective mutism, and it is seen more in girls than boys. Maternal overprotection and anxiety disorders in parents may exacerbate the condition. Some children may develop selective mutism after emotional or physical trauma.

Selectively mute children may have an increased risk for delayed speech and language acquisition and disturbances in auditory processing. However, speech and language problems in children with selective mutism are subtle and are not accountable for the diagnosis of selective mutism. They may also exhibit behavioral disturbances, like temper tan­trums and oppositional behavior at home. They may have symptoms of separation anxi­ety and school refusal.

The diagnosis can be made when a child has clear communication skills but is silent in one or more social situations, like in school. Rarely, a child may be silent at home but communicates normally at school.

Cognitive behavioral therapy is the first-line treatment recommended for school-going children with selective mutism. Treatment also involves psychoeducation for the family. Evidence also suggests that SSRIs such as fluoxetine can have beneficial effects in children with selective mutism, similar to social phobia.

questions.text: A pharmacologist is conducting a study on non-microsomal phase 2 reactions involved in drug metabolism. His experiments are not likely to include which of the following conjugation reactions?
questions.solution:
All of the above conjugation reactions are catalyzed by non-microsomal enzymes except glucuronide conjugation.

Glucuronide conjugation is the only phase II metabolic reaction that is carried out by microsomal enzymes. 

Drug metabolizing enzymes are primarily of two types:

  1. Microsomal enzymes are located in the smooth endoplasmic reticulum in the liver, kidney, intestinal mucosa, and lungs. They include the cytochrome P450 system, monooxygenases, etc. These enzymes can be induced by drugs and certain nutrients. These enzymes are involved in oxidation, reduction, hydrolysis, and glucuronide conjugation reactions.
  2. Non-microsomal enzymes are located in the cytoplasm and mitochondria of hepatic cells, plasma and other tissues. They include esterases, amidases and most conjugases. These enzymes catalyze all conjugation reactions except glucuronidation. Phase II reactions carried out by non-microsomal enzymes are:
  • Glycine conjugation
  • Glutathione conjugation
  • Sulfate conjugation
  • Methylation
  • Acetylation

Related Pearl: Phases of drug metabolism

Phase I reactions: They attach functional groups to the drugs. This usually leads to the inactivation of the drug. 

Examples:

  • Oxidation
  • Reduction
  • Hydrolysis
  • Cyclisation
  • Deamination

Phase II reactions: They attach conjugates to the drugs. This facilitates drug elimination from the tissue. 

Examples:

  • Glucuronide conjugation
  • Sulfate conjugation
  • Glycine conjugation
  • Glutathione conjugation
  • Acetylation
  • Methylation

All phase II reactions are mainly conducted by the non-microsomal enzymes except glucuronidation.

questions.text: A couple who are expecting their first child comes to the hospital for a routine antenatal checkup. The father raises concerns about a disease he fears his child would inherit from him. Upon further history-taking, it is found that the father's mother had also suffered from this condition. There is no history of this disease in the mother's side of the family. The doctor says that the baby will not inherit the disease as long as it is a boy baby. Which disease is it most likely to be?
questions.solution:
The inheritance pattern is highly suggestive of X-linked dominant disorder which follows a mendelian inheritance pattern. Vitamin - D resistant rickets is an X-linked dominant condition which is caused by dominant disease-associated alleles on the X chromosome.

Inheritance pattern :

These disorders are transmitted by an affected heterozygous female to half her sons and half her daughters and by an affected male parent to all his daughters but none of his sons if the female parent is unaffected.

X-linked dominant disorders:

  • Rett's syndrome
  • Vitamin D resistant rickets
  • Alport syndrome (common inheritance pattern)
  • Type X Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease

Other options :

Hereditary spherocytosis - This disease follows the autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance

Leber hereditary optic neuropathy - This disease follows a non-mendelian/non-classical pattern of inheritance. It is a mitochondrial disorder.

Fragile X syndrome - This is a disease caused by trinucleotide repeat mutation.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presented with chest pain and breathlessness which was found to be due to a tumor located in the left anterior apex of the thoracic inlet. The imaging modality shown showed a high uptake within the tumor. Choose the incorrect statements about it.
  1. It is a cancer-specific study
  2. Anatomically more accurate than conventional CT
  3. Smaller lesions are often detected earlier than with conventional CT 
  4. When coupled with CT, it is highly sensitive and specific for staging cancer
  5. It does not show the functional activity of cells after treatment
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 5 are incorrect. The clinical vignette is suggestive of a Pancoast tumor, and the imaging modality shown is an FDG PET-CT scan.

PET imaging with fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) is used to evaluate the presence of known or occult metastases, based on the differential increased glucose metabolism by cancer cells compared with normal cells. However, a PET scan is not a cancer-specific study, since high cellular glucose metabolism is seen in inflammation and reactive hyperplasia.

Fused PET/CT imaging provides information on FDG metabolic activity along with the anatomical detailing of CT. Anatomical localization can be difficult using isolated PET, but the hybrid systems FDG PET CT provide not only accurate localization but also information that aids in diagnosis.

On FDG PET CT, since the metabolic activity that is seen in FDG PET is anatomically mapped on a CT, anatomically both are equally accurate.

FDG-PET scan is not a consistent diagnostic test for lung cancer. FDG-PET coupled with CT is highly sensitive and specific in determining the stage of lung cancer prior to treatment. 

Smaller lesions can be detected earlier using PET CT, as increased glucose metabolism of cancer cells within lymph nodes can be detected before the size of the lesion exceeds the threshold to be seen as abnormal on CT. Similarly, after treatment, the functional activity of cells may be seen as normal on PET earlier than the anatomical abnormalities have resolved.

Previously, MRI was considered as the optimal study for demonstrating the extent of Pancoast’s tumor, reliably diagnosing mediastinal invasion, extension into the root of the neck, and involvement of neurovascular structures.

Pancoast syndrome/superior sulcus tumor results from a local extension of a tumor growing in the apex of the lung, with the involvement of C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots. Regional spread can cause:

  • Tracheal obstruction,
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis).

questions.text: All of the following can be used for the treatment of PCOD except?
questions.solution:
Ulipristal is not used for the treatment of polycystic ovarian disease (PCOD). It is a synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator used as an emergency contraceptive pill.

PCOD is a complex multisystemic endocrine disorder affecting women of reproductive age. 

Rotterdam criteria is used to diagnose PCOD. The presence of two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis.

  • Oligo/amenorrhoea, anovulation, infertility
  • Hirsutism/acne
  • Ultrasound findings:
    • Enlarged ovaries with ovarian volume will be more than 10 mL
    • 12 or more small follicles each of 2-9 mm in size placed peripherally

Clomiphene (option A) is a selective estrogen receptor modulator that is used as the first line of treatment in managing infertility. Clomiphene with dexamethasone improves the fertility rate. In resistant cases, tamoxifen or letrozole (an aromatase inhibitor) (option B) can be tried. 

Surgical management of PCOD includes laparoscopic ovarian drilling (option D). Indications of surgery are:

  • Failed medical therapy
  • Hyperstimulation occurs
  • Infertile women
  • Previous pregnancy losses

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient presents with complaints of double vision. She has noticed that as the day progresses her visual disturbance increases and is maximum when she is reading her book at night. Additionally, she has had trouble swallowing chunks of meat for the past few days. She does not have any lower limb weakness. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals normal deep tendon reflexes and mild bilateral drooping eyelids. Placing an ice pack over her eyes significantly decreases the eyelid drooping. Burke's assessment of levator palpebrae superioris muscle function reveals poor levator function. Further ocular examination reveals the following signs A and B as shown in the gif attached below. Which of the following is the best surgical procedure that you would advise for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of ocular myasthenia leading to acquired myogenic ptosis. The best surgery for a patient with poor LPS function is frontalis sling suspension. Gif A shows the Cogan twitch sign, a  brief upshoot of the eyelid as the eyes saccade from depression to the primary position and gif B shows Simpson's test, after sustained elevation the affected eyelid becomes fatigued. 

Approach to this question:

Drooping of eyelids in a middle-aged woman with a progressive muscular weakness towards the end of the day goes more in favour of myogenic ptosis. A positive ice pack test, Cogan twitch sign (gif A) narrow down the diagnosis to myasthenia gravis. Additionally, a positive Simpsons test (gif B) indicate poor LPS function which is seconded by Burke's assessment revealing poor LPS function in this case. 

  • Generally, for patients for any cause of acquired ptosis other than Horner's syndrome with moderate ptosis (2 - 4mm), the preferred surgery is levator resection. This can be done either by the conjunctival approach (Blaskowic's approach) or by the skin approach (Everbushc's operation). 
  • The patient, in this case, has very poor LPS function, in such cases of severe ptosis (>4mm) or LPS function (poor <4mm) the preferred surgery is Brow approach based frontalis sling suspension

Note:

Horner's syndrome - mild ptosis (<2mm), the preferred surgery is Tarso-conjunctivo-Mullerectomy (Fasanella-Servat operation)

 

Ocular myasthenia: A disease characterized by generalized muscle weakness and rapidly developing fatigue of the muscles due to auto-immune damage of the acetylcholine receptors that take place at the post-synaptic membrane. The symptoms fluctuate and, after a short rest, recovery follows rapidly in the early stages.

  • If weakness remains restricted to the EOMs for 3 years, it is likely that it will not become generalized, and these patients are said to have ocular MG.
  • Ocular involvement occurs in 90% of cases and is the presenting feature in 60%. Two-thirds of patients have both ptosis and diplopia.
  • Ptosis is insidious, bilateral and frequently asymmetrical. Typically worse at the end of the day and worse on prolonged (60 second) upgaze due to fatigue.
  • Ptosis and convergence insufficiency are early and prominent features.
  • Cogan twitch sign is a brief upshoot of the eyelid as the eyes saccade from depression to the primary position. If one eyelid is elevated manually as the patient looks up, the fellow eyelid may show fine oscillatory movements. Get the patient to rapidly re-fixate their eye from downgaze to the primary position, the sign is positive if there is overshooting of the upper lid before settling down to the ptotic position 
  • Diplopia is frequently vertical, although any or all of the extraocular muscles may be affected. A pseudo-internuclear ophthalmoplegia may be seen. Patients with stable deviations may benefit from muscle surgery, botulinum toxin injection, or a combination of both.
  • Nystagmoid movements may be present on the extremes of gaze more for lateral gaze in the abducting eye.

Examinations:

Burke's test: It is determined by lid excursion. The patient is asked to look down and the thumb of one hand is placed firmly against the eyebrow of the patient. This will help block the action of the frontalis muscle. When the patient looks up, the upper lid excursion is measured using a ruler. Levator function is graded as follows:

  • Normal: 15mm
  • Good:8mm or more
  • Fair: 5 to 7 mm
  • Severe/Poor: 4mm or less

The special test required:

  • Ice pack test: If a patient has ptosis, application of a pack of ice over a ptotic eye often results in improvement if the ptosis is due to an NMJ defect. 
  • Tensilon test: A remarkable temporary improvement in the action of the muscles is obtained by injections of Prostigmin or edrophonium intravenously which lead to acetylcholine accumulation.
  • Simpson test: Ask the patient to keep his eyelids elevated. A positive test is one in which the affected eyelid gets fatigued easily and this is observed on the sustained lid and eye elevation.
  • The single most sensitive test for Myasthenia Gravis - Single fibre Electromyography
  • The single most specific test for Myasthenia Gravis - AChR antibodies

The image attached below shows ptosis before and after tensilon test in a patient with myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: On finding a congenital heart block in a fetus, which of the following conditions would you evaluate for in the mother?
questions.solution:
On finding a congenital heart block in the fetus, the mother should be evaluated for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

Fetal and neonatal heart blocks occur due to myocarditis and fibrosis in the region between the AV node and the bundle of His. Congenital heart block primarily develops in fetuses of women with antibodies to the SS-A or SS-B antigens, and up to 50 percent of women with SLE test positive for these antibodies. So in pregnancies with either of these antibodies, fetal cardiac monitoring is performed between 18 and 26 weeks of gestation.

The cardiac lesion is permanent, and in most cases, a pacemaker is required. Maternal hydroxychloroquine therapy is associated with a reduced incidence of fetal heart block, particularly in women who have previously had an affected child.

Neonatal lupus erythematosus is thought to be caused by the transplacental passage of maternal antibodies. It is characterized by skin lesions known as lupus dermatitis in newborns, as well as various hematological and systemic abnormalities. In some cases, congenital heart block may also occur. Thrombocytopenia and hepatic involvement are also seen. 

The most common cutaneous finding in neonatal lupus erythematosus is an erythematous, slightly scaly eruption on the face and periorbital skin (raccoon sign/owl eye/eye mask). The eruption can be exacerbated by UV exposure. The rash improves over the first few months of life and usually resolves without scarring by 12 months of age.

Avoidance of sunlight should be advised and low‐potency topical steroids may be of benefit.

The pregnancy outcomes are best in women with:

  •  Dormant lupus activity for at least 6 months before conception
  •  No lupus nephritis manifestation in the form of proteinuria or renal dysfunction
  •  Absent anti-phospholipid syndrome or lupus anticoagulant 
  •  Superimposed preeclampsia does not develop

questions.text: While taking ward rounds, you come across the ECG of a patient which looks as given below. Which of the following can cause such an ECG?
questions.solution:
In the above ECG, there is a depression of the ST segment, a decrease in the amplitude of the T wave, a slightly prolonged PR interval, and an increase in the amplitude of U waves which occur at the end of the T wave. These are the findings of hypokalemia, which can be seen when giving insulin infusion due to the intracellular shift of potassium. 

Hypokalemia can also cause premature atrial and ventricular beats, sinus bradycardia, paroxysmal atrial or junctional tachycardia, atrioventricular block, and ventricular tachycardia or fibrillation.

Other options:

Option A: Vit A can cause hypercalcemia. It will show a shortening of the QT interval and a decrease in the ST segment duration in ECG. 

Option B: Bisphosphonate overdose is associated with hypocalcemia. It shows prolongation of the QT interval due to lengthening of the ST segment. The QT interval prolongation is proportional to the degree of hypocalcemia. The T wave (which correlates with the time for repolarization) remains unaltered.

Below image shows prolonged QT interval in hypocalcemia

Option C: ACE inhibitors cause hyperkalemia.

ECG changes in hyperkalemia. Different changes are seen according to the levels of potassium.

  • Tall peaked T waves are present when the serum potassium levels are 5.5–6.5 mmol/L. 
  • Loss of P waves are seen when the concentration is between 6.5–7.5 mmol/L.
  • Widened QRS complex is seen when the concentration is between 7.0–8.0 mmol/L
  • Sine wave pattern when concentration is >8.0 mmol/L

Below ECG- hyperkalemia

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presented with low mood, loss of appetite, and sleep disturbances that began a month ago. She has been in good health and has no significant past or psychiatric history. Two months ago, her son was diagnosed with Hodgkin's lymphoma. She is able to carry out her daily activities and still cherishes time with her son. Which among the following is true about the prognosis of this condition?

choices.text: Most patients do not return to their previous level of functioning
Adults are more likely to improve sooner than adolescents
Suicidal risk is not a concern in these patients
Pharmacotherapy is preferred over psychotherapy for this condition.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with low mood, loss of appetite, and sleep disturbances occurring within 3 months of a stressful event (Son's lymphoma diagnosis) is suggestive of an adjustment disorder. Adults recover sooner than adolescents.

Adjustment disorder is an emotional response to a stressful event such as the loss of a job, divorce, moving to a new environment, financial problems, medical illnesses, or the death of a loved one. 

With appropriate treatment, the prognosis of an adjust­ment disorder is good. Most patients are able to return to their previous level of functioning within 3 months. Adolescents usually require a longer time to recover than adults and may develop mood disorders or substance­ related disorders in the future.

The suicidal risk is found to be higher in patients with chronic adjustment disorder with depressive symptoms, associated substance-related disorders in those with previous suicide attempts. The highest risk is seen in adolescent patients.

Diagnosing criteria for adjustment disorder include:

  • Development of emotional or behavioral response within 3 months of the onset of the stressor.
  • The symptoms or behavior are clinically significant, where, any one of the following are met:
    • The response is out of proportion to the severity or intensity of the stressor.
    • Significant impairment in social, occupational, or other areas of functioning.
  • Stress-related disturbance does not meet the criteria for another mental disorder or exacerbation of pre-existing mental disorder.
  • The symptoms do not represent normal bereavement.
  • Once the stressor is terminated, the symptoms do not persist for more than 6 additional months.

The mainstay of treatment is psychotherapy. Pharmacotherapy is not commonly used, however it is reasonable to use medications for specific symptoms for a brief period of time.

questions.text: Identify the structures which consist of commissural fibres:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is A, B, and C only.

The structure marked as 'D' is the body of the fornix and it mainly contains association fibres. The commissure of the fornix (hippocampal commissure) contains the commissural fibers. 

A- Corpus callosum

B- Anterior commissure

C- Posterior commissure

D- Body of the Fornix

The locations of the commissural fibers are:

  • Corpus callosum- Medial surface of the brain
  • Anterior commissure- Beneath the rostrum of the corpus callosum
  • Posterior commissure- In the inferior lamina of the pineal gland
  • Habenular commissure- In the superior lamina of the pineal gland
  • Hippocampal commissure- Between the right fornix and the left fornix 

(Note: Varied information regarding the fibers present in the Fornix. 41st edition Gray's Clinical anatomy mentions Fornix under association fibers, the commissure of the fornix under commissural fibers. Whereas, Snell's Neuroanatomy textbook mentions the Fornix under commissural fibers.) 

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: A myasthenia patient came with recurrent urinary tract infections. The urine culture report is positive for Klebsiella with microbial susceptibility to the drugs given below. Which of the following drugs would have the least adverse effect on the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario of a myasthenic patient with recurrent UTI due to Klebsiella, gentamicin is the preferred drug among the given options because it has the least effect on neuromuscular blockade.

Aminoglycosides accentuate the neuromuscular blockade by decreasing the pre-junctional release of acetylcholine and reducing post-junctional acetylcholine sensitivity. Acute neuromuscular blockade and apnea are seen with the use of aminoglycoside. Patients with myasthenia gravis are susceptible.

Decreasing order of potency for neuromuscular blockade:

  • Neomycin: Highest
  • Kanamycin
  • Amikacin
  • Gentamicin
  • Tobramycin

Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disorder that is characterized by weakness and the fatigability of skeletal muscles. It is due to the autoantibody-mediated destruction of the acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the neuromuscular junction. This consequentially leads to a decreased transmission at the neuromuscular (myoneural) junction. Reflexes are normal in Myasthenia gravis.

Clinical features of myasthenia gravis:

  • Weakness increases during repeated use or late in the day and may improve following rest or sleep.
  • Cranial muscles particularly the lids and extraocular muscles are involved early in the course - diplopia, ptosis
  • Facial weakness - snarling expression on smiling
  • Weakness in chewing
  • Speech with nasal timbre due to the weakness of palate and tongue
  • Difficulty in swallowing
  • Bulbar weakness
  • Limb weakness is proximal and asymmetric
  • Deep tendon reflexes are preserved

In about 30% of the patients, thymic hyperplasia is closely associated with myasthenia gravis, and about 10% have thymoma. The thymus normally contains small numbers of myoid cells, stromal cells that express skeletal muscle antigens. In both thymoma and thymic hyperplasia, the normal thymic function is disrupted leading to autoimmunity against ACh receptors expressed on thymic myoid cells. Thymectomy is often an effective treatment for these patients.

Ice-pack test - ice pack improves ptosis (decreases the activity of acetylcholinesterase, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft). Edrophonium chloride (Tensilon test) - edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft

Diagnosis is made by AChR antibodies, MuSK antibodies, LRP4 antibodies, single-fiber electromyography, repetitive nerve stimulation. Pyridostigmine, azathioprine, and thymectomy are the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text:
During a biochemical screening, an obstetrician identifies that a woman is carrying a fetus with trisomy 18. Which of the following markers would likely be low in this screening test?

1. Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein
2. Beta human chorionic gonadotropin
3. Unconjugated estriol
4. Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1, 2, 3, and 4. All of the above-given findings are decreased in trisomy 18 (Edward's syndrome). Maternal serum AFP, beta hCG, unconjugated estriol, and pregnancy-associated plasma protein A levels are reduced.

Combined first-trimester screening tests: It is performed between 11 and 14 weeks gestation. It comprises of:

  • Human chorionic gonad­otropin (hCG)
  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A)
  • Sonographic measurement of the nuchal translucency (NT)

The abnormalities seen on the triple screen are tabulated below:

 Parameter Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal

Quadruple testing is done in the second trimester between 15-21 weeks of gestation. It comprises:

  • Maternal serum AFP
  • Human chorionic gonadotropin
  • Unconjugated estriol
  • Inhibin A

Trisomy 18 or Edwards’ syndrome is a condition characterised by intellectual disability, micrognathia, low-set ears, rocker-bottom feet, and congenital heart diseases. The most characteristic finding is a clenched fist with overlapping fingers i.e. the index finger overlies the third and fourth fingers, while the fifth finger overlaps the fourth. This syndrome is also associated with polyhydramnios and a single umbilical artery.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man who is a known diabetic and hypertensive comes to the casualty ward with chest pain radiating to the left arm. ECG shows ST elevation. On thrombolytic therapy, the patient's condition becomes worse, and he develops arrhythmia. Which of the following is true about the mechanism of cell death due to the reperfusion of ischemic tissue?
  1. There is a calcium efflux.
  2. Both intrinsic and extrinsic pathways are seen.
  3. There is a failure to activate caspase 8.
  4. There is a loss of ATP.
  5. There is no generation of reactive nitrogen species.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of reperfusion injury seen in a patient treated for MI, where cell death occurs following the pathway of necroptosis. Statements 3 and 4 are true about the mechanism of necroptosis.

Necroptosis starts as apoptosis, fails to activate caspase, and ends like necrosis, hence the name. It is referred to as "caspase-independent” programmed cell death.

Necroptosis is programmed cell death without caspase activation. As there is no caspase activation, only one pathway is seen in necroptosis. The process of necroptosis starts in a manner similar to that of the extrinsic form of apoptosis by ligation of a receptor by its ligand. It can be both physiological and pathological. 

Examples

  • Pathological: Cell death in steatohepatitis, acute pancreatitis, ischemia-reperfusion injury, neurodegenerative diseases like Parkinson's disease, and viral infections
  • Physiological: Formation of the mammalian bone growth plate

Mechanism:

  • TNF-α activates TNFR1 and, in turn, induces the recruitment of RIP1 and RIP3 kinase and other proteins to form a complex.
  • This complex includes caspase 8. But, caspase 8 is not activated in this pathway.
  • This leads to the formation of a necrosome which causes metabolic alterations leading to a loss of ATP and generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and nitrogen species.
  • Acute ischemia causes intracellular and mitochondrial calcium overload that worsens during reperfusion. Reperfusion results in cell membrane damage that allows a further influx of calcium into the cell. The calcium overload increases the permeability of mitochondria with resultant ATP depletion.
  • There is the disintegration of the cell membrane, which causes the cell contents to leak out of the cell leading to an acute inflammatory response.
  • There is a loss of cell and organelle integrity leading to cell death by necroptosis.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presented with a high fever, chills, and rigor associated with severe arthralgia and myalgia. Chik sign is noticed on the patient's nose. Choose the correct statements about the cutaneous manifestations of this disease.
  1. The rash is more pronounced on limbs than on the trunk. 
  2. The rash is never pruritic. 
  3. The rash may progress to petechiae and purpura. 
  4. The rash is often vesiculobullous in infants. 
  5. Ano‐genital and oral ulceration is occasional sequelae.
questions.solution:
Statements 3, 4, and 5 are correct. The clinical history of high fever, chills, and rigor associated with severe arthralgia and myalgia and Chik sign point towards a diagnosis of Chikungunya. Chik sign refers to a central facial pigmentation predominantly on the nose which develops during the acute phase of the disease and helps in the retrospective diagnosis of Chikungunya infection.

Chikungunya fever is due to infection with Chikungunya virus (CHIKV), spread by mosquitos and direct contact between humans. The Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus mosquitoes are the most common vectors.

It presents as an acute onset of fever and joint pains with other flu symptoms such as headache, loss of appetite, and nausea. A maculopapular rash develops, which is more pronounced on the trunk and to a lesser extent on the limbs. Pruritis is not uncommon. The rash may occasionally progress to petechiae and purpura. It may be accompanied by facial flushing. 

Neonates born to a mother who had a CHK infection in the last trimester may present with classic central facial pigmentation. Infants may develop a symmetrical vesiculobullous type of rash and acrocyanosis.

Ano‐genital and oral ulceration may develop as sequelae. The ulcers are shallow and resemble aphthous ulcers. They may involve other flexures such as axillae and oral mucosa.

Diagnosis is mainly clinical, however, a definitive diagnosis can be made by the detection of IgM antibodies in the sera with ELISA or RT PCR.

Treatment is supportive with acetaminophen and NSAIDs. The rash can be managed with saline compresses and emollients. Persistent non-healing ulcers can be managed by topical or systemic antibiotics. Most of the skin lesions resolve within 2 weeks.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presents with a fever and right-sided swelling behind the angle of jaw. He also complains of odynophagia and difficulty moving his jaw.  He underwent a molar tooth extraction about three days ago. On examination, the ipsilateral faucial tonsil is displaced medially with mild collapse of the tonsillar fossa. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is strongly suggestive of a parapharyngeal abscess (anterior compartment type), an infection of the parapharyngeal space.

This space can get infected following infections of the tonsils, adenoids, and parotid glands. It can also occur following dental extractions and penetrating trauma. 

Clinically, patients may present with the following features-

  • Fever
  • Odynophagia or dysphagia
  • Trismus due to irritation of the medial pterygoid muscle
  • The collapse of the tonsillar fossa and tonsil
  • Swelling- Behind the angle of the mandible (in anterior compartment infection), parotid region or area behind the posterior pillar (in posterior compartment infection)
  • Paralysis of IX, X, XI, and XII cranial nerves is commonly seen in infections of the posterior compartment.
  • Features of internal jugular vein thrombosis and carotid artery thrombosis.

Diagnosis can be established using a CECT.

Patients require intravenous antibiotic therapy with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, carbapenem antibiotics plus drugs that target anaerobic organisms, such as clindamycin or metronidazole. A parapharyngeal abscess is drained by an external horizontal incision made on the skin a few centimeters below the angle of the mandible, followed by blunt dissection. 

Other options:

Option B: Retropharyngeal abscess presents predominantly with features of dysphagia and difficulty breathing. Patients may also develop stridor and croupy cough. It is seen as a bulge on the posterior pharyngeal wall, most typically, on one side of the midline, unlike parapharyngeal abscesses. 

Option C: Peritonsillar abscess or quinsy presents with severe pain in the throat, fever (up to 104 °F), chills and rigors, and a “hot potato voice". On examination, a bulging of the soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil can be seen. Uvula can be pushed to the opposite side.

Option D: Lemierre’s syndrome is thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein and devastating anaerobic bacteremia that follows oropharyngeal infection. It typically presents in children and young healthy adults as severe lateral neck pain and sepsis following prolonged pharyngitis.

questions.text:
You notice an obstetrics resident performing the following manoeuvres on a 37-week primigravida. Choose the correctly matched set.
  1. First Leopold
  2. Second Leopold
  3. Third Leopold
  4. Fourth Leopold
questions.solution:
Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of fetal head are assessed by Leopold's manoeuvres:

  1. Fundal grip (first Leopold):
    • Assesses the uterine fundus.
    • Helps in identification of fetal lie and determination of fetal pole at the fundus.
    • The breech gives the sensation of a large, irregular mass. 
    • The head feels hard and round and is more mobile.

  2. Lateral grip (second Leopold): 
    • Assesses the fetal orientation.
    • The palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted.
    • The back is felt on one side as a hard, resistant structure.
    • The fetal extremities are felt on the other side as numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt.
    • Fetal orientation can be determined by noting whether the back is directed anteriorly, transversely, or posteriorly.
    • The position of the anterior shoulder is mainly assessed by this grip.

  3. Pawlik's grip / 1st pelvic grip (third Leopold):
    • Assesses the presenting part in respect to the true pelvis.
    • The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis.
    • If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass will be felt, usually the head.

  4. Deep pelvic grip / 2nd pelvic grip (fourth Leopold):
    • Assesses the engagement, attitude of the fetal head and determine the degree of descent.
    • The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part.
    • They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.
    • If the head has already descended into the pelvis, the anterior shoulder or the space created by the neck may be differentiated readily from the head.
    • It is the only grip performed facing the feet.

questions.text: A young male patient presented to the casualty after a road traffic accident and was diagnosed with intracranial hemorrhage on the CT brain. He was started on hypertonic saline. Which of the following images best depict the changes in the fluid volumes after administration of the given saline?
questions.solution:
After the administration of hypertonic saline, the changes in the fluid volume occur as depicted in image 4.

The clinical features depict raised intracranial pressure due to intracranial haemorrhage. Patients are started on osmotic diuretics like mannitol or hypertonic saline to prevent cerebral swelling. The administration of the osmotic agents increases the osmolarity of the plasma. The cerebral tissues have lower osmolarity compared to the plasma. Therefore, this leads to the flow of excess water from cerebral tissues to the blood via osmosis.

Whenever hypertonic saline is added to the extracellular fluid (ECF), the extracellular osmolarity increases. It causes osmosis of water out of the cells into the extracellular compartment. Almost all the added sodium chloride remains in the extracellular compartment and fluid diffuses into the extracellular space to achieve osmotic equilibrium. The net effect is that the volume of ECF increases, the volumes of intracellular fluid (ICF) decreases, and the osmolarity of both compartments increase. 

Whenever isotonic saline is added to the extracellular fluid, the osmolarity of fluids does not change. The main effect is that it increases the ECF volume

Whenever hypotonic saline is added to ECF, the osmolarity of ECF decreases. This leads to the movement of water from the ECF to the ICF until both attain the same osmolarity. Both the intracellular and extracellular volumes are increased by the addition of hypotonic fluid, but the intracellular volume increases to a greater extent. Osmolarity decreases in both the compartments.

  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding management of acute urinary retention?

choices.text: Coude catheterization is preferred in men with benign prostatic hyperplasia
The tip of the coude catheter should always point to 12 o’clock when inserted
Suprapubic tube should not be inserted due to the risk of bowel injury
If retention is caused due to hematuria, continuous bladder irrigation is done

questions.solution:
Suprapubic tube insertion is one of the modalities in the management of acute urinary retention. The risk of bowel injury is very low as the bladder is fully distended due to the retention of urine.

Acute urinary retention may be seen in men and women but commonly occurs in men with benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Other causes of acute urinary retention include:

  • Diabetic neuropathy
  • Urethral stricture
  • Parkinson’s disease
  • Multiple sclerosis

Management: Acute urinary retention is managed by placing a urinary catheter as early as possible. In patients with BPH, a specialised catheter called coude catheter may be placed. It is a curved catheter and is useful in passing the catheter through the angulation in the prostatic urethra. Once the curved tip enters the bladder, it is maintained at the 12’O o'clock position.

If catheter placement is not successful:

  • If there is a urethral stricture, it is dilated with a cystoscope, guide wires and urethral dilators and a council tip catheter is inserted. Or
  • A suprapubic catheter may be inserted.

If the retention is caused by hematuria:

  • A large three-way catheter with an additional port for fluid inflow is inserted.
  • The fluid is infused, and continuous bladder irrigation is done to prevent clot formation.
  • Note that the fluid should be infused only under gravity, as infusion under high pressure may cause bladder rupture.

questions.text: You work in the Infection Control Committee of the hospital and are assigned the task of inspecting the disinfection and sterilization protocols of the operating room. What procedure should be followed to sterilize the urethroscope used?
questions.solution:
The sterilization of scopes such as arthroscopes and urethroscopes is done by plasma sterilization.

Plasma contains ions, electrons, and neutral particles. This state is produced by the application of radio frequency energy to create an electromagnetic field through which hydrogen peroxide vapors are passed. This generates plasma containing free radicals of hydrogen and oxygen which are used to sterilize articles such as arthroscopes and urethroscopes.

Other options :

Gamma radiation and ethylene oxide gas sterilization is used for the sterilization of articles such as syringes, needles, catheters, and gloves.

Autoclaving is used to sterilize surgical linens, culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut.

questions.text: A young woman was diagnosed with coronavirus 19 disease five days ago. Because of respiratory failure, she is referred to a tertiary care centre.  A bedside portable chest radiograph was done and it showed the presence of bilateral opacities. There is no effusion, lung collapse, or lung nodules. There is no pedal edema, elevated jugular venous pressure or enlargement of the liver. There is no history of excessive administration of intravenous fluids. The ratio of arterial oxygen partial pressure to the fraction of inspired oxygen (PaO2/FiO2) is found to be 240 mm Hg on 5 cm of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP). What is the diagnosis?

choices.text: Severe disease without acute respiratory distress syndrome
Moderate disease without acute respiratory distress syndrome

questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of mild acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to coronavirus 19 disease infection. The patient has developed respiratory failure within one week of the infection. The opacities in the lung are not explained by effusions, lung collapse, lung nodules or excessive administration of fluids. The ratio of arterial oxygen partial pressure to the fraction of inspired oxygen (PaO2/FiO2) is found to be 240 mm Hg on 5 cm of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP).

Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is the most severe type of acute lung injury which leads to hypoxemia. Following injury, fluid gets accumulated in the lung, leading to impaired oxygenation.

Berlin's definition of ARDS is:

  • It develops within 1 week of clinical insult or onset of respiratory symptoms
  • Chest radiograph shows bilateral opacities. These opacities are not fully explained by effusions, lobar or lung collapse, or nodules.
  • The edema is not due to cardiac failure, or fluid overload.
  • There is impaired oxygenation. The ratio of arterial oxygen partial pressure to the fraction of inspired oxygen (PaO2/FiO2) is ≤ 300 mmHg on 5 cm of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) or positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP).

Depending on the value of PaO2/FiO2 (with PEEP or CPAP ≥5 cm H2O) it can be

  • Mild- PaO2/FiO2 is between 300mmHg to 200 mmHg
  • Moderate- PaO2/FiO2 is between 200mmHg to 100 mmHg
  • Severe- PaO2/FiO2 is ≤ 100mmHg

Below radiograph shows bilateral lung opacities due to acute respiratory distress syndrome.

questions.text: An elderly patient who presented with chest pain is undergoing coronary angiography. When the cardiologist injected the radiocontrast dye into the patient, the patient developed profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. The reflex that is responsible for this scenario is
questions.solution:
Reflex responsible for the above scenario is the Bezold Jarisch reflex. 

Activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibres in the cardiopulmonary region (eg, juxtacapillary region of alveoli, ventricles, atria, great veins, and pulmonary artery) causes profound bradycardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. This is called the Bezold Jarisch reflex and can be elicited by capsaicin, serotonin, phenylbiguanide, and veratridine. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography.

Other options

Option A- C fibre endings close to the pulmonary vessels are called J (juxtacapillary) receptors. These receptors are stimulated by hyperinflation of the lungs or intravenous administration of capsaicin. The reflex produced is apnea followed by rapid breathing, bradycardia and hypotension. This is called the J reflex.

Option B- Cushing reflex is the increased blood pressure and bradycardia seen in patients with raised intracranial pressure. Increased intracranial pressure compresses the cerebral blood vessels and causes hypercapnia. This stimulates the central chemoreceptors located in the ventrolateral surface of the medulla and causes increased blood pressure. This increase is proportional to the increase in the intracranial pressure. Increased blood pressure stimulates baroreceptors and causes bradycardia.

Option C- Brainbridge reflex is the increase in the heart rate when the atrium is stretched. Whenever there is a stretch of the atrium, the stretch receptors are activated. They transmit their afferent signals through the vagus nerves to the medulla of the brain. Efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves to increase the heart rate and strength of heart contraction. This reflex prevents the accumulation of blood in the atria, veins and pulmonary circulation.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a lack of object permanence?

choices.text: Uncovering a hidden toy after seeing that it was hidden
Banging two toys against each other
Staring momentarily at the spot where the toy disappeared from

questions.solution:
Staring momentarily at the spot where a toy disappeared from signifies a lack of object permanence or constancy (out of sight, out of mind). This is seen at 2 months of age and disappears at 8-9 months of age when the milestone of object permanence is attained.

Object permanence is the understanding that the object continues to exist even when it is not seen. When an object is hidden, a baby who is 4 to 7 months of age does not search for it and quickly gives up. However, a 9-month-old baby is able to understand that the hidden object continues to exist, will search for it, and be able to find it under a hidden cloth or behind the examiner's back. The child will enjoy the game Peek-a-boo at this stage of development.

 

The GIF below demonstrates object permanence. 

Other options:

Option A: Uncovering a toy (after seeing it hidden) is an example of object permanence, seen by 8 months of age.

Option B: Banging two toys against each other signifies an active comparison of objects, seen by 8 months of age.

Option D: Pointing to toys signifies interactive communication, seen by 10 months of age.

questions.text:
A young man undergoes partial hepatectomy as a part of living-donor hepatic transplantation. Which among the following is true about the regeneration of the liver?
  1. Two major mechanisms: Proliferation of remaining hepatocytes and repopulation from progenitor cells
  2. Hepatocyte proliferation occurs in 4 distinct stages.
  3. The priming phase includes production of IL - 6 by stellate cells
  4. During the termination phase, hepatacytes return to quiesence
  5. Progenitor cells reside in canals of Hering
questions.solution:
Among the given statements, 1, 4, and 5 are true about the regeneration of the liver.

The human liver regenerates by two major mechanisms :

  1. Proliferation of remaining hepatocytes
  2. Repopulation from progenitor cells.

Proliferation of hepatocytes:

This process is triggered by the combined actions of cytokines and growth factors and occurs in 3 distinct stages.

  • Priming stage: Cytokines like IL - 6 are produced by the Kupffer cells and act on hepatocytes to make them sensitive to growth factor signals.
  • Growth factor phase: HGF and TGF-α act on primed hepatocytes to stimulate cell metabolism and entry into the cell cycle. 
  • Termination phase: The hepatocytes return to quiescence with the involvement of antiproliferative factors like TGF-β

Regeneration from progenitor cells :

In situations where the proliferative capacity of hepatocytes is impaired, such as after chronic liver injury or inflammation, progenitor cells(oval cells) in the liver contribute to repopulation.

Oval cells are seen in the liver. These are liver stem cells located in the canals of Hering (structures that connect bile ductules to parenchymal hepatocytes).

questions.solution:
The marked structure is the internal oblique muscle. It can be identified by their fibres which pass obliquely upwards and are attached to the ribs.

Internal Oblique muscle: Its fibres begin at the anterior 2/3 of the iliac crest and the lateral half of the inguinal ligament. The muscle fibres run from these points superomedially (up and towards the midline) to the muscle's insertions on the inferior borders of the 10th through 12th ribs and the linea alba.

questions.text: A woman died due to septic abortion following Clostridium welchii infection. What color is the postmortem hypostasis likely to be in this case?
questions.solution:
Postmortem hypostasis seen in cases of septic abortion due to Clostridium welchii is mostly greenish-brown in color. Septic abortion due to Clostridium perfringens also produces a hypostasis of a brownish color and, in rare cases, bronze.

The terms postmortem hypostasis, postmortem staining, postmortem lividity, livor mortis, and suggillation all refer to the purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin occurring due to the postmortem collection of blood in toneless capillaries in dependant parts of the body.

Features:

  • Caused by engorged vessels showing through the skin
  • Occur on dependent parts due to the pooling of blood under the effect of gravity
  • Margins clearly defined
  • No swelling or abrasion

Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6–12 hours after death. It occurs earlier in summer and is delayed in asphyxial deaths and in intracranial lesions.  

Timing:

  • Mottled patches - 1–3 hours following death
  • Uniform area of staining - 3–6 hours following death
  • Fully developed and fixation of hypostasis - 6–12 hours following death

Postmortem hypostasis/lividity usually develops within 4 hours of death and persists until putrefaction.
