questions.text:
You are the on-call junior surgeon attending to the emergency room. You receive a patient who has been referred from a local primary health centre with multiple open fractures and documented head trauma. The registered medical practitioner in his referral notes has mentioned that he is also suspecting sepsis. Which of the following considerations would you take into account in the management of this patient according to the surviving sepsis guidelines in the first golden hour bundle?
  1. Activated protein C is used in the initial evaluation.
  2. Consider starting insulin if two consecutive blood sugar values are > 180 mg/dl.
  3. Do not use IV immunoglobulin in patients with sepsis.
  4. Use erythropoietin for the treatment of anaemia associated with sepsis.
  5. Use empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy.
questions.solution:
The correct considerations according to the recent surviving sepsis guidelines - 2018 includes 2, 3, 5.

One hour bundle - considerations as per surviving sepsis criteria:

In polytrauma, the initial first hour is considered the golden hour. Active interventions in this time can prevent sepsis and its sequelae. The following are the guiding principle that these complex patients need in addition to detailed initial assessment and ongoing re-evaluation of their response to the treatment considerations.  

  • Begin resuscitation and management immediately.
  • If the patient is brought after 1 hour prioritise resuscitation and simultaneously perform investigations.
  • In patients with hemodynamic instability, vasopressors can be initiated.
  • Measure lactate levels and remeasure if lactate levels initially measured > 2mmol/L.
  • Obtain blood cultures prior to initiation of antibiotics.
  • Administer broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Begin rapid administration of crystalloids at 30ml/kg if hypotension is present or when the serum lactate levels measured are > 4mmol/L. The committee prefers crystalloids followed by albumin. 
  • Consider vasopressor therapy when hypotension persists during or after fluid resuscitation. Vasopressor therapy initially targets a MAP of 65 mm Hg and the actual value must be individualized because the optimal MAP may be higher in older patients with atherosclerosis or previous hypertension (or both) than in younger patients without cardiovascular comorbidity. 
  • Order of inotrope use: Noradrenaline > Vasopressin > Dobutamine > adrenaline
  • Maintain euglycemic status. In diabetic patients, the target blood glucose levels is 150mg/dl.

The committee is against the use of steroids, IV immunoglobulin and erythropoietin in cases of sepsis. But the role of hydrocortisone is still controversial. Many standard textbooks still follow the older guidelines recommending the use of hydrocortisone, but the latest guidelines have no mention of these. 

Older consideration as per 2012:

Surviving sepsis criteria defines the goal of resuscitation to be achieved in the initial bundle of six-hour. These initial goals include:

  • Central venous pressure 8-12 mm Hg
  • Urine output ≥ 0.5 ml/kg/hr
  • Mean arterial pressure ≥ 65 mmHg
  • Mixed venous oxygen saturation of ≥ 65%
  • Normalize lactate which serves as a marker of hypoperfusion

questions.text:
You are a newly posted intern in the department of surgery. During your routine ward rounds, you notice a patient with an ulcer being treated with the following therapy. Which of the following statements are true regarding this modality of treatment?
  1. The therapy involves the application of continuous pressure of -250 mm of Hg
  2. It increases blood flow and decreases wound edema
  3. It creates a suitable bed for a flap or graft cover
  4. It consists of an airtight and sealed wound drain covered with an opaque adhesive film
  5. Everyday redressing of the wound is not required with this therapy
questions.solution:
The image above shows the vacuum-assisted closure of an ulcer. The true statements regarding VAC are 2, 3, and 5.

VAC therapy is also called negative pressure wound closure. It creates an intermittent (not continuous) negative pressure of -125 mm Hg to promote the formation of healthy granulation tissue.

It is made up of foam with a perforated wound drain covered and plastered with transparent plastic/ adhesive film. It is commonly used in the management of pressure bed sores and diabetic ulcers. It creates a suitable niche and bed for harvesting flaps. Everyday redressing of the wound is not required with this therapy. 

It acts by:

  • Reducing tissue edema
  • Clearing interstitial fluid
  • Improves perfusion and increases the healing process

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with 2 months of amenorrhea presents with painless vaginal bleeding. She has a history of dilatation and curettage for a miscarriage 6 months ago.  Her urine pregnancy test is positive but ultrasonography shows an empty uterus and no gestational sac was found in the adnexa. On further investigation, it is suspected that embryo implantation has occurred in the cervical canal below the internal os. Which of the following criteria would you use for the diagnosis in this type of ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The given presentation is suggestive of cervical pregnancy, Rubin's criteria are used for the diagnosis, in these cases.

Cervical pregnancy is a type of ectopic pregnancy where implantation occurs in the cervical canal at or below the internal os. Thinning and distension of the cervical canal occurs due to erosion of the walls by the trophoblasts. The morbidity and mortality is high due to profuse bleeding.

Paalman and McElin: Clinical diagnostic criteria for cervical pregnancy:

  1. Uterine bleeding without cramping pain following a period of amenorrhea

  2. A soft, enlarged cervix equal to or larger than the fundus

  3. Products of conception entirely confined within and firmly attached to the endocervix

  4. A closed internal cervical os

  5. A partially opened external cervical os.

The incidence of cervical pregnancies appears to be rising because of artificial reproductive techniques, especially in-vitro fertilization and embryo transfer. A risk factor unique to cervical pregnancy is a history of dilatation and curettage in a prior pregnancy.

Criteria used in the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy are:

  • Cervical pregnancy: Paalman and McElin (clinical criteria) and Rubin's criteria (Histological criteria)
  • Ovarian pregnancy: Spiegelberg’s criteria
  • Primary abdominal: Studdiford's criteria

Other option: Jones criteria are not related to ectopic pregnancies, it is used as diagnostic criteria for Rheumatic fever.

questions.text:
The lung function of a patient is tested using a spirometer, and the following recording is noted. The technician looks at the graph and enters the following values in the report.
Volumes Values
1. Tidal volume  500 mL
2. Inspiratory reserve volume 2L
3. Expiratory reserve volume 1L
4. Inspiratory capacity 4.5L
5. Expiratory capacity 1.5L
6. Vital capacity 3.5L

Which among the following capacities has been incorrectly calculated by the technician?
questions.solution:
The technician has recorded inspiratory reserve volume, inspiratory capacity, and vital capacity wrongly.

In the above graph, 

Tidal volume (TV) is the amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration or the amount of air that moves out with each expiration during quiet breathing. In this patient it is 0.5L. The normal values are 500-750 mL.

Inspiratory reserve volume (IRV) is the air inspired with a maximal inspiratory effort in excess of the tidal volume. In this patient, it is 6-3L = 3L. The normal values are around 2L.

Expiratory reserve volume (ERV) is the volume expelled by an active expiratory effort after passive expiration. In this patient it is 2.5-1.5 = 1L. The normal value is around 1L.

Inspiratory capacity (IC) is the maximum amount of air inspired from the end-expiratory level. It can be calculated as TV+IRV which is 0.5L + 3L= 3.5L. The normal value is around 2.5L.

Expiratory capacity (EC) is the maximum amount of air expired after a normal inspiration. It is calculated as TV+ERV, which is 0.5L + 1L = 1.5 L. Normal value is around 1.5L

Vital capacity (VC) refers to the maximum amount of air expired after full inspiration. It is calculated as TV+IRV+ERV. In this patient it is 0.5+ 3+1 =4.5L. The normal value is around 3.5L.

Other important lung values:

The forced vital capacity (FVC), is the largest amount of air that can be expired after a maximal inspiratory effort.

Forced expiratory volume in the first second, FEV1, is the fraction of the vital capacity expired during the first second. 

Respiratory minute volume (RVV) is a measurement of the amount of air that enters the lungs per minute. It is calculated as respiratory rate X tidal volume.

Maximal voluntary respiration (MVV), is the largest volume of gas that can be moved into and out of the lungs in 1 min by voluntary effort.

Total lung capacity is the total volume of the lung. It can be calculated by adding tidal volume, inspiratory reserve volume, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume. Normal total lung capacity is around 5L.

questions.text: The life cycle of a parasite is shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this parasitic infection?

choices.text: The parasite belongs to the phylum Nematoda
Feces examination is not commonly used in diagnosis
The alimentary canal of the parasite is incomplete, without an anus
The eggs of the parasite are  colorless and non-bile stained

questions.solution:
The given life cycle is indicative of Enterobius vermicularis, and the incorrect statement is its alimentary canal is incomplete, without an anus.

The nematode Enterobius vermicularis has an alimentary canal that is complete till the anus. It causes perianal pruritis. Eggs are present in the feces only in a small proportion of patients, so feces examination is not useful in diagnosis. NIH swab method and Scotch tape method are used for the collection of specimens. This involves pressing an adhesive cellophane tape against the perianal region early in the morning and transferring it to a glass slide under the microscope to demonstrate eggs.

Pinworm eggs are planoconvex with a double-layered eggshell that is relatively thick and transparent. The are colorless, non-bile stained. They float in the saturated salt solution. Treatment includes albendazole.

questions.text: An 18-year-old patient comes with swelling of face and lips after he heard the passing of his dog as shown in the image. He was administered icatibant. What is the likely mechanism of action of the drug prescribed to the boy?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is hereditary angioedema.

Icatibant is a selective bradykinin B2 receptor competitive antagonist. It is indicated for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioedema.

The other drug which is approved for the treatment of acute attacks of hereditary angioedema is ecallantide which is a synthetic plasma kallikrein inhibitor. 

Both icatibant and ecallantide are administered subcutaneously.

A common side effect is a local reaction at the injection site (redness, bruising, swelling, burning, itching, etc.). Other side effects include fever, elevated transaminase, dizziness, nausea, headache, or rash. 

Hereditary angioedema (HAE) is due to an inherited deficiency of C1 inhibitors. Patients with HAE usually present with episodic attacks that begin during childhood that became more severe during adolescence.

There may be symptoms before the episodes occur, such as sudden mood changes, anxiety, sensory changes, or exhaustion may also occur for several hours. In one-third of patients, attacks are precipitated by trauma-like pressure. 

Symptoms are referable to 3 prominent sites:

  • Subcutaneous tissues like face, hands, arms, legs, genitals, and buttocks
  • Abdominal organs like the stomach, intestines, bladder, and kidneys. This manifests as vomiting, diarrhea, or paroxysmal colicky pain
  • The upper airway (larynx) and tongue, which results in laryngeal edema and upper airway obstruction

The swelling is usually unresponsive to antihistamines.

Recent Update: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has recently approved another plasma kallikrein inhibitor, berotralstat, as the first oral drug for the prevention and treatment of hereditary angioedema.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old girl child is brought to the clinic by her father with a history of fever, weight loss, and an abdominal mass. Examination reveals an irritable child with slight bilateral proptosis. The abdominal mass is resected and sent for histopathological examination which is shown below. Diagnosis is established based on the findings. Which of the following statements is true regarding the prognosis of this tumor?
  1. An age lesser than 18 months has a favourable prognosis
  2. Hyper-diploid tumors have a favourable prognosis.
  3. Amplification of MYCN oncogene is prognostically favourable
  4. Stage 4S of disease has an unfavourable prognosis
  5. The presence of Schwannian stroma is associated with favourable outcome
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of neuroblastoma. The child presents with abdominal pain and a mass. Biopsy of the mass shows characteristic Homer-Wright pseudorosettes which point towards the diagnosis. Statements 1, 2, and 5 are true regarding the prognosis of this disease. 

Neuroblastomas arise from the neural crest cells and are the most common intra-abdominal and extracranial solid tumors in children. Most patients present before the age of 5 years. Patients who present with the disease before the age of 18 months have a significantly better prognosis. There has been an association established with fetal alcohol syndrome, neurofibromatosis, fetal hydantoin syndrome, and Hirschsprung's disease.

Genetics :

Rearrangement or deletion of the short arm of chromosome 1 is seen in many patients. The MYCN gene is used as a biomarker for risk stratification. Expression of this oncogene, which is seen in about 20% of the patients, is associated with aggressive disease. Hyperdiploidy is associated with a favorable prognosis in children. Loss of heterozygosity in 1p, 11q, 14q, and gain of 17q are associated with a worse prognosis.

Diagnosis :

Histopathology is the gold standard for diagnosis. Histologically, classic neuroblastomas are composed of small, primitive-appearing cells with dark nuclei, scant cytoplasm, and poorly defined cell borders growing in solid sheets. Typically, Homer-Wright pseudorosettes can be found in which tumor cells are concentrically arranged about a central space filled with neuropil.

questions.text: Given below is the ECG of a patient who presented to the emergency room with sudden onset palpitations and breathlessness. Which of the following drugs will be useful in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given ECG, the presence of narrow-complex regular tachycardia and P-waves occurring after QRS complexes, known as retro P waves or pseudo-r' waves, (especially prominent in lead V1) point to a diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Out of the given drugs, Verapamil can be used in the treatment of PSVT.

PSVT is an arrhythmia characterized by sudden onset and offset with rapid ventricular response. It includes atrioventricular nodal reentry tachycardia, junctional tachycardia, and AV reentry tachycardia. Initial management of PSVT is by vagal maneuvers such as carotid massage. If this method is ineffective, intravenous adenosine is used which will terminate the majority of PSVT episodes by blocking the conduction at AV node. Beta-blockers and non-DHP calcium channel blockers like Verapamil and Diltiazem are also able to block AV nodal conduction and can therefore be used in patients with PSVT.

Verapamil is a class IV anti-arrhythmic agent. It is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It acts by slowing down the SA node automaticity and AV nodal conduction velocity. This decreases the conduction velocity and prolongs the refractory period, leading to the effective termination of the re-entrant current. Additionally, they also decrease cardiac contractility and reduce blood pressure. Diltiazem acts in a similar manner. Side effects of Verapamil include hypotension, bradycardia, constipation, and rarely, worsening of heart failure.

Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like Nifedipine, Amlodipine, and Cilnidipine do not have any antiarrhythmic properties.

 

Other options:

Option A: Cilnidipine blocks both N and L-type calcium channels. It is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It blocks the L-type calcium channels in blood vessels and inhibits the contraction of blood vessels and blocks the N-type calcium channels located at the sympathetic nerve endings, inhibiting the release of norepinephrine. It is used in hypertension, especially in patients with diabetes who present with albuminuria and chronic kidney disease as it has end-organ protective properties.

Option B: Fenoldopam injection is a dopaminergic agonist. It is indicated in adult patients for short-term management of severe hypertension when rapid and reversible reduction of blood pressure is clinically indicated, including for hypertensive emergencies. 

Option D: Nifedipine is a dihydropyridine that acts by blocking L-type calcium channels, having a rapid onset and short duration of action. It results in an abrupt decrease in blood pressure resulting in reflex tachycardia. Increased heart rate increases the O2 demand and might precipitate angina.

questions.text:
As the chief medical officer, you set up a COVID -19 vaccination camp. At the end of the day, only three doses remain. Who among the following would you prioritize for vaccination according to the revised vaccination guidelines?
  1. A 65-year-old diabetic woman who has already received her first dose of the vaccine
  2. A 39-year-old man who is the superintendent of police
  3. A 42 year old male working for the Integrated Child Development Services
  4. A 21-year-old college student
  5. A 46-year-old male with no comorbidities.
questions.solution:
According to revised vaccination guidelines, the 2nd, 3rd, and 5th person will be vaccinated.

In respect of the vaccine doses provided free of cost by the Government of India to the States, vaccination will be prioritized in the following order:

  1. Health Care Workers
  2. Front Line Workers
  3. Citizens more than 45 years of age
  4. Citizens whose second dose has become due
  5. Citizens 18 years & above

Within the population group of citizens more than 18 years of age, States/UTs may decide their own prioritization factoring in the availability of the vaccine.

In the given scenario, an employee of the ICDS belongs to the "Health Care Workers" group and the superintendant of police belongs to the "Front line workers" group and hence will be prioritised accordingly.

questions.text: An 81-year-old woman presented with gradually increasing shortness of breath over the past 6 months. Examination reveals finger clubbing and bibasilar fine inspiratory crackles. Pulmonary function test showed a restrictive defect with reduced lung volumes. HRCT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Respiratory bronchiolitis associated interstitial lung disease

questions.solution:
In a patient with chronic shortness of breath, finger clubbing, and fine inspiratory crackles, spirometry showing a restrictive defect and reduced lung volumes points to a diagnosis of interstitial lung disease. In the given HRCT, there is prominent honeycombing in the lower and posterior lung zones. This is seen in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).

Interstitial lung diseases are characterized by inflammation and fibrosis involving the lung parenchyma. Although there are multiple diseases under this subset, the clinical presentation for all of them is the same. The patients are usually over 60 years of age and present with progressive exertional dyspnea and dry cough. On examination, fine inspiratory, velcro crackles may be heard. Digital clubbing and cyanosis are signs of advanced disease.

Pulmonary function tests (PFT) will show a restrictive deficit and reduction of TLC, FEV1, and FVC. There is also a reduction in DLCO and may be the first finding seen in PFT. Other laboratory tests should be undertaken if the patient has symptoms involving other systems, to rule out any connective tissue disorder which might have led to ILD.

IPF is the most common interstitial lung disease occurring due to an unknown cause. HRCT shows predominant subpleural and basal involvement, in the form of reticulation, honeycombing, and traction bronchiectasis. This is known as the usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) pattern. Note that ground glass opacities are absent in this pattern. 

The treatment of IPF is with antifibrotic therapy such as pirfenidone and nintedanib.

Other options:

Option A: Acute interstitial pneumonia is characterized by a sudden onset of hypoxemia and respiratory distress, following symptoms of an upper respiratory tract infection. HRCT shows patchy bilateral ground-glass opacities and consolidation of the air spaces.

Options B and D: Respiratory bronchiolitis associated with ILD (RB-ILD) and desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP) are more commonly seen in smokers. HRCT shows prominent ground-glass opacities in both these disorders.

Related Pearl: HRCT Findings in Interstitial Lung Diseases

Idiopathic interstitial lung diseases

  • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis / Usual interstitial pneumonia
    • Honeycombing
    • Reticular shadows
    • Traction bronchiectasis
    • Complete loss of lung architecture
    • Absence of other nonspecific findings (ground-glass opacities, nodules, cysts, consolidations)
  • Non-specific interstitial pneumonia
    • Extensive ground-glass opacities
    • Sub pleural sparing (specific, but not seen always)
  • Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP)
    • Patchy consolidation with air bronchogram
    • Reverse halo/ Atoll sign: Ground glass area surrounded by peripheral consolidation (as shown below in red arrows)
  • Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonia (LIP)
    • Thin-walled cysts (shown below in red arrows)
    • Centrilobular nodules 
    • Ground glass opacities
  •  Respiratory bronchiolitis related interstitial lung disease
    • Centrilobular ground-glass nodules
    • Bronchial wall thickening
  • Acute interstitial pneumonia
    • Diffuse patchy ground-glass opacities
  • Desquamated interstitial pneumonia
    • Patchy ground-glass opacities 

Other forms of ILDs

  • Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM)
    • Regular thin-walled cysts
  • Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (PAP)
    • Ground-glass opacification with superimposed septal thickening, known as “crazy paving”
    • It is characteristic but not diagnostic
  • Pulmonary Langerhans cell histiocytosis (PLCH)
    • Bilateral irregular shaped cysts with nodules, predominantly in the upper lobe.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presented with complaints of diarrhea for the past 3 days. On examination, he is tachypneic. His laboratory investigations are given below. What is the acid-base disorder in this patient?
pH 7.2
pCO2 20 mmHg
HCO3- 7 mEq/L
Cl- 120 mEq/L
Na+ 135 mEq/L

choices.text: Metabolic acidosis with normal anion gap
Metabolic acidosis with increased anion gap

questions.solution:
The acid-base disorder in this patient is metabolic acidosis with a normal anion gap.

Diagnosis can be arrived at by the following steps:

Step 1: A pH of 7.20 indicates acidosis. The normal pH is 7.35-7.45. 

Step 2: Bicarbonate level of 7 mEq/L (normal = 22-28) together with low pH indicates that acidosis is due to loss of bicarbonate (i.e. base). Hence this is metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: PCO2 levels of 20 mmHg indicate respiratory alkalosis. The decrease in PCO2 with a decrease in pH indicates that it is a compensatory mechanism. Hence the patient has metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.

Assessing the anion gap:

AG=( Na+)- {(Cl-)+(HCO3-)}

=135-(120+7)

=8 mEq/L

The normal anion gap is 6-12 mEq/L. Hence the anion gap is within the normal range.

Diarrhea causes metabolic acidosis due to intestinal loss of bicarbonate-rich fluid.

Other options:

Option B: Metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap is seen if the anion gap is >12 mEq/L. It occurs in conditions such as methanol poisoning, uremia, diabetic ketoacidosis, paracetamol poisoning, lactic acidosis, salicylate poisoning, etc. 

Option C: Respiratory acidosis occurs in conditions in which decreased ventilation (hypoventilation) increases the concentration of carbon dioxide in the blood and decreases the blood's pH. 

Option D: Lactic acidosis causes a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: Microaneurysms which are the earliest manifestation of diabetic retinopathy most frequently develop in which layer
questions.solution:
Microaneurysms are localized outpouchings, mainly saccular, of the capillary wall that may form either by focal dilatation of the capillary wall where pericytes are absent, or by fusion of two arms of a capillary loop.

  • Most develop in the inner capillary plexus (inner nuclear layer), frequently adjacent to areas of capillary non-perfusion.
  • Loss of pericytes may also lead to endothelial cell proliferation with the formation of ‘cellular’ microaneurysms.
  • Microaneurysms may leak plasma constituents into the retina as a result of breakdown in the blood–retinal barrier, or may thrombose.
  • They tend to be the earliest sign of DR.

questions.text: The trichograms of two hair follicles infected with dermatophytes are shown below as images A and B. Identify the correct statements about the respective images.

choices.text: A is caused by M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum and M. canis, no fluorescence on wood's light
A is caused by T. tonsurans and T. violaceum, no fluorescence on wood's light
B is caused by T. tonsurans and T. violaceum, fluorescence seen on wood's light
B is caused by M. audouinii, M. ferrugineum and M. canis, no fluorescence on wood's light

questions.solution:
Image A is an endothrix, which is usually caused by the dermatophyte trichophyton- T. tonsurans and T. violaceum. It does not exhibit fluorescence on wood's light. Image A shows numerous fungal spores within the hair shaft.

Image B shows numerous fungal spores outside the hair shaft, making it an ectothrix.

Tinea capitis (scalp ringworm), is an infection of the hair shafts by a dermatophyte fungus. It can be caused by all the pathogenic dermatophytes except for Epidermophyton floccosum and Trichophyton concentricum. It occurs mainly in children, although it can be seen at all ages. 

Clinical variants:

  • Small‐spored ectothrix type
    • Caused mainly by the Microsporum canis complex.
    • Small spores are visible on the outside of the hair shaft.
    • These fungi show green fluorescence under Wood’s light examination.
    • Presents as circular patches of partial alopecia, with numerous broken‐off hairs. They appear dull grey due to coating with spores.
    • Fine scaling is seen, although inflammation is minimal
  • Endothrix type
    • Caused mainly by Trichophyton species- T. tonsurans, T. violaceum
    • Chains of large spores are seen within the hair shaft (large-spore endothrix)
    • They do not produce fluorescence under Wood’s light.
    • Present as non-inflammatory bald patches with black dots (swollen hair shafts) where the affected hair breaks at the surface 
    • May also present with minimal inflammation and, seborrheic-like scales 
    • The common clinical types are gray patch (scaling with patchy hair loss), black dot and diffuse alopecia.

Treatment is with drugs such as Terbinafine, Itraconazole, or Griseofulvin. Ketoconazole shampoo or selenium sulphide can be used in combination with an oral treatment. Wet compresses with careful removal of crusts should be done, along with analgesics if painful. Secondary bacterial infection if confirmed, should be treated with antibiotics.

 

 

Related Pearl: Wood's lamp examination

Wood's lamp examination is a diagnostic test wherein the skin or hair is examined under exposure to the black light emitted by the Wood lamp.

Blacklight is invisible to the naked eye because it is in the ultraviolet spectrum, with a wavelength just shorter than the color violet. The lamp glows violet in a dark environment because it also emits some light in the violet part of the electromagnetic spectrum.

A traditional Wood lamp is a low-output mercury arc covered by a Wood filter (barium silicate and 9% nickel oxide) and emits light at wavelength 320–450 nm (peak 365 nm).

questions.text: You had ordered to centrifuge a tissue sample and separate the mitochondria out to extract mitochondrial DNA for genetic evaluation. Which of the following is an enzyme marker to identify the mitochondria?
questions.solution:
ATP synthase is the enzyme marker used to identify the mitochondria. It is present in the inner mitochondrial membrane.

The membranes of cell organelles contain various proteins, some of which are enzymes. Certain enzymes are located only in particular membranes. These enzymes may be used as markers following the purification of these membranes. 

The mitochondrial matrix is enclosed by an outer membrane and a selectively permeable inner membrane. The inner membrane contains the respiratory chain enzymes, ATP synthase, and membrane transporters. 

A cytogenetic study involving mitochondrial DNA is generally done when you suspect a genetic disease inherited through the mt-DNA. 

Human mitochondria contain dsDNA that makes up approximately 1% of total cellular DNA. This mitochondrial DNA codes for mt-specific ribosomal and tRNAs as well as for 13 proteins that play roles in the respiratory chain.

Mitochondrial DNA has a high mutation rate, 5-10 times that of nuclear DNA. It is transmitted by maternal non-mendelian inheritance because all mitochondria are contributed by the ovum during the formation of the zygote.

The image attached below shows the pedigree chart pattern of mitochondrial pattern of inheritance.

questions.text:
Which of the following is seen in freshwater drowning?

A. Haemodilution
B. Hypokalemia
C. Hyponatremia
D. Arrhythmia
questions.solution:
In cases of freshwater drowning, hyperkalemia is seen due to hemolysis of swollen RBCs and not hypokalemia.

Freshwater is hypotonic to plasma and is rapidly absorbed from the alveoli and into the RBCs. The RBCs finally swell up and lyse resulting in the release of intracellular potassium causing hyperkalemia. Increased intravascular blood volume combined with hyperkalemia causes arrhythmia. 

Seawater is hypertonic to plasma and causing a shift of fluid from the blood to alveoli causing pulmonary edema. There is a net decrease in blood volume causing a fall in blood pressure.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with tingling and weakness in his right hand and left foot for the past 4 days. He is also a known case of asthma and is on treatment.  On examination, you notice that the patient has a purpura over his body. Laboratory investigations reveal marked eosinophilia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mono neuritis multiplex, and eosinophilia in an asthmatic patient is suggestive of Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Churg-Strauss syndrome (eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis) is a necrotizing vasculitis of the small-to-medium-sized vessels and is characterized by asthma, peripheral and tissue eosinophilia, granuloma formation, and vasculitis.

Common presenting symptoms of this condition are

  • Initial non-specific symptoms like fever, malaise, anorexia, and weight loss
  • Severe attacks of asthma, allergic rhinitis, sinusitis
  • Mononeuritis multiplex- It is a type of peripheral neuropathy affecting at least two nerve areas. Patients complain of pain, tingling, numbness, or weakness in the affected areas.
  • Skin lesions like palpable purpura and subcutaneous nodules

Laboratory investigations will show eosinophilia. They also show elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), fibrinogen, or α2-globulins. Some patients may be positive for antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA). Histopathology shows the presence of necrotizing vasculitis, tissue eosinophilia, and extravascular granulomas.

Daily cyclophosphamide and prednisolone, followed by azathioprine or methotrexate, can be used for the treatment. Mepolizumab, a monoclonal antibody against IL-5, is the drug recently approved by the FDA for Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Note: A rare side effect following the use of montelukast and zafirlukast is the development of Churg-Strauss syndrome.

Other options:

Option A: Patients with microscopic polyangiitis can have symptoms of mononeuritis multiplex and cutaneous purpura. However, features of asthma and eosinophilia make microscopic polyangiitis less likely as the diagnosis.

Option B: Polyarteritis nodosa can also present with mononeuritis multiplex and skin lesions, but patients do not have eosinophilia. In addition to this, it does not affect bronchial or pulmonary arteries.

Option D: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener's) also has symptoms of upper respiratory tract infection (sinusitis, septal perforation, otitis media), lower respiratory tract involvement (hemoptysis, dyspnea, and chest discomfort), and glomerulonephritis. However, eosinophilia is not a feature of this disease.

Related Pearl: Microscopic polyangiitis v/s granulomatosis with polyangiitis

questions.text: Which among the following statements is false regarding the instrument shown below?

choices.text: It is the safest in procedures close to vital structures
It can be used for coagulation
It can be used for cutting
There is more thermal dissipation of current

questions.solution:
From the single-tipped electrode in the cautery image shown below, we can identify the instrument is a unipolar cautery. The false statement is option A. Due to a high thermal spread in unipolar cautery, it is not the safest instrument during procedures close to vital structures. The vitals structures are at risk of thermal injury with this instrument. 

Electrosurgery is the use of high-frequency currents to cut or coagulate tissue during surgery. It can be performed using:

  • Monopolar or unipolar cautery: consists of a single electrode tip
  • Bipolar cautery: consists of two electrode tips in the form of scissors, graspers, etc. 

Other options

Option B: It is true that unipolar cautery can be used for coagulating tissue. The two main settings in unipolar and bipolar cautery are:

  • Coagulation mode: Blue button in the image above.
  • Cutting mode: Yellow button in the image above

In the coagulation mode, a high-voltage current is produced that spreads over a greater surface area. This helps to produce a dehydration effect on the tissues and is very useful when trying to stop the bleeding from nicked vessels during surgery. 

Option C: It is true, as mentioned above that unipolar cautery can be used for cutting tissue. Cutting mode produces a low voltage current that acts on a smaller surface area. This makes it more effective in heating the tissue than in the coagulation mode. The thermal spread will also be less than the coagulation mode, making it safer. 

Option D: It is true that monopolar cautery produces more thermal dissipation of current.

1. Salmonella typhii A) --++
2. Enterobacter aerogenes B) -+--

IMViC - Indole, Methyl Red, Voges-Proskauer and Citrate test respectively.

+ : Positive

questions.solution:
The correct IMViC reactions for the corresponding Enterobacteriaceae species is

Species IMViC reaction
1. Salmonella typhii D) -+-+
2. Enterobacter aerogenes A) --++
3. Shigella sonnei B) -+--
4. Escherichia coli C) ++--

Indole test : 

This test demonstrates the production of indole from tryptophane. Add "Kovac's reagent" and shake gently. Red denotes a positive reaction.

Methyl red test (MR):

This test is used to detect the production of acid during the fermentation of glucose and the maintenance of pH below 4.5. Methyl red is added to a glucose phosphate medium where red is positive while yellow signifies a negative test.

Voges-Proskauer test (VP) :

This test is based on the production of acetyl methyl carbinol from pyruvic acid. In the presence of alkali and atmospheric oxygen, the acetyl methyl carbinol present in the medium is oxidized to diacetyl which reacts with the peptone of the broth to give a red color. In a positive reaction, a pink colour appears in 2-5 minutes, deepening to a magenta or crimson at the half-hour mark. In a negative reaction, it remains colorless for half an hour. Traces of pink are ignored.

Citrate utilization:

Koser's citrate medium uses citrate as the sole source of carbon. A positive test where the citrate is utilized indicates turbidity in the medium.

Indole, MR, VP, and citrate tests are very useful in the identification and classification of enteric gram-negative bacteria. These tests are referred to as "IMViC" tests.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman with a history of chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML) comes for a follow-up. She complains of tremors and balance issues while walking. Tremors are aggravated with movement and relieved at rest. She has difficulty making alternating movements with the front and back of her palm with both hands. Which of the following anti-cancer drugs causes these adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Cytarabine toxicity is associated with cerebellar ataxia.

Cerebellar ataxia is characterized by the following:

  • Gait impairment
  • Unclear (“scanning”) speech
  • Visual blurring due to nystagmus
  • Hand incoordination
  • Tremor with movement

Cytarabine, an anticancer drug used in the treatment of leukemias, acts on the S phase of the cell cycle.

It is a pyrimidine analog and inhibits the DNA polymerase during the replication and repair of DNA.

It is the most important antimetabolite used in the therapy of AML and is also useful in the treatment of patients with other leukemias, such as ALL, CML in the blast phase, APL, and high-grade lymphomas.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with long hands and feet, and a protruding lower jaw. Which of the following genes is most likely implicated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Mutations of the pituitary-specific gene PIT-1 can lead to the development of a somatroph adenoma which produces elevated levels of GH Growth hormone (and IGF-1) which can lead to acromegaly as given in the clinical scenario above.

Somatotrophs, mammosomatotrophs, and lactotrophs are derived from stem cells that express the pituitary transcription factor, PIT-1.

If the increased levels of GH are present after closure of the epiphyses, acromegaly develops. In this condition, growth is most conspicuously seen in

  • Skin and soft tissues, viscera (thyroid, heart, liver, and adrenals).
  • The bones of the face, hands, and feet are thickened and enlarged.
  • Bone density may increase (hyperostosis) in both the spine and the hips.
  • Enlargement and protusion of the jaw is seen (prognathism), and broadening of the lower face.
  • The feet and hands are enlarged, and the fingers become thickened and sausage-like.

GH excess can also be associated with a variety of other manifestatiions, like gonadal dysfunction, diabetes mellitus, generalized muscle weakness, hypertension, arthritis, congestive heart failure, and an increased risk of gastrointestinal cancers.

Other options:

Steroidogenic factor -1 (SF-1) and GATA-2 are factors that are required for gonadotroph differentiation.

questions.text: The given cylinder is supposed to be attached to a patient for labour analgesia in a maternity suite. Which pin index corresponds to this cylinder, as a safety measure to prevent incorrect cylinder attachment?
questions.solution:
The given image of a cylinder with a blue body and white shoulder is the Entonox cylinder, its PIN index is 7, which is number 4 of the given PINs.

Entonox is 50:50 mixtures of nitrous oxide and oxygen, popularly used as labour analgesia in maternity suites

 

The pin index system (PISS) is a safety measure to prevent incorrect cylinder attachment.

  • Each gas cylinder has two holes (except Entonox) in its cylinder valve that fits the corresponding pins in the yoke of the anesthesia machine. The relative positioning of the pins and holes is unique for each gas that constitutes the pin index system.
  • The PISS should only be considered as partial protection because pin index failures have been reported due to bent or broken pins.

Related Pearl: Pin index safety system (PISS):

Note:

  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with more than 7% CO2: 1,6
  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2: 2,6

questions.text:
An elderly lady presented with weight gain. On examination, her limbs appeared thin, and her blood pressure was 180/100 mm Hg. She is also noticed to have the following findings, as shown in the image below. Her lab investigation findings are given below. This condition is likely to be due to
  • 24h urinary free cortisol- elevated 
  • Plasma cortisol after administration of 1mg dexamethasone - elevated
  • Plasma ACTH levels- elevated
  • Corticotropin-releasing hormone test- negative
  • High-dose dexamethasone test- negative
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the image showing buffalo hump, central obesity, and purple stretch marks, is suggestive of Cushing's syndrome. It is likely to be due to ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) production.

Cushing's syndrome refers to a group of clinical features that result from chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids. It can be ACTH-dependent or ACTH-independent.

Clinical features of Cushing’s syndrome are attributed to the increased glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and sex steroid actions of cortisol. They include:

System Clinical features
Body fat
  • Central or truncal obesity (most common)
  • Buffalo hump (fat deposition behind the neck)
  • Moon facies  
Skin
  • Purple striae (over abdomen & flanks)
  • Acne and Hirsutism 
  • Easy bruising 
  • Facial plethora
  • Hyperpigmentation 
Musculoskeletal
  • Proximal myopathy
  • Osteoporosis
Metabolic
  • Poorly controlled hyperglycemia
  • Dyslipidemia
Reproductive
  • Oligomenorrhea
  • Amenorrhea
Renal
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
CVS
  • Atherosclerosis 
  • Diastolic Hypertension 
  • Edema 
  • Hypertension
Hematologic
  • Hypercoagulable state 
  • Lymphopenia
  • Neutrophilia
  • Eosinopenia
CNS
  • Depression
  • Psychosis 
  • Anxiety

The image given below shows the clinical features seen in Cushing's syndrome.

Once Cushing's syndrome is suspected, laboratory investigations are useful in the diagnosis. Patients will have elevated 24-hour urinary cortisol levels; they have elevated levels of plasma cortisol, which are not suppressed by dexamethasone. If these are elevated, it confirms that the patient has elevated levels of cortisol.

The next step is to evaluate if the elevated cortisol levels are due to elevated ACTH or are independent of ACTH levels. In this patient, the ACTH levels are elevated, which means that increased ACTH has caused increased production of cortisol. Increased ACTH can be due to a pituitary tumor that produces ACTH or ectopic ACTH production that is seen in tumors like bronchial or pancreatic carcinoids, medullary thyroid carcinoma, etc.

The source of ACTH production can be identified using an MRI of the pituitary, a corticotropin-releasing hormone test, and a high-dose dexamethasone test. If the ACTH production is due to an adenoma in the pituitary, it responds to the administration of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) and is suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone. In this patient, both of these tests are negative, which means that ACTH production is not from the pituitary but is due to ectopic production of ACTH. The patient has to be evaluated for underlying tumours. 

Other options:

Option A: Pituitary adenoma has elevated levels of cortisol and is normal to high ACTH levels. The pituitary MRI might show the presence of a tumor. CRH test and high-dose dexamethasone tests are positive.

Option B: In bilateral adrenal hyperplasia, there are increased levels of cortisol. However, the ACTH levels are low due to negative feedback to the hypothalamus and pituitary.

Option C: In adrenocortical adenoma also, cortisol levels are associated with a decrease in ACTH levels.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman was about to undergo orthopaedic surgery for fractured calcaneum and her pre-surgery preparation was done. Following this, even before properly inducing the anaesthesia she showed signs of hypoxemia, hypotension, bronchospasm, and rash. Which of the following should you suspect as the most common anaphylactic agent to cause this?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is cephalosporins. Antibiotics are the most common anaphylactic agents during anaesthesia.

The most common precipitating agents are Antibiotics (53%), Neuromuscular blocking agents (33%), and Chlorhexidine (9%). Penicillins and cephalosporins are the most common causes of anaphylaxis among antibiotics.

questions.text: A nursing student uses a modified WHO partograph to monitor the progress of labour in a 39 weeks primigravida woman. Which phase of labour does the nurse need not plot on this partograph?
questions.solution:
Modified WHO Partograph doesn't need plotting of the latent phase of labour.

The reason for excluding the latent phase was more likelihood of interventions due to prolonged latent phase which was overdiagnosed. There was also difficulty reported in transferring the dilatation from latent phase to active phase.

The first stage of labour has got two phases:

  1. Latent phase 
  2. Active phase 

The latent phase of labour is defined as the period between the onset of true labour pain and the point when the cervical dilatation becomes 3–4 cm. The normal duration of the latent phase of labour in a primigravida is about 20 hours (average 8.6 hours) and 14 hours (average 5.3 hours) in a multipara.

The active phase has got three components:

  1. Acceleration phase with cervical dilatation of 3–4 cm.
  2. The phase of maximum slope of 4–9 cm dilatation.
  3. The phase of deceleration of 9–10 cm dilatation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented with burns injury. His face and neck are covered with burns along with both the arms and sides of the chest. He requires both crystalloids and colloid resuscitation. Which of the following will you not follow while resuscitating the patient in the first 24 hours?

choices.text: Human albumin solution (HAS) is  commonly used
Muir and Barclay formula is used for calculation of colloids
Urine output should be between 0.5 to 1 ml/kg body wt/hour
Proteins should be given within the first 12 hours of burn

questions.solution:
Proteins should be given after the first 12 hours of burn because proteins leak out of the cells due to intravascular fluid shifts in the first 12 hours of burn. 

Human albumin solution (HAS) is commonly used for colloid resuscitation.

The most common colloid-based formula is the Muir and Barclay formula. It is calculated as -0.5 × percentage body surface area burnt × weight = one portion.

Urine output is a commonly used parameter to monitor resuscitation and it should be between 0.5 to 1 ml/kg body weight per hour.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: A 45-year-old chronic alcoholic with thiamine deficiency developed lactic acidosis. While on rounds, the senior resident explains the biochemical basis for the development of this condition. He says an important enzyme complex is principally affected. Which of the following is not a component of the enzyme complex being spoken of here?
questions.solution:
The enzyme complex affected in an alcoholic with lactic acidosis is the pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH) enzyme complex. Pyruvate kinase is not a part of this complex. 

The three enzyme components of the PDH complex:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase
  • Dihydrolipoyl transacetylase
  • Dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase

Thiamine is a cofactor of the pyruvate dehydrogenase component of the PDH complex. In thiamine deficiency, pyruvate dehydrogenase is inhibited. Many alcoholics are thiamine deficient because of a poor diet and also because alcohol inhibits thiamine absorption. 

In the state of thiamine deficiency, there is an impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl CoA. This results in the accumulation of pyruvate. Pyruvate then gets converted into lactate by the enzyme lactate dehydrogenase. This results in increased plasma concentrations of lactate and pyruvate, leading to a state of lactic acidosis. 

Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex is a multienzyme complex that is associated with the inner mitochondrial membrane which catalyzes the oxidative decarboxylation of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. The cofactors are:

  • Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)
  • Lipoic acid
  • Coenzyme A
  • Flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)
  • Nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+)

The overall reaction is given as follows: Pyruvate + NAD+ + CoA → Acetyl-CoA + NADH + H+ + CO2

Pyruvate dehydrogenase is inhibited:

  • by its end products- acetyl CoA and NADH.
  • when there is adequate ATP available.
  • when fatty acids are being oxidized.
  • by arsenite and mercuric ions that react with the -SH groups. 
  • by a dietary deficiency of thiamine, e.g. chronic alcoholics and beriberi.

Note- Pyruvate kinase is involved in substrate-level phosphorylation to form 2× ATP per molecule of glucose oxidized. The reaction of pyruvate kinase is essentially irreversible under physiological conditions. It is involved in the regulation of glycolysis.

questions.text: A person experiences heat in her left hand on touching a hot vessel on the stove. In the pathway that carries this sensation of temperature to the brain, the axons of which order neurons cross to the right side?
questions.solution:
In the pathway that carries temperature from the site of sensation to the brain, the axons of second-order neurons cross to the opposite side of the spinal cord.

The pathway that is responsible for conveying the sensations of pain and temperature is the lateral spinothalamic tract. The following are the order of neurons in this tract.

  • First-order neurons - Neurons in the dorsal root ganglia. 
    • These neurons synapse with the neurons in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
  • Second-order neurons - Neurons in the gray matter of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
    • The axons of these neurons cross to the opposite side of the spinal cord at the same level at which the sensation is perceived. They ascend up and synapse with the neurons in the thalamus
  • Third-order neurons - Neurons in the thalamus.
    • Their axons then relay in the postcentral gyrus of the cerebral cortex

questions.text: As a first-year anesthesia resident, you intubate a patient for general anesthesia. After placement of the endotracheal tube, your senior performs capnography, which reveals the following graph. What is the likely possibility?
questions.solution:
The likely possibility causing the above capnographic waveform is oesophagal intubation. In oesophageal intubation, there is an initial peak of the graph showing end-tidal CO2 due to some amount of swallowed expired air present in the stomach. Subsequently, the graph approaches zero due to wash out of this swallowed air in a few breaths.

Capnography is the measurement and graphical representation of the concentration or partial pressure of carbon dioxide at the airway opening. It uses the technique of infrared light absorption by CO2 by the principle of Beer-Lambert law.

The presence of carbon dioxide in the expired air reveals the functioning of the patient's ventilation, pulmonary blood flow and aerobic metabolism. Thus, it can be used to monitor the correct placement of an airway device, the adequacy of cardiac output, as well as the integrity of a breathing circuit. Capnography can be used to: 

  • Confirm tracheal intubation
  • Assess tracheal tube and tracheostomy patency and position
  • Monitor adequate ventilator support
  • Percutaneous tracheostomy placement
  • Monitoring patients with increased intracranial pressure
  • Monitoring response to treatment of bronchospasm
  • Estimation of cardiac output
  • During cardiac arrest

The time capnogram is a type of capnography that displays both inspiratory and expiratory phases. A normal time capnograph is shown below:

questions.text:
During your neonatal rotation, a final year student asks you to explain the score which evaluates the baby at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth. Which among the following is an incorrect statement regarding it?
  1. 1 point is assigned if the baby is pink with blue extremities
  2. 0 points are assigned if the baby is floppy
  3. 2 points are assigned if the pulse is absent 
  4. 1 point is assigned if the respiratory rate is less than 40
  5. 2 points if the baby coughs in response to the insertion of a nasal catheter
questions.solution:
The score which evaluates the baby at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth is the APGAR score, and statements 3 and 4 are incorrect.

The Apgar score is a method of systematically evaluating newborn infants immediately after birth. It measures appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, and respiration. It is performed at 1 minute and again at 5 minutes after birth.

Statements 3 and 4 are incorrect because 0 points are assigned if the pulse is absent, and respiratory rate is not used in calculating the APGAR score, but the respiratory effort is considered.

The maximum score is 10 which indicates the fetus is in the best possible condition. Scores of 0-3 require immediate resuscitation, although resuscitation should ideally be started before the  1-minute APGAR score is calculated. 

APGAR score can be used to assess the response to resuscitative efforts and should be calculated every 5 minutes for up to 20 minutes if the 5-minute Apgar score is less than 7.

Causes of Low APGAR scores include:

  • Fetal distress
  • Prematurity
  • Analgesics, narcotics, sedatives
  • Airway obstruction (Eg: choanal atresia)
  • Pneumonia and sepsis
  • Previous episodes of fetal asphyxia (recovered)

False-negative APGAR score is when the score is normal, but there is acidosis or high fetal catecholamine levels.

Related Pearl: APGAR score

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency room with complaints of blurred vision, difficulty in swallowing, and weakness of limbs for the past 6 hours. The wife says that he consumed some expired canned tuna the previous day.  Samples from the feces are cultured and show the following on gram staining. Which sub-type of the causative organism likely caused this condition?
questions.solution:
The characteristic clinical history of descending flaccid paralysis, dysphagia, diplopia, and gram-positive sporing bacilli seen on staining is suggestive of foodborne botulism caused by Clostridium botulinum. Type E is often associated with fish and other seafood (canned tuna).

The flaccid paralysis is due to the toxin that blocks the release of acetylcholine.

Clostridium Botulinum Toxin types A, B, E, and (rarely) F cause disease in humans. Type C and D cause disease in animals. Type G has been associated with sudden death, but not with neuroparalytic illness. Type E is often associated with fish and other seafood.

Symptoms usually begin 12--36 hours after ingestion. There is no vomiting or diarrhea. Coma or delirium may occur first. 

All the pathogenic effects are caused by a powerful exotoxin produced by the organism. Botulinum toxin acts by blocking the production and release of acetylcholine at the synapses and neuromuscular junction

Site of action: Pre-synaptic neuromuscular junctions, postganglionic parasympathetic nerve endings, and peripheral ganglia.

Clinical use :

  • It is used in the treatment of neuromuscular disorders like strabismus, blepharospasm, wrinkle, myoclonus (since botulism toxin produces flaccid paralysis).
  • The action is short-lasting and recovery occurs in 2-4 months once the new terminal axon sprouts form and restore transmission.
  • Blocking of acetylcholine release from nerve terminal is permanent and recovery occurs only by sprouting of new nerve
    terminals.

Diagnosis:

Laboratory diagnosis is usually established by the demonstration of the bacillus or toxin in food or feces. Gram-positive sporing bacilli may be demonstrated in smears made from the food. C.botulinum may be isolated from the food or the patient's feces.

Treatment:

A prophylactic dose of antitoxin should be given intramuscularly to all who consumed the food article in the case of an outbreak.

Antitoxin may be tried for treatment. Polyvalent antiserum to types A, B, and E may be administered as soon as a clinical diagnosis is made.

questions.text: You are a medical officer at a blood bank. Following a medical camp, you have obtained around 10 units of cryoprecipitate. Which of these conditions cannot be treated with cryoprecipitate?
questions.solution:
Cryoprecipitate can be used in patients with Haemophilia A, von Willebrand disease, hypofibrinogenemia, and factor XIII deficiency as it contains factor VIII, von Willebrand factor, factor XIII and fibrinogen. Cryoprecipitate does not contain factor IX and factor XI. Therefore it cannot be used in patients with hemophilia B and factor XI deficiency.

Cryoprecipitate is prepared from fresh frozen plasma by thawing it to +4°C. The plasma is then centrifuged to obtain cryoprecipitate. It is stored at a temperature of–25°C or colder for up to 1 year after the date of phlebotomy.

During the administration of cryoprecipitate, ABO compatibility should be checked. After thawing, it should be transfused as soon as possible or maximum within 6 hours.

Uses of other blood components

Whole blood- Red cell replacement in acute blood loss with hypovolemia, and exchange transfusion.

Red cell concentrates- In patients with anaemia. Whole blood and red cell concentrates are stored between +2°C and +6°C .

Platelets concentrates- These can be stored up to 5 days at +20°C to +24°C, with agitation. It is used in thrombocytopenia, platelet function defects, disseminated intravascular coagulation, during massive blood transfusion to prevent dilutional thrombocytopenia, and in bone marrow failure.

Fresh frozen plasma- FFP is plasma prepared from whole blood, either from the primary centrifugation of whole blood into red cells and plasma or from secondary centrifugation of platelet rich plasma. It is stored at –25°C or colder for up to 1 year. Before use, it should be thawed in the blood transfusion centre between +30°C and +37°C. It contains stable clotting factors, albumin, immunoglobulin and Factor VIII. It can be used in coagulation factor deficiency, reversing the effects of warfarin, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura, C1 esterase inhibitor deficiency where the specific concentrate is unavailable.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with diarrhoea, steatorrhea, low-grade fever, abdominal pain and joint pains. Colonoscopy is normal. Duodenal biopsy revealed the presence of PAS-positive foamy macrophages containing gram-positive bacilli. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: IV glucocorticoids for 3 days followed by oral glucocorticoids for 1 year
IV meropenem for 2 weeks followed by oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for 1 year

questions.solution:
The clinical features and the duodenal biopsy showing the presence of PAS-positive macrophages containing gram-positive bacilli are suggestive of Whipple's disease. The current regimen for treatment includes intravenous ceftriaxone or meropenem for 2 weeks followed by oral trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) for 1 year.

Whipple's disease is a chronic multisystem disorder caused by a gram-positive bacillus Tropheryma whipplei. It primarily causes malabsorption along with central nervous system & cardiac problems.

The disease has an insidious onset, characterized by diarrhoea, steatorrhea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and migratory large-joint arthropathy. Patients may also have ophthalmologic and CNS symptoms. Few patients who develop a relapse after remission may present with dementia.

The diagnosis of Whipple's disease is made through a biopsy which shows PAS-positive macrophages containing  the gram-positive bacilli in the small intestine.

The treatment regimen includes ceftriaxone 1 g intravenously twice daily or meropenem 1 g intravenously three times daily for 2 weeks. It is followed by trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole 160/800 mg twice daily for 12 months.

Other options:

Option A: The use of IV glucocorticoids for 3 days followed by oral glucocorticoids for 1 year is not included in the management of patients with Whipple's disease.

Option B & D: Numerous randomized controlled trials have proven the failure of remission of patients when treated with tetracyclines or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole when used as monotherapy.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male presents with difficulty in hearing and frequent episodes of tinnitus in his right ear. He adds that the continuous ringing sensation disturbs him and that he is unable to concentrate on his daily chores. On probing further he also complains of occasional imbalance. The tuning fork tests were performed and the findings are summarised as below and cranial nerve examinations are within normal range. The patient was subject to a pure tone audiogram (PTA) which revealed sensorineural hearing loss of the right ear at high frequencies. The brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) findings are given in the image below. An NCCT scan revealed a normal study. What is the likely diagnosis?
Name of the test Right ear Left ear
Rinnes test Positive Positive
Webers test - Lateralized
Schwabach's test Shortened  Normal

Absolute Bone conduction test

 Reduced Normal
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and findings of audiological examinations and investigations are suggestive of right vestibular schwannoma/acoustic neuroma. 

Approach to this question:

Step 1: history: A middle-aged male with progressive hearing difficulty and consistent tinnitus (more in favour of sensorineural hearing loss) should raise the suspicion of an acoustic neuroma or Meniere's disease.

step 2: audiological tuning fork tests: In the given patient, Rinne's test is positive (AC> BC) and this rules out conductive hearing loss. Webers test is lateralised to the left ear (Webers always lateralises to the normal ear in sensorineural hearing loss). To add to this, the Schwabachs test and ABC are also pointing towards sensorineural pathology. 

step 3: Pure tone audiogram: Generally, Pure tone audiometry will show a sensorineural hearing loss, more marked in high frequencies. But in the case of a small intracanalicular tumor, PTA will show only subtle changes in the initial stages. 

step 4: Brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA): There is a significant increase in the inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms between the right (affected) and the left ear.

This specific finding in BERA is more than sufficient enough to land at the diagnosis of vestibular schwannoma. 

Note:

NCCT scan is generally not preferred in cases of vestibular schwannoma. It is very difficult to pick up small lesions of the CP angle and specifically those which have intracanalicular extensions. Generally, in the context where MRI is not feasible CT with iodine contrast is preferred, but even then tumours having at least 5mm of CPA component or those with a minimum size of 1.5cm can be appreciated. (cranial nerve examinations are within the normal range in the patient, so size has to be less than 2.5cm)

Cochleo-vestibular symptoms are the earliest symptoms when the tumour is still intracanalicular and are caused by pressure on vestibular nerve fibres > cochlear nerve fibres or on the internal auditory artery. Imbalance often accompanied by tinnitus, is the presenting symptom in the majority of cases. Patient may also show progressive sensorineural hearing loss. 

 

Acoustic neuroma is a schwannoma more commonly arising from the superior and the inferior division of the vestibular nerve and less commonly from the cochlear nerve, in the medial internal auditory canal at the site of transition of central to peripheral myelin i.e. Obersteiner-Redlich zone.

It is the most common cerebellopontine angle tumour. It is a slow-growing tumour and mostly affects middle-aged and elderly individuals. Bilateral acoustic schwannomas are strongly suggestive of neurofibromatosis type 2. Clinically, patients with acoustic neuroma present with the following features-

  • Cochleovestibular symptoms- They are the earliest symptoms.
    • Progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss with higher frequencies affected first
    • Tinnitus
    • Unsteadiness and imbalance
    • Poor speech discrimination on speech audiometry disproportionate to the hearing loss
    • Absent recruitment phenomenon
    • Roll-over phenomenon- Reduction in discrimination score when loudness is increased beyond a particular limit. 
  • Other cranial nerve involvement
    • Reduced corneal sensitivity, numbness, or paraesthesia of face due to involvement of the trigeminal nerve
    • Hitzelberger’s sign- Hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall when the tumour affects the sensory fibres of the facial nerve
    • Dysphagia and hoarseness due to palatal, pharyngeal and laryngeal paralysis due to glossopharyngeal and vagus nerve involvement. 

MRI with Gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acoustic neuroma. The mass will be seen extending into the intracanalicular portion of the internal acoustic meatus. Extracanalicular extension into the cerebellopontine angle along the path of least resistance can lead to an "ice-cream-cone" appearance.

Surgical removal of the tumor is the treatment of choice. The approach depends on the site and size of the tumor and includes the middle cranial fossa approach, translabyrinthine approach, retrosigmoid/suboccipital approach, or combined approach. External beam radiation is not recommended as it causes significant damage to the surrounding brain and neural structures. Stereotactic radiosurgery is a reasonable alternative for people who refuse/cannot tolerate surgery. Here, beams are modified and focused only to concentrate on the tumor and have little effect on surrounding tissue. It can be done by using X-knife using LINAC, Gamma-knife using Cobalt 60, and Cyber-knife. 

The image below shows the MRI of a patient with acoustic neuroma.

Other options:

Meniere's disease, brain Mets and glomus tumour are all close differentials for vestibular schwannoma. 

1. Meniere's disease is a cochlear pathology and will have delayed wave-I with normal inter-peak latency of I-V in BERA.

2. Glomus tumour is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear.

It is of 2 types:

  • Glomus jugulare: It arises from the dome of the jugular bulb causing neurological signs of IXth to XIIth cranial nerve involvement.
  • Glomus tympanicum: It arises from the promontory of the middle ear and causes aural symptoms, sometimes with facial paralysis.

Also, tinnitus in glomus tumours is pulsatile, Of swishing character, synchronous with pulse and can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure.

Signs in Glomus Tumors

Sign
Seen on
What is seen
Rising sun
Otoscopy
Tumor arising from floor
Brown sign
Otoscopy
On increasing the ear canal pressure, tumor pulsates and then blanches
Phelp sign
CT
Loss of carotico-jugular crest

Investigations would include:

  • Phelp's sign-on CECT scan helps to distinguish glomus tympanicum from the glomus jugulare tumour by identification of caroticojugular spine which is eroded in the latter.
  • MRI gives soft tissue the extent of the tumour.
  • Four vessel angiography is necessary when CT head shows the involvement of jugular bulb, carotid artery or intradural extension.
  • A biopsy is never done since it’s a highly vascular tumour.

3. Brain Mets would be picked up on NCCT as space-occupying lesions.

Related Pearl: Pure tone audiometry (PTA)

A pure tone is the sound of a single frequency. An audiometer is a device that generates pure tones and its frequency can be increased or decreased by 5Hz.

The threshold for air conduction (AC) of sound frequencies from 125-8000 Hz and the threshold for bone conduction (BC) of sound frequencies from 250-4000 Hz is measured and the result is plotted on an audiogram.

Normal thresholds:
  • For AC: 15 dB
  • For BC: 25 dB

Related Pearl: BERA (Brainstem Evoked Response Audiometry) or ABR (Auditory Brainstem Response)

It is an objective test that records electrical activity occurring in the auditory pathway.

Normally, 7 waves are produced in the first 10ms. 

  • Wave I – distal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave II –proximal part of the cochlear nerve
  • Wave III – cochlear nucleus
  • Wave IV – superior olivary complex
  • Wave V – lateral lemniscus
  • Wave VI & VII – inferior colliculus

Findings:

  • Conductive or cochlear pathology- delayed wave-I but inter-peak latency of I-V is normal
  • Retrocochlear pathology- wave-I present, rest of the waves absent
  • Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma- increased inter-peak latency of wave I-V and increased inter-aural latency of wave V > 0.2ms.

Uses:

  • To objectively find hearing threshold- wave-V appears 10dB above the hearing level obtained through PTA
  • Best audiometric test for:
    • Confirming hearing loss in infants
    • Diagnosing acoustic neuroma
    • Differentiating cochlear and retro-cochlear hearing loss
    • Diagnosing non-organic hearing loss.

questions.text:
A group of health workers are conducting a perinatal mortality audit in a hospital. Which of the following must they take into account to calculate the perinatal mortality rate?
  1. No. of live births per year
  2. No. of stillbirths over 1000 g per year
  3. No. of stillbirths after 22 weeks of gestation
  4. No. of early neonatal deaths per year
  5. No. of late neonatal deaths per year
questions.solution:
The perinatal mortality rate (PMR) is calculated using the following parameters during a particular time period:

  • Late fetal deaths or stillbirths > 1000 g - correlates to 28 weeks of gestation
  • Early neonatal deaths - from birth to 7 days of life
  • Live births > 1000 g

The neonatal mortality rate (NMR) refers to the deaths within the first 28 days of life. It is calculated using the following parameters:

  • Early neonatal deaths
  • Late neonatal deaths - after 7th day but before 28th completed day of life

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: A young boy is posted for tonsillectomy. During the preoperative evaluation, it was found that he had increased activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT). However, the platelet counts and prothrombin time (PT) are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has an elevation of activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) with normal prothrombin time (PT) and normal platelet count. This is likely to be due to hemophilia.

Hemophilia is an X-linked recessive hemorrhagic disease due to mutations in the F8 gene (hemophilia A or classic hemophilia) or F9 gene (hemophilia B). It typically affects men, and women are usually asymptomatic. Depending on the residual activity of factor VIII or IX, the manifestations can be mild, moderate, or severe. 

Early in life, the patient may have prolonged bleeding after circumcision, or as intracranial hemorrhages. When the child begins to walk, bleeding into the joint, hemarthrosis is seen. They present as painful swelling and reddening of the knee, elbow, ankle, shoulder, or hips. 

Laboratory investigations will show elevated aPTT, with normal PT and platelet count. It is treated with the administration of factor VIII or factor IX concentrates.

Prothrombin time- measures the integrity of extrinsic and common pathways. It measures factors VII, fibrinogen, II (prothrombin), V, and X.

Activated partial thromboplastin time, aPTT, measures intrinsic pathways. It measures factors VIII, IX, XI, and XII, I (fibrinogen), II (prothrombin), V, and X.

Elevated aPTT with normal PT and platelet count is seen in factor XI and factor XII deficiency, hemophilia, von Willebrand disease, an inhibitor to factor VIII, lupus anticoagulant, presence of heparin, etc.

Elevated PT with normal aPTT and platelet count is seen in factor VII deficiency and oral anticoagulant therapy.

Elevated PT and aPTT with normal platelet count are seen if there is any defect in the common pathway. It is seen in afibrinogenemia; deficiencies of factors II, V, and X; and deficiency of vitamin K–dependant factors. 

Elevated PT and aPTT with low platelet counts are seen in disseminated intravascular coagulation, liver disease, and lupus anticoagulant.
