questions.text: The skeleton remains of an unidentified body were brought to the forensic department for identification. The skull had bull-teeth, where the pulp cavity of molars was found to be wide and deep, and the roots were fused and bent. There was also a lack of the third upper molar. What race do you think the skeletal remains belong to?
questions.solution:
The condition of bull-tooth or ‘taurodontism’ suggests that the skeletal remains most probably belonged to a person from the Mongoloid race.

In bull-teeth, the pulp cavity of molars is wide and deep, and the roots are fused and bent. A congenital lack of the third upper molar is most common in Mongoloids. In Mongoloid teeth, enamel pearls, small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface, are much more frequent. 

 Features of Mongoloid dentition

  • Shovel-shaped upper central incisors - Posterior surfaces of these teeth have a depression centrally
  • Enamel pearls - Small nodules of enamel on the tooth surface
  • The pulp cavity of molars is wide and deep
  • A congenital lack of the third upper molar is common but nonspecific.

Other options-

Option (B): Caucasian race-  the lateral incisors in the upper jaw are usually smaller than the central. They also have long pointed canine roots. Small nodules on the lingual surface of maxillary molars, called ‘Carabelli’s cusp’, are most common in Caucasian races.

Option (C): Negroid races tend to have large teeth and often have more cusps on their molars, even up to eight, with two lingual cusps on the mandibular first premolars as an additional common finding.

Option (D): Aboriginal races tend to have large teeth with wide crowns. They do not show taurodontism.

questions.text: A registered medical practitioner is requested by a survivor of sexual violence to examine her. Within what time must the practitioner take a vaginal swab to look for the presence of spermatozoa?
questions.solution:
A vaginal swab of a rape victim demonstrates spermatozoa if the vaginal swab is taken within 72 hours after an assault.

However, a vaginal swab can be taken within 96 hours to demonstrate semen. 

Evidence on the outside of the body and on materials such as clothing can be collected even after 96 hours.

questions.text: A G2P1 woman has presented to the hospital in active labor. You conduct the delivery and now proceed to the active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL). Which of the following is  recommended in active management of the third stage of labor according to WHO:

choices.text: Early cord clamping to prevent blood loss
Sustained uterine massage to prevent atony

questions.solution:
Postpartum abdominal uterine tone assessment is recommended according to the WHO guidelines for active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL). 

AMTSL recommended by WHO :

  • Immediate administration of prophylactic uterotonic (Oxytocin). Oxytocin 10 IU is given IM or IV.
  • Controlled cord traction during placental delivery (in cesarean section and in vaginal birth where skilled birth attendants are present)
  • Delayed cord clamping
  • Postpartum abdominal uterine tonus assessment for early identification of uterine atony is recommended for all women. Continuous monitoring of uterine tone is done every 15 minutes for 2 hours. If uterine atony is detected, a fundal massage is performed.

Uterine massage is not recommended routinely.

The goal of this is to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). Hence, uterotonics are the most important factor to decrease PPH. Delayed cord clamping is a less important component in this direction and similarly, cord traction is not as critical. Uterine massage does not form the main component of AMTSL.

questions.text: You are working in the intensive care unit. Your resident asks you to perform arterial blood sampling in a patient. Which of the following steps you should not do?

choices.text: Pull back the syringe plunger to collect blood
Ask the patient to relax his fist
Transport the sample in container containing crushed ice

questions.solution:
During arterial blood sampling, we should not pull back the syringe plunger.

Arterial blood sampling

Materials required

  • Preheparinised syringe
  • Needles (20, 23 and 25 gauge)
  • A safety syringe with a needle cover
  • A bandage to cover the puncture site after collection
  • A container with crushed ice for transportation of the sample

Procedure

Approach the patient, introduce yourself and ask the patient to state their full name. Make the patient lie on his/her back comfortably. If the patient is clenching their fist, holding their breath or crying, this can alter the test results.

Locate the radial artery and performing an Allen test to check for collateral circulation. If the collateral circulation is poor, choose other hand for blood sampling.

Perform hand hygiene, clean the sampling site with 70% ethyl alcohol and allow it to dry. Assemble the needle and heparinised syringe. Pull the syringe plunger to the required fill level. 

Hold the syringe like a dart and palpate the radial pulse with the index finger. Once the pulse is localised, insert the needle into the artery at 45 degrees, approximately 1 cm distal to the index finger. Once the needle reaches the radial artery, blood flashes in the syringe. Allow the syringe to fill to the appropriate level. Do not pull back the syringe plunger.

Withdraw the needle and syringe. Place a clean, dry piece of gauze or cotton wool over the site and have the patient or an assistant apply firm pressure for sufficient time to stop the bleeding.

Remove the air bubble if present within the syringe. Place the sample in a container containing crushed ice if the analysis is not done in the point of care.

 

Below gif shows Allen's test used to assess collateral circulation in the hand before performing arterial sampling.

On examination, the temperature is 38 °C, pulse rate - 110/min, respiratory rate - 20/min, BP- 120/78 mm of Hg. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness in the right iliac fossa. He was subjected to the evaluation of complete blood count, the findings of which are given below. What is the Alvarado score in this patient?

questions.solution:
The young male patient with vomiting, fever, and abdominal pain is likely to have acute appendicitis. The symptoms in the order of pain followed by vomiting and fever constitute Murphy’s triad of appendicitis. The Alvarado Score is 8.

Appendicitis:

Acute appendicitis begins as periumbilical pain, which is a visceral pain followed by anorexia and nausea; then, the pain shifts to the right lower quadrant due to peritoneal irritation.

Clinical features :

  • The classical features of acute appendicitis begin with poorly localized colicky abdominal pain.
  • This is due to midgut visceral discomfort in response to appendiceal inflammation and obstruction.
  • The pain is frequently first noticed in the periumbilical region.
  • The patient often gives a history of similar discomfort that settled spontaneously. Family history is also useful as up to one-third of children with appendicitis have a first-degree relative with a similar history.

Symptoms of appendicitis

  • Periumbilical colic
  • Pain shifting to the right iliac fossa
  • Anorexia
  • Nausea 

Clinical signs in appendicitis

  • Pyrexia
  • Localised tenderness in the right iliac fossa
  • Muscle guarding
  • Rebound tenderness
  • Pointing sign, Rovsing's sign, Psoas sign, Obturator sign are some of the signs to be elicited in a patient with appendicitis.

The Alvarado Scoring System is the clinical scoring system used in the diagnosis of appendicitis.

In children, ultrasound is the imaging of choice while in adults, the best imaging modality is a CT scan.

The management of patients can be based on Alvarado score which is summed up in the pearl attached below.

If the score is 4-6, an an adjunctive CT scan would be recommended to confirm the diagnosis.

If the score is 7 or higher, surgery is recommended.

questions.text: The given blood smear shows a characteristic cell type. What is the cell of origin in this condition?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is adult T cell leukemia/lymphoma caused by human T cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1). The peripheral smear given above shows tumor cells with multilobulated nuclei (“cloverleaf” or “flower” cells) which is characteristic of Adult T-Cell Leukemia/Lymphoma. The cell of origin is helper T cells/CD4+ T cells.

Adult T-Cell Leukemia/Lymphoma (CD4+):

  • It is observed in adults infected by human T cell leukemia retrovirus type 1 (HTLV-1)
  • It is characterized by skin lesions, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, peripheral blood lymphocytosis, and hypercalcemia.
  • Peripheral smear shows cells with multilobulated nuclei (“cloverleaf” or “flower” cells)
  • A rapidly progressive disease that is fatal within months to 1 year.

The HTLV-1 genome contains the gag, pol, env, and long terminal-repeat regions typical of all retroviruses, but, in contrast to other leukemia viruses, it contains two other genes referred to as tax and HBZ.

Tax : It is essential for viral replication because it stimulates transcription of viral RNA from the 5′ long terminal repeat.

HBZ:  It is a transcription factor

Tax and HBZ, together alter the transcription of host cell genes and interact with certain host cell signaling proteins. This leads to the acquisition of cancer hallmarks.

Other options :

Neoplasms that have Memory B cells as the cell of origin include Extranodal marginal zone lymphoma and Hairy cell leukemia

Naive B cells are the cell of origin in Mantle cell lymphoma.

In Anaplastic large-cell lymphoma, Cytotoxic T cells are the cells of origin.

questions.text: In a study, group A received placebo while group B received a new drug. In group A,  36 deaths were reported out of a sample of 120. In group B, 26 deaths were reported out of a sample size of 130. How many patients should be treated to avert 1 death?
questions.solution:
10 patients need to be treated with the new drug to avert 1 death.
 
The number needed to treat (NNT) is defined as the number of individuals to be treated with the new drug to prevent 1 death (or to save 1 life).
 
NNT = 100/ARR
 
Where, ARR is the absolute risk reduction, which is the difference in the absolute risk rates between the placebo group and drug group. The absolute risk is usually expressed in percentage.
 
ARR = (No. of deaths/Sample population) x 100
 
Calculation:
 
Step 1: Calculation of absolute risk rate
 
The absolute risk rate in group A (placebo)
= (36/120)x100
= 30%
 
The absolute risk rate in group B (new drug)
= (26/130)x100
= 20%
 
Step 2: Calculation of absolute risk reduction (ARR)
 
ARR = Absolute risk rate in group A - Absolute risk rate in group B
= 30 - 20
= 10%
 
Step 3: Calculation of number needed to treat
 
NNT = 100/ARR
= 100/10
= 10
 
Therefore, 10 individuals need to be treated with the new drug to save 1 life.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the clinic with a constant ringing sensation in his left ear. He has had these symptoms for the past 3 months with a progressive decrease in hearing in the same ear. He also complains that he has dizziness occasionally. On oral administration of glycerol, the patient reports improvement in hearing in his left ear. He has been prescribed a drug that is supposed to dilate blood vessels in his ears. What is the mechanism of action of this drug? ( H refers to Histamine)
questions.solution:
The presenting symptoms along with improvement in hearing with Glycerol test narrows down to diagnosis of Meniere's disease and Betahistine is used to treat vertigo in Meniere's disease.

Betahistine is a selective H1 agonist. It causes vasodilation in the inner ear which improves circulation. 

Meniere's disease (MD) or endolymphatic hydrops is a disorder of the inner ear caused by impaired endolymph resorption. It is characterized by an episodic sudden onset of vertigo, low-frequency hearing loss (in the early stages of the disorder), low-frequency roaring tinnitus, and sensation of fullness in the affected ear

Glycerol test is done in Meniere's disease.

  • Glycerol is a dehydrating agent.
  • When given orally, it reduces endolymph pressure and thus causes an improvement in hearing.
  • The test has a diagnostic and prognostic value.
  • These days, glycerol test is combined with electrocochleography.

Betahistine (Vertin), used in the medical management of Meniere's disease acts by causing dilatation of the labyrinthine blood vessels, thereby improving the microvascular circulation in the stria vascularis of the cochlea. It is also found to inhibit vestibular nuclei activity.

Side-effects:

It is contraindicated in asthmatics and ulcer patients

Other drugs used in the medical management of Meniere's disease are

  • Prochlorperazine (stemetil), is a vestibular sedative.
  • Diazepam (Valium or Calmpose) 5–10 mg may be given intravenously. It has a tranquillizing effect and also suppresses the activity of the medial vestibular nucleus.
  • In some patients, an acute attack can be stopped by atropine, 0.4 mg, given subcutaneously
  • Diuretics such as furosemide and hydrochlorothiazide are used to control recurrent attacks.
  • Propantheline bromide (probanthine), an anticholinergic agent is also found to be effective.

questions.text: A psychiatric patient with a history of bipolar disorder is brought by her relatives. They give a history suggestive of an acute manic episode. She is already on lithium therapy and the serum lithium levels are measured to be 0.2 mEq/L. What steady-state concentration will you be aiming to achieve in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing increased activity, energy, and euphoria with a decreased need for sleep is indicative of an acute manic episode for which a steady-state concentration of 0.8 - 1.2 mEq/L of lithium has to be achieved for adequate treatment.

Lithium is used in the management of bipolar disorder, and mania, and has anti-suicidal properties. It has a narrow therapeutic index, and blood levels in excess of this may cause symptoms of toxicity. Therapeutic drug monitoring is done by measuring lithium levels 12 hours after the last dose.

Lithium therapy for acute mania:

  • Three individual 10-mg/kg doses of a sustained-release preparation administered at 2-h intervals.
  • The sustained-release form is used to minimize GI adverse effects (e.g., nausea, diarrhea)
  • Subsequent treatment may then be continued with Li+ carbonate.

Steady state-concentrations for therapy :

  • For maintainance therapy in bipolar disorder - 0.5-0.8 mEq/L
  • For episodes of acute mania - 0.8-1.2 mEq/L
  • Toxic levels - >1.5 mEq/L

The blood sample for serum lithium estimation is to be collected after a time interval of 10-12 hours from the previous dose of lithium which is used to estimate the steady-state concentration.

Known significant side effects of lithium therapy include

  • Polyuria-polydipsia (nephrogenic diabetes insipidus)
  • Hand tremors
  • Confusion 
  • ECG changes
  • Psoriasis
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Diarrhea

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy

Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with complaints of fatigue, vomiting, abdominal cramps and bone pain. She had undergone total parathyroidectomy and heterotopic autotransplantation for the same complaints 8 months ago. Sestamibi scan was done and found to be normal. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Post her for bilateral neck exploration
Label her as persistent hyperparathyroidism and start her on medical management

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of recurrent hyperparathyroidism which could be due to recurrence in the neck or graft (graft hyperplasia). The next step would be to perform Casnova test to differentiate between them, as Sestamibi scan has ruled out ectopic parathyroid.

Casanova test involves selective venous sampling for PTH levels from neck veins and brachial veins. If PTH from the brachial venous sample is >20 times that of neck vein sample, graft hyperplasia is confirmed.

Persistent parathyroidism is defined as hypercalcemia that fails to resolve after parathyroidectomy i.e. within 6 weeks of surgery. Recurrent parathyroidism is hyperparathyroidism that occurs after an intervening period of at least 6 months of biochemically documented normocalcemia. Causes of persistent/recurrent hyperparathyroidism include:

  • Ectopic parathyroid
  • Unrecognized hyperplasia - graft site hyperplasia
  • Missed adenoma in normal position
  • Incomplete resection
  • Familial hyperparathyroidism
  • MEN-1 syndrome

The image below summarises the management protocol for a case of persistent/recurrent hyperparathyroidism.

*FHH stands for Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia

questions.text: You are a biochemist working on various cytogenetic abnormality. You use the following cytogenetic technique to study the abnormality from a tissue specimen. Which of the following cytogenetic abnormality cannot be picked up by this technique?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an array - comparative genomic hybridization (CGH). This cytogenetic technique cannot detect balanced translocation.

Array-based Comparative Genomic Hybridization:

In array CGH, two genomes are compared. The test DNA and the reference DNA are labeled with two different fluorescent dyes (red and green respectively) and are added to a DNA chip spotted with the entire human genome.

  • If the contribution of both samples is equal for a given chromosomal region, then all spots on the array will fluoresce yellow.
  • If the test sample has amplification, that spot will fluoresce red
    • If the test sample has a deletion, that spot will fluoresce green

Uses of Array CGH:

  • To detect gene amplification
  • To detect gene deletion 
  • To detect copy number variations

Limitations:

Cannot detect balanced translocations. Reason being as follows:

If there is less DNA in the patient than the control for a particular probe, the a-CGH will show a deletion of material from the patient for that particular locus; if there is more DNA in the patient than the control for a particular probe, the a-CGH will show a gain of material from the patient for that locus. In a balanced translocation, there is no gain or loss of material, so the probes will show that the patient and the control have equal amounts of DNA in those translocated regions.

Other methods for molecular analysis of genetic alterations include:

  • Fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH)
  • Southern blotting
  • SNP - single nucleotide polymorphisms genotyping arrays
  • Multiple ligation dependant probe assays (MLPA)

Comparison of different cytogenetic techniques:

Method Required growing of cells Detects deletions and duplications Detects balanced structural re-arrangements Detects uniparental disomy Lower limits of deletions
G Banding YES YES YES NO 5-10 mb
Metaphase FISH YES YES YES NO 40-250 thousand mb
Interphase FISH NO YES SOME NO 40-250 thousand mb
CGH Array NO YES NO NO single exon or single gene
SNP array NO YES NO SOME single exon or single gene

Related Pearl: Fluorescent In Situ Hybridisation (FISH)

It is a simple technique for the detection of specific genetic information on a morphologically intact tissue using fluorescent probes.

The fluorescent probes are added to cells usually arrested in the metaphase stage of cell division (when every chromosome is separately).

Types of FISH:

1) Chromosomal painting: Each chromosome is identified by using a different colour of the fluorescent probe, however, each chromosome does not have a unique colour. Since the fluorescent dyes are limited.

2) Multicolour FISH: 23 distinct fluorescent colours made by mixing 5 fluorophores. Thus each chromosome is identified by a unique colour. It is also known as spectral karyotyping (SKY). It offers various advantages such as

  • Detects structural and numeric abnormalities in chromosomes.
  • Detects gene amplification and subtle microdeletions
  • Maps a newly isolated gene to its correct chromosomal loci

However, this process requires prior knowledge of the genes and chromosomes.

3) Interphase FISH: It is a rapid procedure of FISH, wherein growing cells are not needed. It is used in prenatal diagnosis and in tumour diagnosis.

The image shown is of a Multicolor FISH also known as Spectral karyotyping with a unique colour to each chromosome pair.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man came with abdominal cramps, nausea, diarrhea for the past two days. He also reports having body pain, a runny nose, and teary eyes. On examination, his pupils are dilated and he frequently keeps yawning. On probing further, he reluctantly says that he uses recreational drugs. His blood pressure is 150/80 mm Hg and his heart rate is 110. Which of the following drugs is used for the maintenance therapy for his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Methadone is used for the maintenance of opioid (heroin) dependence as a substitute therapy because of its good oral bioavailability and long half-life. 

Methadone is substituted for opioids during detoxification to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Once stabilized, the dose is gradually reduced and the drug is stopped slowly over days. Because of its long half-life and accumulation in tissues, discontinuing the drug still results in low concentrations of the drug in plasma resulting in protracted withdrawal symptoms.

Treatment for opioid dependence

Maintainance phase: to decrease the severity of withdrawal symptoms.

  • Oral mu agonist: a safe substitute like methadone is given in a supervised manner to prevent withdrawal symptoms.
  • Long acting agonist: buprenorphine can also be used.
  • Clonidine, lofexidine reduce the withdrawal symptoms and anxiety
  • Methadone, buprenorphine, LAAM(L-Alpha-Acetyl-Methadol): opioid agonists which reduce craving.

Relapse prevention phase:

  • Naltrexone: An opioid antagonist that blocks opioid effects.

Other options:

Option A- Methylmorphine (codeine)is an opioid agonist used for the relief of severe chronic cancer pain and suppression of cough. 

Option C- Meperidine belongs to a class of opioid analgesics and is similar to morphine. It is used to treat moderate to severe pain. 

Option D- Methylphenidate is a stimulant used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the hospital due to hoarseness of voice and dyspnea. Laryngoscopic examination revealed that the vocal cords were in the paramedian position. The woman is diagnosed with a nerve palsy. Which of the following is the most common cause of this kind of palsy?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features are suggestive of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy. Surgical trauma is the most common cause for bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis.

The incidence of permanent RLN paralysis is approximately 1% to 1.5% for total thyroidectomy and less for near-total procedures. Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy presents with hoarseness, and in severe cases aphonia. Since it supplies the posterior cricoarytenoid muscles which is the only abductor of the vocal cords, damage to this nerve results in the cord being in a paramedian position.

A 20-year retrospective study of causes of vocal fold immobility shows that neck surgery has become the most common cause of vocal fold paralysis over the past 10 years.

Note : Previously, extralaryngeal malignancies had been the most common cause which included Lung (50%), Oesophagus, Thyroid, Larynx.

questions.text:
Match the following braces to the appropriate clinical scenarios.
  1. A 13-year-old girl with a scoliotic curve beginning at T10
  2. A 12-year-old girl with a single thoracolumbar scoliotic curve to wear while sleeping
  3. A 40-year-old recovering from Dorso-lumbar surgery
  4. A 20-year-old man with a cervical spine injury 
  1. Boston brace
  2. Milwaukee brace
  3. Charleston brace
  4. SOMI brace
  5. ASHE brace

 Abbreviations: ASHE (anterior spinal hyperextension), SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer)
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-A, 2-C, 3-E, 4-D.

A 13-year-old girl with a scoliotic curve beginning at T10 should be provided with a Boston brace. It is the commonest brace prescribed for scoliosis and is a type of thoraco-lumbo-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace). It has a hard polypropylene outer shell with a soft foam lining inside. The Boston brace works by applying corrective pressure on the convex side of the curve. It is used in patients whose scoliosis curve apex is at T7 or lower. 

Boston brace is also available as a Cervical TLSO brace - which is a TLSO with a neck extension. It is used for the correction of a high thoracic curve.

Wilmington Brace is another common TLSO brace that is custom-fitted based on a cast taken of the patient in the supine position. The brace fits onto the body like a tight jacket, known as a full-contact TLSO. There are no gaps or open spots.

 

A 12-year-old girl with a single thoracolumbar scoliotic curve to wear while sleeping should be provided with a Charleston bending brace. It is the most commonly prescribed nighttime brace. It is custom-fitted based and is intended to be worn while lying down. It applies lateral force to the spine, pushing the curve closer to the midline and holds it in an overcorrected position. 

Providence Brace is similar to the Charleston brace. It applies a hypercorrective force on the spine while lying down. It slightly elevates one shoulder and directly applies lateral and rotational forces on the curve (or both curves if it is a double curve).

 

A 40-year-old recovering from Dorso-lumbar surgery should be provided with an ASHE brace (anterior spinal hyperextension brace).  A hyperextension brace will take the pressure off the weak vertebrae and limit forward bending. 

A 20-year-old man with a cervical spine injury should be treated with a SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) brace. It is a rigid cervical brace that positions the neck in alignment with the spine and immobilizes it. The SOMI brace may be used as a treatment for cervical spine injury or for cervical pain due to a chronic condition, such as rheumatoid arthritis. It may also be prescribed after cervical spine surgery as a recovery aid.

Other options: 

Milwaukee brace is the originally designed cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO) introduced in the 1940s. It is less commonly used nowadays due to the convenience of modern braces. It is still used for scoliosis with curves in the high thoracic and cervical spine.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented to the dermatology OPD with umbilicated papules on his lower abdomen and inner thighs. History reveals that he is sexually active and the presence of similar lesions on his sexual partner. Microscopic examination of material expressed from the papule shows the following. Which of the following is the most probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given microscopic image shows large (up to 35 μm), ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum classically seen in molluscum contagiosum where the sexually transmitted type is MCV - 2.

Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limited viral disease of the skin or mucous membrane caused by a poxvirus. Poxvirus is brick-shaped and is about 300 nm in size, the largest pathogenic poxvirus in humans. There are 4 types of molluscum contagiosum virus (MCVs) - MCV-1 to -4. The most prevelent is MCV-1 and MCV-2 is most often sexually transmitted.

Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, pink to skin-colored umbilicated papules. A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication

Tzanck smear: intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson–Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30–35 μm)

Microscopic examination: Cuplike verrucous epidermal hyperplasia and Molluscum bodies: large (up to 35 μm), ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum.

Molluscum bodies contain numerous virions.

The below image shows the characteristic skin lesions which is the mainstay for diagnosis.

questions.text: Shown in the image below is a congenital heart condition. Which among the following represents its characteristic radiological appearance on a chest X-ray?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the transposition of great arteries (TGA), and egg-on-string appearance is the characteristic radiological sign on chest X-rays. The image shows the aorta arising from the right ventricle and the pulmonary arteries arising from the left ventricle.

Chest x-rays may show mild cardiomegaly, a narrow mediastinum (the classic egg-shaped heart or egg on a string appearance), with normal to increased pulmonary blood flow.

Egg-on-a-string appearance refers to a globular-shaped heart due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, and therefore appears like an egg.

ECHO is diagnostic. The size of the interatrial communication and the ductus arteriosus, the degree of mixing assessed, any associated ventricular outflow tract obstruction, or a septal defect, can be assessed by color Doppler examination. 

Pathology of TGA: The deoxygenated blood returning from the body goes inappropriately out the aorta and back to the body again, while oxygenated pulmonary venous blood is returned directly to the lungs. Survival in the immediate neonatal period is due to the mixture of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood provided by the foramen ovale and the ductus arteriosus. 50% of patients also have a ventricular septal defect (VSD).

TGA is the most specific heart disease in infants of diabetic mothers. 

Other options:

Option A: Box-shaped heart is seen in Ebstein's anomaly. There is severe right-sided cardiomegaly due to an elongated and enlarged right atrium which leads to an elevated apex. 

Option B: Snowman heart is seen in total anomalous pulmonary venous return. It refers to the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resembling a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign.

Option C: Gooseneck sign: Seen on left lateral angiograms in endocardial cushion defects.

questions.text:
A man was brought unconscious to the casualty ward following a head injury. His GCS was 5 but his CT was normal. MRI showed multiple small hemorrhages in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain with no midline shift. The patient died after 48 hours and his body was sent for post-mortem. Which of the following statements regarding the patient's disease condition is true?
  1. The patient had diffuse axonal injury.
  2. It is caused due to stretching of axons due to sudden deceleration injuries.
  3. Several focal subcortical grey matter lesions of 1-15 mm can be seen.
  4. Histopathology sections will reveal retraction balls on congo red staining.
  5. Immunohistochemistry will be positive for beta-amyloid precursor protein.
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, 4, and 5 are true. 

A patient with a head injury having a poor Glasgow Coma Score (GCS), normal findings on CT scan, and evidence of hemorrhages on MRI is likely to have diffuse axonal injury. 

Diffuse axonal injury is a form of primary brain injury seen in high-energy accidents. It is caused by damage to axons throughout the brain due to rotational acceleration followed by deceleration. There is disruption and shearing of axons leading to microhemorrhages.

Diffuse axonal injury typically consists of several focal white-matter lesions measuring 1-15 mm in a characteristic distribution. CT may be normal. Small hemorrhages can be seen in more severe cases, especially on MRI (investigation of choice). Hemorrhages are classically seen in the corpus callosum and the dorsolateral midbrain.

The earliest microscopic evidence for diffuse axonal injury is 'retraction balls/globes' which appear 12-18 hours after injury. This can be appreciated using the congo red stain.

Immunohistochemistry marker with beta-amyloid precursor protein is considered to be the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours.  

The prognosis is very poor. It results in a persistent vegetative state after severe head trauma.

Related Pearl: Diffuse Axonal Injury

The mechanism of diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration injury. This leads to the deformation of the axons by stretching them.

Pathology of DAI:

  • Changes in permeability of the axolemma
  • Axonal swelling
  • Intracellular calcium accumulation
  • Proteolysis
  • The collapse of the cytoskeleton
  • 'Retraction balls or globes' - bulbous and clubbed axons. Seen earliest at 12-18 hours. The number of retraction balls begins to decrease after 2-3 weeks after injury and a cluster of microglial cells appears followed by astrocytosis and demyelination.
  • Immuno-histochemistry shows beta-amyloid precursor protein - the most reliable indicator of axon damage. Seen earliest at 2-3 hours. 

Image shows scattered axonal retraction balls stained with Congo Red:

questions.text: An elderly patient was started with metformin therapy for the newly diagnosed type 2 diabetes mellitus. However, after 3 months, there was no significant decline in the HbA1c levels. The doctor decides to start injectable exenatide for this patient. This drug is an analogue of a hormone that is released in our gastrointestinal system. Which of the following will not be seen during this therapy?

choices.text: Increased release of insulin from the pancreas

questions.solution:
Exenatide is a glucagon-like peptide-1 analogue known to cause delayed gastric emptying.

 Glucagon-like peptides are derived from proglucagon and are secreted by intestinal L cells. They are released after the meals. Their main actions are

  • Stimulate insulin secretion leading to decreased blood sugar levels
  • Inhibit glucagon release
  • Delay gastric emptying
  • Decrease food intake leading to weight loss

These peptides are inactivated by dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4). 

Clinical correlate—GLP-1 receptor agonists have been used in the treatment of diabetes mellitus. They are exenatide, liraglutide, albiglutide, dulaglutide, lixisenatide, etc. Because they cause weight loss, they can be used in the management of diabetes in obese patients. Since they are peptide hormones, they are metabolised if given orally and must be given through a percutaneous route.

Dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors, such as alogliptin, linagliptin, saxagliptin, sitagliptin, and vildagliptin, have also been used in the management of diabetes mellitus. These inhibitors increase the plasma concentrations of GLP-1 and its analogues.

questions.text:
Identify the medical presentations associated with the deliriant poison derived from the plant given below.
  1. Magnan syndrome
  2. Amotivational syndrome
  3. Run amok
  4. Nasal septum ulceration
  5. Loss of self-respect
questions.solution:
The given plant is Erythroxylum coca. Cocaine is the principal alkaloid found in the cultivated varieties of coca. The correct answer is 1, 4, and 5 only.

Cocaine is a CNS stimulant. CNS stimulation (anxiety, hyperactivity), CVS overactivity (tachycardia, hypertension), and increased respiratory rate are seen in poisoning with cocaine causing sympathetic toxidrome.

The water-soluble form (-hydrochloride) can be injected or snorted. Tattoos may be made to cover the injection marks. Whilst another form (-sulfate) can be smoked. It gives a cracking sound when burnt. It inhibits the uptake of dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin. It thus, enhances the action of these neurotransmitters.

It causes digestive disturbances, anorexia, salivation, tachycardia, tachypnoea, and insomnia. The face is pale, eyes sunken, pupils dilated, and the gaze is shifty. 
 
Magnan's syndrome or cocaine bugs is a characteristic feature in which there is a feeling as if grains of sand are under the skin or as if small insects are creeping on the skin, giving rise to an itching sensation (formication, tactile hallucination) and resultant excoriation, which leads to irregular scratches and ulcers.
 
It is a drug of addiction and causes a lowering of moral tone and loss of decency and self-respect. Sniffing habits leads to nasal septum ulceration.

Initial management involves the administration of activated charcoal and gastric lavage if it has been ingested.

Treatment involves the administration of benzodiazepines to control heart rate/ seizures, propranolol to control cardiac arrhythmia, and haloperidol to treat psychosis. Counseling needs to be done to avoid resisting the urge for repetitive usage.

  • Amotivational syndrome - Chronic use of Cannabis may lead to amotivational syndrome with lethargy, and lack of interest in day-to-day activities.
  • Run-amok - Run-amok is a psychic disturbance resulting from the continued use or sudden consumption of Cannabis and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania. The person is not held responsible for his acts since ‘run amok’ is considered a disorder of mind and not intoxication.

questions.text: You undertake a research project where you compare the attack rate of people vaccinated by Covishield and Covaxin. You adopt the Chi-square test to assess the significance of the difference between the two proportions. What is the first step employed in this method?
questions.solution:
The first step of the Chi-square test is to test the null hypothesis.

The Chi-square (x2) Test is a method of testing the significance of difference between two proportions. It has the advantage that it can also be used when more than two groups are to be compared.

The first step is to test the null hypothesis: a hypothesis is set up that there was no difference between the effect of the two vaccines (in this particular scenario) and then proceed to test the hypothesis in quantitative terms such as observed and expected values.

This is then used to apply the χ2 test for which a formula is used. 

This is followed by finding the degree of freedom using the number of rows and columns in the initial table.

The values of the last two steps are used to plot probability tables. The values from these tables are used to compare with the null hypothesis to test the significance of difference between the two proportions.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A patient is being evaluated for irresistible sleepiness that leads to uncontrollable episodes of sleep that last for 10-20 minutes during the day. A test specifically for diagnosing this condition is performed during the first 2 hours after waking up in the morning. It involves the measurement of 3 parameters which are also measured in polysomnography (shown in the image below). Identify them.
questions.solution:
The condition described is narcolepsy, diagnosed with the Multiple Sleep Latency Test which measures the electro-oculographic, electroencephalographic and sub­ mental electromyography activity, ie., A, B, and C are included in the test.

Narcolepsy is characterized by excessive sleepi­ness leading to sleep attacks, which are episodes of irresist­ible sleepiness, leading to 10 - 20 minutes of sleep, following which the patient feels briefly refreshed. These attacks can occur at inappropriate times such as during eating, talking, driv­ing, or during sex. It may be associated with hypnagogic and hypnopompic hallucinations, cataplexy, and sleep paralysis during REM sleep. 

Multiple sleep latency test (MSLT):  It is indicated for diagnosing narcolepsy. The test is done in the first 2 hours after waking up in the morning. 20-min­ute nap opportunities are provided where the patient is instructed to avoid resisting falling asleep. MSLT should be performed after a full-night polysomnogram to ensure that at least 6 hours of sleep precede the test and that no other causes for excessive daytime sleepiness are present. Electroencephalographic, electro-oculographic, and sub­ mental electromyography activity is recorded to determine sleep stage. The latency to sleep is used to assess the level of sleepiness.

If the patient falls asleep on a given nap opportunity, the nap is terminated 15 minutes after initial sleep onset. If the patient does not fall asleep, the session is terminated after 20 minutes of recording. Five nap opportunities are provided at 2-hour intervals across the day.

The appearance of REM sleep on two or more nap opportuni­ties confirms narcolepsy.
 
The image below shows records from a multiple sleep latency test (MSLT) with the appearance of 2 episodes of REM sleep during the nap opportunities, confirming the diagnosis of narcolepsy.

Tools in Sleep Medicine:

  • Polysomnography: A recording of the physiological changes that occur during sleep, that is typically recorded at night and lasts 6 - 8 hours. It involves the measurement of :
    • Brain wave activity
    • Eye move­ments
    • Submental electromyography activity
    • Nasal-oral airflow
    • Respiratory effort
    • Oxyhemoglobin saturation
    • Heart rhythm
    • Leg movements
    • Body position and snoring sounds may also be recorded
  • Maintenance of Wakefulness Test: It provides 40-minute test sessions at 2-hour intervals across the day where the patient is instructed to try to remain awake. It is used to assess the response to treatment and is part of "fit for duty" testing. Any sleep latency of fewer than 8 minutes is abnormal.
  • Actigraphy: An actigraph is a device that measures and records movement, which is worn on the wrist. It is used as a rough measure of the sleep-wake cycle and is useful for assessing insom­nia, circadian rhythm disorders, and movement disorders.
  • Home sleep testing involves recording cardiopulmonary parameters such as airflow, respiratory effort, heart rhythm and oximetry. Snoring sounds are also recorded. It is used to assess patients for sleep-related breathing disorders.

2. A married woman bought dead with 3rd-degree burns on her body, with a history of harassment by the husband in demand of money. b. 303 IPC
3. A person murders his cousin due to a property dispute. c. 304A IPC
4. A life convict out on bail commits the murder of his neighbor d. 304B IPC
questions.solution:
The correct match is

Case Section  Description

Causing death by negligence: "Whoever causes the death of any person, by doing any rash or negligent act not amounting to culpable homicide shall be punished with imprisonment for a term which may extend to two years ·or with fine, or with both.

(2) Whoever commits dowry death shall be punished with imprisonment of not less than ten years, but which may extend to life imprisonment.

You notice that the patient's eyes are swollen due to injury and are unable to open. He is speaking single words. On applying stimulus to the neck, he brings his hand above the clavicle. What is the GCS score in this patient?
questions.solution:
In this case,

  • Eyes cannot be opened due to swelling- NT
  • Verbal response- Able to speak 1-2 words- 3
  • Motor response- The patient is able to localise the stimulus- 5

So, the GCS score in him is ENTV3M5

questions.text: An 82-year-old female patient presented with a non-healing ulcer on the labia majora for 1 year which appears to be 3 cm x 4 cm on the surface. Biopsy shows squamous cell carcinoma. Further investigations reveal the tumour has invaded the upper 2/3rd of the urethra with inguinal lymph node involvement of <5mm. What is the stage of vulval cancer in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a stage IIIA vulval carcinoma, as the tumour has invaded the upper 2/3rd of the urethra with inguinal lymph node involvement of <5mm.

Staging of vulval cancer:

Stage I Tumour confined to the vulva
IA Lesions ≤2 cm in size, and with stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm
IB Lesions >2cm in size or with stromal invasion >1mm

The image below shows Stage II vulval cancer. Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (lower 1/3rd of the urethra, lower 1/3rd of the vagina, lower 1/3rd of the anus) with negative nodes.

The image below shows Stage III vulval cancer. Tumour of any size with/without extension to adjacent perineal structures (upper 2/3rd urethra, upper 2/3rd vagina, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa) with any number of positive nonfixed, nonulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes.

IIIA Regional lymph node metastasis <5mm
IIIB Regional lymph node metastasis >5mm 
IIIC With positive nodes with extracapsular spread

Stage IV: Tumour of any size fixed to bone, or fixed, ulcerated lymph node metastasis or distant structures.

IVA Disease fixed to pelvic bone or fixed or ulcerated regional lymph node metastasis.
IVB Distant metastasis.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy developed skin lesions on his trunk and proximal portion of his arms, 10 days after he recovered from an episode of pharyngitis. The skin lesions are shown in the image below. Which among the following are correct about this condition?
  1. It follows a chronic course
  2. It is associated with HLA‐C:06:02
  3. It responds to broadband UVB phototherapy
  4. May lead to toxicity and hypocalcemia
  5. Acitretin is the drug of choice
questions.solution:
The clinical stem of small, red, drop-like lesions on the trunk and arms (shown in the image) after an attack of pharyngitis is suggestive of Guttate psoriasis, and statements 2 and 3 are correct.

Guttate psoriasis is a type of psoriasis occurring as a sudden onset shower of small lesions seen diffusely over the body, more on the trunk and proximal limbs. It is more common in children and young adults, following infection with group A streptococcus and is often the first presentation of psoriasis. It can also occur as a flare-up in adults with plaque psoriasis that began in childhood. It is linked to HLA‐C:06:02 (statement 2).

Lesions usually resolve over about 3 months. Some patients with acute guttate psoriasis might develop plaque psoriasis in the future.

Treatment:

  • Topical steroids
  • Antimicrobials: Recurrent episodes may be related to the pharyngeal carriage of the responsible streptococcus by the patient or close contact. A course of a semisynthetic penicillin (Eg dicloxacillin) with rifampin may be required to clear chronic streptococcal carriage.
  • Phototherapy: Broad-band ultraviolet B (UVB): Response is better with broadband UVB (statement 3) over narrow-band UVB. 

Other options:

Statement 1: Plaque psoriasis and follicular psoriasis follow a chronic course.

Statements 4 and 5 are true about pustular psoriasis, where the patient is often ill with fever, erythroderma, hypocalcemia, and cachexia, for which Acetretin is the drug of choice.

questions.text: A young woman was admitted to the psychiatry ward for severe depression with psychotic features, and a complete refusal to eat or drink. During rounds, she was found to be in the position shown in the image below, and resistance was felt in attempting to change her position. Which of the following is the treatment of choice in this case?
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for a patient with severe depression and psychotic features with posturing with waxy flexibility would be electroconvulsive therapy. 

Posturing with waxy flexibility refers to the maintenance of the body position into which they are placed, where any attempt made to change the posture results in resistance felt by the examiner. 

Catatonia is a syndrome characterized by three or more behav­ioral abnormalities such as: 

  • Stupor: Absence of psychomotor activity and not actively relating to the environment.
  • Catalepsy: Passive induction of a posture held against gravity.
  • Waxy flexibility: Slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner.
  • Negativism: Opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli.
  • Posturing: Spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity.
  • Mannerism: Odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions.
  • Stereotypy: Repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements
  • Grimacing
  • Echopraxia: Mimicking another's movement.
  • Echolalia: Mimicking another's speech.
  • Mutism: Very little or no verbal response to instructions or external stimuli.

 The primary treatment includes:

  • Identifying and treating underlying medical or pharmacological causes. Any offending substances should be removed.
  • Benzodiazepines, especially, lorazepam, are effective in temporarily improving the symptoms.
  • Electroconvulsive therapy is the definitive treatment in cases of life-threatening catatonia (if the patient is unable to eat) or if the patient has developed malignant catatonia.

Other options:

Option C: Lithium is a mood stabiliser used for the management of mania and bipolar depression. 

Option D: Transcranial magnetic stimulation using magnetic energy stimulates the nerve cells in the brain and is used for the treatment of depression. 

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text:
A baby was born with the following anomaly, who was later diagnosed with OEIS complex. What are the components of this condition?
  1. Gatrochischis
  2. Omphalocele
  3. Hemi-bladders
  4. Hemi-Uteruses
  5. Imperforate Anus
  6. Imperforate Hymen
  7. Spleen abnormalities
  8. Spine abnormalities
questions.solution:
The baby is diagnosed with the OEIS complex, its components are 2, 3, 5, 8.

The given image shows cloacal exstrophy, which includes an exstrophy central bowel area flanked by two Hemi-bladders. Cloacal atrophy can present as part of OEIS syndrome, in which multiple anomalies are seen, where O stands for Omphalocele, E for Exstrophy of bladder or cloaca, I for Imperforate anus, and S for Skeletal anomalies (Kyphoscoliosis/Hemivertebrae).

Exstrophy of the cloaca: The closure of the ventral body wall is more severely affected than in bladder exstrophy. There is the involvement of the bladder and rectum, both of which are derived from the cloaca. In addition, there is defective development of the anorectal septum leading to anal canal malformations and imperforate anus. As the genital swellings are widely separated, external genitalia will be defective.

  2. Competitive ELISA
  3. Direct ELISA
  4. Sandwich ELISA
questions.solution:
ELISA type Image
1. Indirect ELISA B

3. Direct ELISA D
4. Sandwich ELISA C

ELISA is a type of heterogenous Enzyme immunoassay (Enzyme-linked Immunosorbent Assay) is named so because it involves the use of an immunosorbent, an absorbing material specific for one of the components of the reaction: the antigen or antibody.

The steps of Direct ELISA is as shown below :

 

Indirect ELISA : 

It follows the steps of Direct ELISA but here the antigen is bound by the primary antibody which then is detected by a labeled secondary antibody whereas, in direct ELISA only one labelled primary antibody is used.

Sandwich ELISA: It is a variant of that used for antigen detection in a given sample. The antigen is sandwiched between two layers of antibodies - capture and detection antibodies.

Competitive ELISA: It is similar to RIA where both the unknown antigen (sample) and a known antigen (standard) competes for a fixed amount of antibody. This yields an inverse curve where higher values of antigen in the samples/standard yields a lower amount of color change. It is used for hapten detection.

questions.text:
As the chief medical officer of the primary health centre, with the onset of monsoon season, you are tasked with the training of newly employed health workers male under the national vector-borne disease control for malaria. Which of the following will be included as responsibilities of the health workers male?
  1. Surveillance activities
  2. Dispatching blood smears to the PHC laboratory twice a week
  3. Verify results obtained by the use of rapid diagnostic kits
  4. Planning, executing and supervising the administration of radical treatment in consultation with PHC MO.
  5. Contacting the MO and inform the spray dates, and prepare the community for accepting the spray operations.

Abbreviations:  MO - Medical officer; ASHA - Accredited Social Health Activist
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 3 are true about the responsibilities of a Health Worker Male (HWM) pertaining to Malarial control according to the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

The following are all the responsibilities of the HWM :

  1. Surveillance activities.
  2. Collecting thick and thin blood smears on one glass slide from case having fever or giving the history of fever.
  3. Contacting ASHAs and other FTDs during village visits and collecting blood smears already taken by the ASHA, FTD and replenishing drugs, glass slides and Rapid Diagnostic Kits (RDKs)
  4. Dispatching blood smears along with MF-2 to the PHC Laboratory twice a week
  5. Verify results obtained by the use of RDKs and verify the radical treatment administered by the ASHA.
  6. Administering radical treatment to the positive cases as per the drug schedule prescribed, and as per instructions issued by the Medical Officer PHC, and take laid down action if toxic manifestations are observed in a patient receiving radical treatment with primaquine.
  7. Contacting the ASHA and FTD and inform the spray dates, and make requests to motivate the community and prepare them for accepting the spray operations.
  8. Assist the Health Supervisor (Male)/ Health Assistant (Male) in supervising spraying operations and training of field spraying staff.

Planning, executing, and supervising the administration of radical treatment in consultation with the PHC medical officer is the duty of the Health Assistant (Male). The HWM's duty is to follow the plan laid down by the medical officer and the Health Assistant Male and administer treatment. (Statement 4)

Spray dates are informed to the ASHA and not the Medical Officer. Spray operations do not fall under the duties of the medical officer. (Statement 5)

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient, with complaints of cough and high-grade fever, was diagnosed to have pneumonia. He was started on broad-spectrum antibiotics, but his pneumonia did not resolve. In due course of treatment, he also developed painful sores in the mouth, associated with lymphadenopathy. He had been in South America, a few years back.  Culture from the lesion shows the appearance given in the image.  What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The history of travel to South America and the involvement of the reticuloendothelial system suggests the diagnosis of paracoccidioidomycosis. The condition is also called South Amerian Blastomycosis.

The above image shows the characteristic Pilot wheel appearance on culture seen with Paracoccidioides brasiliensis.

Paracoccidioides brasiliensis is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It causes Paracoccidioidomycosis, a chronic granulomatous disease affecting lungs, skin, mucosa, lymph nodes. 

On culture at 37 °C, large oval cells with multiple buds encircling the mother cell are seen This is known as Mariner’s or pilot’s wheel appearance.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text:
'Cataract' surgeries are considered the bread and butter for a practising ophthalmic surgeon. As a young surgeon who wants to reduce the incidence of the below-shown complication, commonly encountered following cataract surgeries in your patients, which of the given steps if taken by you could avert the incidence of development of this condition post-operatively?
  1. Enhance cortical clean up by hydrodissection.
  2. The diameter of capsulorrhexis should be smaller than the diameter of the optic of the IOL.
  3. Prefer PMMA (Polymethyl methacrylate) based IOL.
  4. Use an IOL with a square and truncated optic edge.
  5. Place the IOL within the capsular bag.
questions.solution:
The given image shows Elschnig's pearl, a type of Posterior capsular opacification. Posterior capsular opacification (PCO) or after cataract or secondary cataract is the most common late complication of uncomplicated cataract surgery. The incidence of PCO can be reduced by 1, 2, 4, 5.

Factors that can aid in decreasing the incidence of PCO:

FACTOR IMPORTANT STEPS / PRECAUTIONS THAT CAN AID IN DECREASING THE INCIDENCE OF PCO
Surgery related factors
  1. Enhance cortical clean up by hydrodissection - this can avoid remnants
  2. The performance of capsulorrhexis should be slightly smaller than the diameter of the IOL optic.
  3. The opening of capsulorrhexis should be in complete contact with the anterior surface of the IOL
  4. Prefer in the bag IOL fixation
IOL related factors
  1. Use bio-compatible IOL - these would reduce the stimulation of cellular proliferation.
  2. Enhance contact between the IOL optic and the posterior capsule.
  3. Use IOL with square and truncated optic edge
  4. Limit the use of IOL based on PMMA or hydrogel as they are more prone to PCO. 

 

 

Note:

Despite these advantages, square IOLs are seldom used in clinical practice, as they have higher rates of dysphotopsia. 

 

Posterior capsular opacification also called "after" or "secondary" cataract is the opacity that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens. In this surgery, the posterior capsule and part of the anterior capsule are left in situ which almost always has remnants of the capsule. 

Pathogenesis:

  • These remnants become partially absorbed by the action of the aqueous but often become shut off by adhesion of the remains of the anterior to the posterior capsule. In such cases the cubical cells which line the anterior capsule also persist; they continue to fulfil their function of forming new lens fibres, although those formed under these abnormal conditions are abortive and opaque.
  • Sometimes these fibres, enclosed between the two layers of the capsule, form a dense ring behind the iris (the ring of Sömmerring).
  • At other times, the subcapsular cells proliferate and develop into large balloon-like cells, which sometimes fill the pupillary aperture (Elschnig pearls).
  • If these remnants lie in the pupillary area a dense membrane is formed so that vision is impaired (membranous). 

The rate of posterior capsule opacification following extracapsular cataract extraction (ECCE) and phacoemulsification varies with the age of the patient, the surgeon, the surgical technique, the type of intraocular lens used, and the duration after surgery.

Symptoms:

These include a reduction in visual acuity. These patients present 3 to 6 months post operatively. Other symptoms include blurring of vision, glare, and monocular diplopia. 

Treatment:

  • Nd-YAG laser capsulotomy: The laser used in posterior capsulotomy is Nd: YAG laser (1064 nm) whose principle is photodisruption. The plasma produced at the laser target expands and disrupts the tissues creating an opening.
  • Surgical treatment: Posterior capsular opacification is managed by creating an opening on the posterior capsule along the visual axis, a procedure called a posterior capsulotomy.
  • Other options: discission with cystitome or Zeigler’s knife. 

The given image below shows the presence of a white ring behind the iris with the likely diagnosis being Soemmering’s ring.

 

The below image shows Elschnig’s pearls which are vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells, clustered like soap bubbles along the posterior capsule of the lens.

 

The given image below summarizes the findings of various types of after cataract seen through slit lamp examination. 

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

 

Related Pearl: Types of contact lens (based on the material)

3 types of contact lens (based on the material) are:

  • Hard lenses:
    • Made of PMMA (polymethylmethacrylate)
    • They are sparingly used because of poor patient compliance.
  • Rigid gas permeable lenses/ semi soft lenses:
    • Made up of silicone acrylate and cellulose acetate butyrate (CAB)
  • Soft lenses:
    • Made up of HEMA (hydroxy ethyl methyl acrylate)

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, malaise, and pharyngitis. On examination, splenomegaly was present and lymph nodes were normal. Peripheral smear showed a predominance of lymphocytes. The heterophile antibody test result is negative. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Fever, malaise, pharyngitis, splenomegaly with lymphocytosis suggest infectious mononucleosis. Cytomegalovirus is the most common causative agent of heterophile-negative infectious mononucleosis.

Patients may develop CMV infectious mononucleosis spontaneously or after transfusion of leukocyte-containing blood products. They present with fever, malaise, pharyngitis and splenomegaly. Cervical lymphadenopathy is rare. Some patients develop rubelliform rashes after exposure to ampicillin. Unlike EBV mononucleosis, heterophile antibodies are negative. This condition is less severe than the infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient presented with a complaint of lower backache. The MRI of her lumbosacral spine is given below. Her bone mineral density is measured, and her T-score is -2.8. She is given oral drugs, but she develops esophagitis. Which of the following intravenous treatment plans would be useful in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray depicts the ballooning of disc spaces, leading to the biconcave shape of the vertebral body, which is known as the ‘codfish' appearance. Along with a T-score of -2.8, it is diagnostic of postmenopausal osteoporosis. Zoledronate 5 mg intravenous annually is used in the management of postmenopausal osteoporosis. It belongs to a class of drugs called bisphosphonates.

Bisphosphonates inhibit bone resorption and thus are very effective for the treatment of postmenopausal osteoporosis. They get concentrated at sites of active remodeling and remain in the matrix until the bone is remodeled. Then, they are released in the acid environment of the resorption lacunae and induce apoptosis in osteoclasts.

Routes of administration - Certain bisphosphonates like etidronate, alendronate, risedronate, and tiludronate may be administered orally, while others like zoledronate, ibandronate, and pamidronate can be given intravenously. Intravenous formulations are given when oral formulations cannot be taken due to side effects like esophagitis.

Zoledronate: It can be administered via intravenous infusion for over 15 minutes. It is given once a year, and the dose given is 5 mg for osteoporosis in postmenopausal females. A single 5-mg infusion of zoledronate is also used for the treatment of Paget disease, lowering bone turnover markers for 6 months without losing its therapeutic impact. For patients with hormone-treated prostate and breast cancer, zoledronate is frequently given to prevent osteoporosis. Both vertebral and nonvertebral fractures are decreased by it. For the treatment of multiple myeloma, bone metastases from solid tumors, or hypercalcemia of malignancy, a 4-mg formulation is offered for intravenous administration. 

Other options:

Options A and B - Teriparatide is a recombinant parathormone analog that has an anabolic effect on bone homeostasis when given intermittently. It acts by increasing osteoblastic activity. It increases bone mineral density and decreases the risk of fractures in postmenopausal women. It is administered as a subcutaneous injection of 20 μg once daily.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

Risk factor for osteoporosis
Low BMI
