Chronic use of glucocorticoids
Family history of hip fractures
Smoking and alcohol intake
Drugs like anticonvulsants, anticoagulants and thyroid replacement therapy
Hyperparathyroidism, multiple myeloma, and malabsorption syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely in patients with atheroembolic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Atheroembolic kidney disease is associated with decreased complement levels.

Atheroembolic kidney disease is more frequent in males with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and ischemic heart disease.  Most clinical atheroembolic events follow angiographic procedures, often of the coronary vessels.

It is associated with aortic aneurysms and renal artery stenosis. Systemic embolic manifestations such as fever, abdominal pain, and weight loss are also present, although cutaneous manifestations are more common like livedo reticularis and localized toe gangrene.

The lab findings include:

  • Rising serum creatinine
  • Transient eosinophilia
  • Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate
  • Hypocomplementemia

Definitive diagnosis depends on kidney biopsy which demonstrates microvessel occlusion with cholesterol crystals that leave a cleft in the vessel as shown below.

questions.text: In the following left ventricle (LV) pressure-volume loop diagram, the aortic valve will open at point ________.
questions.solution:
The aortic valve will open at point 3.

  • 1 - Mitral valve opens
  • 2 - Mitral valve closes
  • 3 - Aortic valve opens
  • 4 - Aortic valve closes

Pressure-volume diagram during the cardiac cycle:

The pressure-volume diagram plots the changes in the pressure and volume in the left ventricle that occur during the cardiac cycle. The X-axis shows the changes in ventricular volume, while the Y-axis shows the changes in ventricular pressure.

 

It has the following phases.

Phase I- This phase is called the period of filling and extends between points A and B. Point A is at the end of systole when the ventricular volume is about 50 mL. This volume is called end-systolic volume. The pressure at this point is about 2 to 3 mmHg. The volume and pressure go on increasing as the blood from the atrium flows to the ventricle during diastole. At the end of diastole, marked by point B, the ventricle will have a volume of around 120 mL. This volume is called end-diastolic volume. The pressure is slightly raised to 5-7 mmHg. 

Phase II- It is the phase of isovolumetric contraction, and extends between points B and C. At the end of diastole (point B), a slight increase in the ventricular pressure closes the mitral valve, and contraction starts. The ventricle contracts while both mitral and aortic valves are closed. Therefore, the pressure within the ventricle slowly rises without any changes in the volume. 

Phase III- It is the phase of ejection and extends between point C and point D. Point C is the place where the aortic valve opens. The pressure within the left ventricle rises slowly during isovolumetric contraction until it is sufficient to open the aortic valve. Once the aortic valve opens, blood within the left ventricle is ejected into the aorta. This decreases the volume of the left ventricle, while increasing the pressure within the ventricle.

Phase IV- It is the period of isovolumetric relaxation. It extends between points D and A. At the end of the ejection (Point D), the aortic valve closes. However, the ventricular relaxation continues despite closed aortic and mitral valves. Therefore, the ventricular pressure continues to fall while the volume remains the same. The ventricle returns to its starting point, with about 50 mL of blood left in the ventricle and pressure of about 2 to 3 mmHg.

End-systolic pressure-volume relationship (ESPVR)

ESPVR is the maximum pressure that can be developed by the ventricle at the end-systolic volume. It is determined by the line intersecting the upper left corners of the loops. This line can be extended down to the x-axis. The slope of this line is called as ESPVR slope.

questions.text:
A 15-month-old child is admitted for the treatment of severe acute malnutrition (SAM). Identify the incorrect statements about the treatment of micronutrient deficiencies.
  1. Vitamin A should be supplemented on days 1, 2 and 14 
  2. Iron therapy can be started from day 2 onwards
  3. 5mg of folic acid to be given on day 1, 1mg to be given subsequently
  4. Copper and other trace minerals are added to the ReSoMal solution and given from day 1
  5. Zinc should be avoided till 2 weeks of stabilization is complete
questions.solution:
The incorrect statements are 2 and 5. Iron should not be given in the initial stabilization phase and zinc can be started in the stabilization phase, given with F75/F100 feeds or ReSoMal.

The general treatment involves 10 steps in 2 phases:

Initial stabilization phase: It focuses on restoring homeostasis and treating medical conditions and requires 2-7 days of inpatient treatment.

Rehabilitation phase: It focuses on rebuilding wasted tissue and generally takes several weeks (2nd to 6th week).

Steps:

  • Treat hypoglycemia (blood glucose level <54 mg/dl): if symptomatic, give 10% Dextrose IV at 5ml/kg. Feeding should be initiated with starter F-75 (formula with 75 kcal/100 ml of feed)
  • Treat hypothermia (axillary <35°C or 95°F): Skin-to-skin contact with care called “kangaroo technique” or dress in warmer clothes, cover head, wrap in a warmed blanket, and provide indirect heat.
  • Treat dehydration: Hydrate with ReSoMal (45 mmol Na/L). It is a low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition.
  • Correct electrolyte imbalance: There is a deficit of potassium and magnesium and excess sodium. Give extra potassium (3 to 4 mEq/kg/day) and magnesium (4 mEq/ kg/day) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Treat an infection: Starting on the first day, give broad-spectrum antibiotics to all children.
  • Correct micronutrient deficiencies:
    • Do not give iron in the stabilization phase, because excess iron leads to free radical injury. Give iron 3 mg/kg/day once the child starts gaining weight after the stabilization phase.
    • Give vitamin A on day 1. Repeat on day 2 and day 14. (Dose: Age <6 months: 50,000 units; Age 6-12 months: 100,000 units; Age >12 months 200,000 units)
    • Folic acid 1 mg (5 mg on day 1)
    • Zinc (2 mg/kg/day)
    • Copper (0.3 mg/kg/day)
    • Give Vitamin K 2.5 mg as a single intramuscular dose at the time of admission.
  • Start cautious feeding: Give 8 to 12 small feeds of F75 feeds. It is low-lactose milk that contains 75 kcal and 0.9 g protein per 100 mL.  After 3 days (usually within 1 week), transition to F100 feeds is made which is called a catch-up diet. This provides 100 kcal and 2.9 g protein per 100 mL. After 1 week, calories are further increased to 150–200 kcal/kg/day and protein to 4–6 g/kg/day.
  • Rehabilitation: The indications of entry to this phase are reduced/minimal oedema and the return of appetite.
    • Beginning of feeding.
    • After 3 days, the transition to energy-dense feeding
    • Stimulation of emotional and sensorial development
    • Transfer to home-based diet

 

Mnemonic: SHIELDED

Sugar deficiency(hypoglycemia) 
Hypothermia
Infection
ELectrolyte imbalance
DEhydration
Deficiency of nutrients

questions.text: Match the following intracranial bleed:

choices.text: A -i B-ii C- iii  D- iv

questions.solution:
Epidural hematoma:

Noncontrasted axial computed tomography scan showing a lenticular area of increased density in left parietal region.

  • Typically occur in the groove of the middle meningeal artery associated with temporal bone fractures that have resulted in a tear of middle meningeal artery.
  • They tend to not to cross suture lines of the skull.

Subdural hematoma:

A non contrasted computed tomography scan of acute subdural hematoma shows a cresentric area of increased density in the right posterior parietal region between brain and the skull. An area of intraparenchymal haemorrhage also seen. In addition, mass effect causes a midline shift to left.

  • They can cross suture lines but they do not cross the tentorium or falx.
  • Can be acute or chronic

Subarachnoid haemorrhage:

A non contrasted axial computed tomography scan shows the blood as areas of increased density near the base of the brain shows blood in Texaco star pattern formed blood radiating from suprasellar cistern into the sylvian fissures and anterior interhemispheric fissure.

  • Most often accompanied by severe sudden onset headache.
  • Can really be visualised in acute stage, when blood is radiographically dense (whiter) than the CSF.

Intracereberal haemorrhage:

Non contrast computed tomography shows a large area of fresh blood appearing white in the region of right thalamus. Blood is denser than CSF so settles dependently.

This settling is not seen with subarachnoid or interparenchymal blood.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text:
You are attending the ENT practical examination. Your external examiner gives you the following instrument in your viva station and asks you to state the uses of the same. Which of the following would constitute the part of your answer?
  1. It is used to depress the tongue
  2. Used for examining both the oral cavity and oropharynx.
  3. Assists while performing posterior rhinoscopy
  4. It can aid in the diagnosis of septic tonsillitis
  5. It can aid in performing Cottle's test
questions.solution:
The given image shows Lack's tongue depressor.

These are available in different sizes for adults and children. It is a very commonly used instrument in the field of ENT.

Uses:

  • It is used to depress the tongue
  • Used for examining both the oral cavity and oropharynx.
  • Lateral gutters are better examined by two tongue depressors; one retracting the tongue and the other retracting the cheek.
  • It can be used to examine the floor of the mouth by medially pushing down the lateral surface of the tongue. Thereby it also aids in the examination of the gums and oral buccal mucosa.
  • It is used to check the patency of the nose by spatula test.
  • Assists while performing posterior rhinoscopy.
  • It can aid in the diagnosis of septic tonsillitis. Pressure on the anterior pillar with the edge of the tongue depressor may express cheesy material from the crypts (normal) of frank fluid pus (septic tonsil). 

The above image shows Cottle test where cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly.
If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve.

The images below depict the method of performing posterior rhinoscopy and the various structures visualised in the posterior rhinoscopy mirror. 

The image attached below depicts the spatula test.  A cold tongue depressor is used to perform the spatula test. A tongue depressor is held below the nostrils to look for the area of mist formation, when the patient exhales, the two sides are compared.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man presents to the hospital with complaints of irritability, increased sweating, and weight loss of around 6 kgs for the last 3 months. On examination, the patient has tachycardia and enlarged neck mass which moves with deglutition. An image of the patient is shown below. Which of the following statements are true regarding the hormone elevated in this patient?
  1. T4 has a longer half-life than T3
  2. T3 is more in concentration than T4
  3. This hormone binds to nuclear receptors
  4. Iodine transporter is also present in pituitary gland
  5. Drugs used in this condition primarily act by inhibiting deiodinase
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of Graves disease. Thyroid hormone is elevated in this patient. Statements 1 and 3 are true regarding the thyroid hormone.

Synthesis- Iodine is required for the synthesis of thyroid hormone. Absorbed iodine is taken by the thyroid follicular cells with the help of a sodium iodide transporter (NIS). NIS is mainly present in the thyroid gland, but it can also be present in salivary glands, lactating breast, and placenta. NIS is not present in the pituitary gland.

The iodine that enters the thyroid gland undergoes organification and is added to tyrosyl residues within thyroglobulin. These iodotyrosines are then coupled to form T4 and T3 hormones. This reaction is catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase. After coupling, the thyroglobulin is taken back into the cells to release T4 and T3. Uncoupled mono and diiodotyrosines are deiodinated by the enzyme dehalogenase to recycle iodine.

T3 and T4 are the two forms of the hormone. T4 is present in higher concentrations and has a longer half-life than T3. However, T3 is more potent than T4.

Thyroid hormones enter the cell by passive diffusion or by the transporters. On entering the cell, they bind to the nuclear thyroid hormone receptors. On binding to the receptors, they either stimulate or inhibit transcription.

Methimazole, carbimazole and propylthiouracil are the drugs used in the management of hyperthyroidism. They act by inhibiting thyroid peroxidase. In addition to this, propylthiouracil also inhibits the deiodination of T4 → T3. 

Drugs that prevent deiodination of T4 to T3 are propylthiouracil, propranolol, amiodarone, and oral cholecystographic agents.

questions.text: A 32-year-old farmer from Eastern UP presented to the local PHC with a scrotal swelling and edema of the right leg. Suspecting filariasis, he was subjected to the DEC Provocation test.  Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this test?

choices.text: 100 mg of DEC is administered orally
Can be done during the day time
This test is cumbersome for surveys
Blood collected in 20-50 minutes will show microfilariae

questions.solution:
DEC provocation test has a great advantage for surveys as blood collected 20-50 minutes after the DEC administration will show microfilariae and the blood collection can be done during daytime. DEC provocation test is used to demonstrate microfilaria in Wuchereria bancrofti infection.

Diethylcarbamazine is administered as 100 mg or 2 mg/kg body weight orally. This causes the mobilization of microfilariae into the peripheral blood and thus detection of microfilariae by the collection of a sample of peripheral blood.

Wuchereria bancrofti is a filarial nematode that causes lymphatic filariasis. The adult worms reside in the lymphatics and mechanical obstruction by the adult worms or allergic inflammatory reaction to worm antigens is responsible for the clinical manifestations of lymphatic filariasis. 

The microfilaria, on the other hand, are present in the blood of humans where they demonstrate nocturnal periodicity, wherein the microfilaria appear in the peripheral blood only during nighttime and migrate to vessels of the lung or kidneys during the day time. Hence a sample of peripheral blood for identification of the microfilariae is collected during the nighttime, between 10 pm to 4 am.

On microscopy, these microfilariae have sheathed bodies with blunt heads and pointed tails. They have no nuclei at their tail tip. These features can help in distinguishing the microfilaria of Wuchereria from those of other filarial nematodes.

Detection of microfilariae is done by examination of a thick and thin blood smear, stained with Giemsa stain. Examination of the unstained mount of blood under a microscope using an acridine-orange microhematocrit tube technique can also be done. Detection of the adult worm is done by lymph node biopsy, X-ray (if worms are calcified), and high-frequency ultrasound Doppler of the scrotum.

Indirect evidence includes eosinophilia in blood and elevated serum IgE levels. Immunodiagnosis involves antigen detection by ELISA (enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) and ICT (immunochromatographic test). Antibody detection tests have low sensitivity and specificity. Molecular diagnosis is done by PCR (polymerase chain reaction). This test is positive only when microfilariae are present in peripheral blood. It is negative in chronic filariasis.

Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice. The life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti is given below:

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman was found dead at a cafe around midnight. Her face was congested with marked petechiae and her tongue was protruded and swollen. On examination, signs of struggle and a pale transverse mark completely encircling her neck below the thyroid cartilage were noted. Which of the following is the likely cause of her death?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and examination findings of a pale transverse mark completely encircling her neck below the thyroid cartilage with signs of struggle point toward a diagnosis of strangulation by ligature.

Strangulation is a type of asphyxia where there is neck constriction without suspension of the body. The pressure on the neck is applied either by bare hands, a ligature, or by any other instrument.

When strangulation is done by using a ligature like a constricting band or rope, it is called ligature strangulation. The constricting band is tightened by a force other than the victim's body weight. It is characterized by the ligature mark which is transverse and completely encircling the neck below the thyroid cartilage. There is no dribbling of saliva. Bleeding may be present in the ears, nose, and mouth.

Other options:

Option A: In a cafe coronary syndrome, the victim is usually healthy but grossly intoxicated and dies suddenly and unexpectedly during a meal with no signs of respiratory distress or of asphyxia. The autopsy reveals a bolus of food lodged in the pharynx or larynx. The cause of death in these patients is mechanical asphyxia leading to vasovagal reflex causing reflex cardiac inhibition.

Option B: Throttling or manual strangulation occurs due to compression of the neck by humans leading to asphyxia. Thumb impression and finger marks may be seen over the victim's neck. It is characterized by autopsy findings showing carotid intimal tear and muscle hematoma with nail marks on the neck and absence of ligature marks.

Option D: Mugging is a method of strangulation wherein the neck of the victim is caught in the bend of the assailant's elbow as shown below. Pressure is usually applied either in front of the larynx or at one or both sides of the neck.
